-   A property cannot be reported as non-configurable, if it does not exists as an own property of the target object or if it exists as a configurable own property of the target object.

<span id="sec-9.5.6" class="secnum">[9.5.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-defineownproperty-p-desc "link to this section")</span> \[\[DefineOwnProperty\]\] (P, Desc)
==================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the \[\[DefineOwnProperty\]\] internal method of a Proxy exotic object O is called with [property key](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-type) P and [Property Descriptor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-property-descriptor-specification-type) *Desc*, the following steps are taken:

1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [IsPropertyKey](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ispropertykey)(*P*) is **true**.
2.  Let *handler* be the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
3.  If *handler* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
4.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*handler*) is Object.
5.  Let *target* be the value of the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
6.  Let *trap* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*handler*, `"defineProperty"`).
7.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trap*).
8.  If *trap* is **undefined**, then
    1.  Return *target*.\[\[DefineOwnProperty\]\](*P*, *Desc*).

9.  Let *descObj* be [FromPropertyDescriptor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-frompropertydescriptor)(*Desc*).
10. Let *booleanTrapResult* be [ToBoolean](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-toboolean)([Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*trap*, *handler*, «*target*, *P*, *descObj*»)).
11. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*booleanTrapResult*).
12. If *booleanTrapResult* is **false**, return **false**.
13. Let *targetDesc* be *target*.\[\[GetOwnProperty\]\](*P*).
14. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*targetDesc*).
15. Let *extensibleTarget* be [IsExtensible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-isextensible-o)(*target*).
16. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*extensibleTarget*).
17. If *Desc* has a \[\[Configurable\]\] field and if *Desc*.\[\[Configurable\]\] is **false,** then
    1.  Let *settingConfigFalse* be **true**.

18. Else let *settingConfigFalse* be **false**.
19. If *targetDesc* is **undefined**, then
    1.  If *extensibleTarget* is **false**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
    2.  If *settingConfigFalse* is **true**, throw a **TypeError** exception.

20. Else *targetDesc* is not **undefined*,***
    1.  If [IsCompatiblePropertyDescriptor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-iscompatiblepropertydescriptor)(*extensibleTarget*, *Desc* , *targetDesc*) is **false**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
    2.  If *settingConfigFalse* is **true** and *targetDesc*.\[\[Configurable\]\] is **true**, throw a **TypeError** exception.

21. Return **true**.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> \[\[DefineOwnProperty\]\] for proxy objects enforces the following invariants:

-   The result of \[\[DefineOwnProperty\]\] is a Boolean value.

-   A property cannot be added, if the target object is not extensible.

-   A property cannot be non-configurable, unless there exists a corresponding non-configurable own property of the target object.

-   If a property has a corresponding target object property then applying the [Property Descriptor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-property-descriptor-specification-type) of the property to the target object using \[\[DefineOwnProperty\]\] will not throw an exception.

<span id="sec-9.5.7" class="secnum">[9.5.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-hasproperty-p "link to this section")</span> \[\[HasProperty\]\] (P)
===========================================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the \[\[HasProperty\]\] internal method of a Proxy exotic object O is called with [property key](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-type) P, the following steps are taken:

1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [IsPropertyKey](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ispropertykey)(*P*) is **true**.
2.  Let *handler* be the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
3.  If *handler* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
4.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*handler*) is Object.
5.  Let *target* be the value of the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
6.  Let *trap* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*handler*, `"has"`).
7.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trap*).
8.  If *trap* is **undefined**, then
    1.  Return *target*.\[\[HasProperty\]\](*P*).

9.  Let *booleanTrapResult* be [ToBoolean](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-toboolean)([Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*trap*, *handler*, «*target*, *P*»)).
10. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*booleanTrapResult*).
11. If *booleanTrapResult* is **false**, then
    1.  Let *targetDesc* be *target*.\[\[GetOwnProperty\]\](*P*).
    2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*targetDesc*).
    3.  If *targetDesc* is not **undefined**, then
        1.  If *targetDesc*.\[\[Configurable\]\] is **false**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
        2.  Let *extensibleTarget* be [IsExtensible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-isextensible-o)(*target*).
        3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*extensibleTarget*).
        4.  If *extensibleTarget* is **false**, throw a **TypeError** exception.

12. Return *booleanTrapResult*.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> \[\[HasProperty\]\] for proxy objects enforces the following invariants:

-   The result of \[\[HasProperty\]\] is a Boolean value.

-   A property cannot be reported as non-existent, if it exists as a non-configurable own property of the target object.

-   A property cannot be reported as non-existent, if it exists as an own property of the target object and the target object is not extensible.

<span id="sec-9.5.8" class="secnum">[9.5.8](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-get-p-receiver "link to this section")</span> \[\[Get\]\] (P, Receiver)
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the \[\[Get\]\] internal method of a Proxy exotic object O is called with [property key](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-type) P and [ECMAScript language value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types) *Receiver* the following steps are taken:

1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [IsPropertyKey](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ispropertykey)(*P*) is **true**.
2.  Let *handler* be the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
3.  If *handler* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
4.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*handler*) is Object.
5.  Let *target* be the value of the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
6.  Let *trap* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*handler*, `"get"`).
7.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trap*).
8.  If *trap* is **undefined**, then
    1.  Return *target*.\[\[Get\]\](*P*, *Receiver*).

9.  Let *trapResult* be [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*trap*, *handler*, «*target*, *P*, *Receiver*»).
10. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trapResult*).
11. Let *targetDesc* be *target*.\[\[GetOwnProperty\]\](*P*).
12. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*targetDesc*).
13. If *targetDesc* is not **undefined**, then
    1.  If [IsDataDescriptor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-isdatadescriptor)(*targetDesc*) and *targetDesc*.\[\[Configurable\]\] is **false** and *targetDesc*.\[\[Writable\]\] is **false**, then
        1.  If [SameValue](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-samevalue)(*trapResult*, *targetDesc*.\[\[Value\]\]) is **false**, throw a **TypeError** exception.

    2.  If [IsAccessorDescriptor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-isaccessordescriptor)(*targetDesc*) and *targetDesc*.\[\[Configurable\]\] is **false** and *targetDesc*.\[\[Get\]\] is **undefined**, then
        1.  If *trapResult* is not **undefined**, throw a **TypeError** exception.

14. Return *trapResult*.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> \[\[Get\]\] for proxy objects enforces the following invariants:

-   The value reported for a property must be the same as the value of the corresponding target object property if the target object property is a non-writable, non-configurable own data property.

-   The value reported for a property must be **undefined** if the corresponding target object property is a non-configurable own accessor property that has **undefined** as its \[\[Get\]\] attribute.

<span id="sec-9.5.9" class="secnum">[9.5.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-set-p-v-receiver "link to this section")</span> \[\[Set\]\] ( P, V, Receiver)
====================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the \[\[Set\]\] internal method of a Proxy exotic object O is called with [property key](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-type) P, value V, and [ECMAScript language value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types) *Receiver*, the following steps are taken:

1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [IsPropertyKey](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ispropertykey)(*P*) is **true**.
2.  Let *handler* be the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
3.  If *handler* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
4.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*handler*) is Object.
5.  Let *target* be the value of the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
6.  Let *trap* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*handler*, `"set"`).
7.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trap*).
8.  If *trap* is **undefined**, then
    1.  Return *target*.\[\[Set\]\](*P*, *V*, *Receiver*).

9.  Let *booleanTrapResult* be [ToBoolean](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-toboolean)([Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*trap*, *handler*, «*target*, *P*, *V*, *Receiver*»)).
10. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*booleanTrapResult*).
11. If *booleanTrapResult* is **false**, return **false**.
12. Let *targetDesc* be *target*.\[\[GetOwnProperty\]\](*P*).
13. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*targetDesc*).
14. If *targetDesc* is not **undefined**, then
    1.  If [IsDataDescriptor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-isdatadescriptor)(*targetDesc*) and *targetDesc*.\[\[Configurable\]\] is **false** and *targetDesc*.\[\[Writable\]\] is **false**, then
        1.  If [SameValue](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-samevalue)(*V*, *targetDesc*.\[\[Value\]\]) is **false**, throw a **TypeError** exception.

    2.  If [IsAccessorDescriptor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-isaccessordescriptor)(*targetDesc*) and *targetDesc*.\[\[Configurable\]\] is **false**, then
        1.  If *targetDesc*.\[\[Set\]\] is **undefined**, throw a **TypeError** exception.

15. Return **true**.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> \[\[Set\]\] for proxy objects enforces the following invariants:

-   The result of \[\[Set\]\] is a Boolean value.

-   Cannot change the value of a property to be different from the value of the corresponding target object property if the corresponding target object property is a non-writable, non-configurable own data property.

-   Cannot set the value of a property if the corresponding target object property is a non-configurable own accessor property that has **undefined** as its \[\[Set\]\] attribute.

<span id="sec-9.5.10" class="secnum">[9.5.10](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-delete-p "link to this section")</span> \[\[Delete\]\] (P)
===================================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the \[\[Delete\]\] internal method of a Proxy exotic object O is called with [property key](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-type) P the following steps are taken:

1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [IsPropertyKey](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ispropertykey)(*P*) is **true**.
2.  Let *handler* be the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
3.  If *handler* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
4.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*handler*) is Object.
5.  Let *target* be the value of the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
6.  Let *trap* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*handler*, `"deleteProperty"`).
7.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trap*).
8.  If *trap* is **undefined**, then
    1.  Return *target*.\[\[Delete\]\](*P*).

9.  Let *booleanTrapResult* be [ToBoolean](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-toboolean)([Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*trap*, *handler*, «*target*, *P*»)).
10. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*booleanTrapResult*).
11. If *booleanTrapResult* is **false**, return **false**.
12. Let *targetDesc* be *target*.\[\[GetOwnProperty\]\](*P*).
13. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*targetDesc*).
14. If *targetDesc* is **undefined**, return **true**.
15. If *targetDesc*.\[\[Configurable\]\] is **false**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
16. Return **true**.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> \[\[Delete\]\] for proxy objects enforces the following invariant:

-   The result of \[\[Delete\]\] is a Boolean value.
-   A property cannot be reported as deleted, if it exists as a non-configurable own property of the target object.

<span id="sec-9.5.11" class="secnum">[9.5.11](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-enumerate "link to this section")</span> \[\[Enumerate\]\] ()
======================================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the \[\[Enumerate\]\] internal method of a Proxy exotic object O is called the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *handler* be the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
2.  If *handler* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
3.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*handler*) is Object.
4.  Let *target* be the value of the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
5.  Let *trap* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*handler*, `"enumerate"`).
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trap*).
7.  If *trap* is **undefined**, then
    1.  Return *target*.\[\[Enumerate\]\]().

8.  Let *trapResult* be [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*trap*, *handler*, «*target*»).
9.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trapResult*).
10. If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*trapResult*) is not Object, throw a **TypeError** exception.
11. Return *trapResult*.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> \[\[Enumerate\]\] for proxy objects enforces the following invariants:

-   The result of \[\[Enumerate\]\] must be an Object.

<span id="sec-9.5.12" class="secnum">[9.5.12](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-ownpropertykeys "link to this section")</span> \[\[OwnPropertyKeys\]\] ( )
===================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the \[\[OwnPropertyKeys\]\] internal method of a Proxy exotic object O is called the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *handler* be the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
2.  If *handler* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
3.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*handler*) is Object.
4.  Let *target* be the value of the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
5.  Let *trap* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*handler*, `"ownKeys"`).
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trap*).
7.  If *trap* is **undefined**, then
    1.  Return *target*.\[\[OwnPropertyKeys\]\]().

8.  Let *trapResultArray* be [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*trap*, *handler*, «*target*»).
9.  Let *trapResult* be [CreateListFromArrayLike](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createlistfromarraylike)(*trapResultArray*, «‍String, Symbol»).
10. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trapResult*).
11. Let *extensibleTarget* be [IsExtensible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-isextensible-o)(*target*).
12. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*extensibleTarget*).
13. Let *targetKeys* be *target*.\[\[OwnPropertyKeys\]\]().
14. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*targetKeys*).
15. [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *targetKeys* is a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) containing only String and Symbol values.
16. Let *targetConfigurableKeys* be an empty [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type).
17. Let *targetNonconfigurableKeys* be an empty [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type).
18. Repeat, for each element *key* of *targetKeys*,
    1.  Let *desc* be *target*.\[\[GetOwnProperty\]\](*key*).
    2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*desc*).
    3.  If *desc* is not **undefined** and *desc.*\[\[Configurable\]\] is **false**, then
        1.  Append *key* as an element of *targetNonconfigurableKeys*.

    4.  Else,
        1.  Append *key* as an element of *targetConfigurableKeys*.

19. If *extensibleTarget* is **true** and *targetNonconfigurableKeys* is empty, then
    1.  Return *trapResult*.

20. Let *uncheckedResultKeys* be a new [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) which is a copy of *trapResult*.
21. Repeat, for each *key* that is an element of *targetNonconfigurableKeys*,
    1.  If *key* is not an element of *uncheckedResultKeys*, throw a **TypeError** exception.
    2.  Remove *key* from *uncheckedResultKeys*

22. If *extensibleTarget* is **true**, return *trapResult*.
23. Repeat, for each *key* that is an element of *targetConfigurableKeys*,
    1.  If *key* is not an element of *uncheckedResultKeys*, throw a **TypeError** exception.
    2.  Remove *key* from *uncheckedResultKeys*

24. If *uncheckedResultKeys* is not empty, throw a **TypeError** exception.
25. Return *trapResult*.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> \[\[OwnPropertyKeys\]\] for proxy objects enforces the following invariants:

-   The result of \[\[OwnPropertyKeys\]\] is a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type).

-   The Type of each result [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) element is either String or Symbol.

-   The result [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) must contain the keys of all non-configurable own properties of the target object.

-   If the target object is not extensible, then the result [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) must contain all the keys of the own properties of the target object and no other values.

<span id="sec-9.5.13" class="secnum">[9.5.13](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-call-thisargument-argumentslist "link to this section")</span> \[\[Call\]\] (thisArgument, argumentsList)
==================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The \[\[Call\]\] internal method of a Proxy exotic object O is called with parameters thisArgument and argumentsList, a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) of [ECMAScript language values](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types). The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *handler* be the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
2.  If *handler* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
3.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*handler*) is Object.
4.  Let *target* be the value of the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
5.  Let *trap* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*handler*, `"apply"`).
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trap*).
7.  If *trap* is **undefined**, then
    1.  Return [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*target*, *thisArgument*, *argumentsList*).

8.  Let *argArray* be [CreateArrayFromList](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createarrayfromlist)(*argumentsList*).
9.  Return [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*trap*, *handler*, «*target*, *thisArgument*, *argArray*»).

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> A Proxy exotic object only has a \[\[Call\]\] internal method if the initial value of its \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) is an object that has a \[\[Call\]\] internal method.

<span id="sec-9.5.14" class="secnum">[9.5.14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-construct-argumentslist-newtarget "link to this section")</span> \[\[Construct\]\] ( argumentsList, newTarget)
=======================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The \[\[Construct\]\] internal method of a Proxy exotic object O is called with parameters argumentsList which is a possibly empty [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) of [ECMAScript language values](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types) and newTarget. The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *handler* be the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
2.  If *handler* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
3.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*handler*) is Object.
4.  Let *target* be the value of the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
5.  Let *trap* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*handler*, `"construct"`).
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*trap*).
7.  If *trap* is **undefined**, then
    1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *target* has a \[\[Construct\]\] internal method.
    2.  Return [Construct](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-construct)(*target*, *argumentsList*, *newTarget*).

8.  Let *argArray* be [CreateArrayFromList](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createarrayfromlist)(*argumentsList*).
9.  Let *newObj* be [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*trap*, *handler*, «*target*, *argArray*, *newTarget* »).
10. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*newObj*).
11. If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*newObj*) is not Object, throw a **TypeError** exception.
12. Return *newObj*.

<span class="nh">NOTE 1</span> A Proxy exotic object only has a \[\[Construct\]\] internal method if the initial value of its \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) is an object that has a \[\[Construct\]\] internal method.

<span class="nh">NOTE 2</span> \[\[Construct\]\] for proxy objects enforces the following invariants:

-   The result of \[\[Construct\]\] must be an Object.

<span id="sec-9.5.15" class="secnum">[9.5.15](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxycreate "link to this section")</span> ProxyCreate(target, handler)
===============================================================================================================================================================================

The abstract operation ProxyCreate with arguments target and handler is used to specify the creation of new Proxy exotic objects. It performs the following steps:

1.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*target*) is not Object, throw a **TypeError** exception.
2.  If *target* is a Proxy exotic object and the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *target* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
3.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*handler*) is not Object, throw a **TypeError** exception.
4.  If *handler* is a Proxy exotic object and the value of the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *handler* is **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
5.  Let *P* be a newly created object.
6.  Set *P*’s essential internal methods (except for \[\[Call\]\] and \[\[Construct\]\]) to the definitions specified in [9.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).
7.  If [IsCallable](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-iscallable)(*target*) is **true**, then
    1.  Set the \[\[Call\]\] internal method of *P* as specified in [9.5.13](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-call-thisargument-argumentslist).
    2.  If *target* has a \[\[Construct\]\] internal method, then
        1.  Set the \[\[Construct\]\] internal method of *P* as specified in [9.5.14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots-construct-argumentslist-newtarget).

8.  Set the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *P* to *target*.
9.  Set the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *P* to *handler*.
10. Return *P*.

<span id="sec-10" class="secnum">[10](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-source-code "link to this section")</span> ECMAScript Language: Source Code
===============================================================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-10.1" class="secnum">[10.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-source-text "link to this section")</span> Source Text
==========================================================================================================================================================

Syntax
------

*SourceCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span>

<span class="gprose">any Unicode code point</span>

ECMAScript code is expressed using Unicode, version 5.1 or later. ECMAScript source text is a sequence of code points. All Unicode code point values from U+0000 to U+10FFFF, including surrogate code points, may occur in source text where permitted by the ECMAScript grammars. The actual encodings used to store and interchange ECMAScript source text is not relevant to this specification. Regardless of the external source text encoding, a conforming ECMAScript implementation processes the source text as if it was an equivalent sequence of *SourceCharacter* values. Each *SourceCharacter* being a Unicode code point. Conforming ECMAScript implementations are not required to perform any normalization of source text, or behave as though they were performing normalization of source text.

The components of a combining character sequence are treated as individual Unicode code points even though a user might think of the whole sequence as a single character.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> In string literals, regular expression literals, template literals and identifiers, any Unicode code point may also be expressed using Unicode escape sequences that explicitly express a code point’s numeric value. Within a comment, such an escape sequence is effectively ignored as part of the comment.

ECMAScript differs from the Java programming language in the behaviour of Unicode escape sequences. In a Java program, if the Unicode escape sequence `\u000A`, for example, occurs within a single-line comment, it is interpreted as a line terminator (Unicode code point U+000A is line feed (lf)) and therefore the next code point is not part of the comment. Similarly, if the Unicode escape sequence `\u000A` occurs within a string literal in a Java program, it is likewise interpreted as a line terminator, which is not allowed within a string literal—one must write `\n` instead of `\u000A` to cause a line feed (lf) to be part of the string value of a string literal. In an ECMAScript program, a Unicode escape sequence occurring within a comment is never interpreted and therefore cannot contribute to termination of the comment. Similarly, a Unicode escape sequence occurring within a string literal in an ECMAScript program always contributes to the literal and is never interpreted as a line terminator or as a code point that might terminate the string literal.

<span id="sec-10.1.1" class="secnum">[10.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding "link to this section")</span> Static Semantics: *UTF16Encoding ( cp )*
=============================================================================================================================================================================================

The UTF16Encoding of a numeric code point value, cp, is determined as follows:

1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): 0 ≤ *cp* ≤ 0x10FFFF.
2.  If *cp* ≤ 65535, return *cp*.
3.  Let *cu1* be [floor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)((*cp* – 65536) / 1024) + 0xD800.
4.  Let *cu2* be ((*cp* – 65536) [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) 1024) + 0xDC00.
5.  Return the code unit sequence consisting of *cu1* followed by *cu2*.

<span id="sec-10.1.2" class="secnum">[10.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16decode "link to this section")</span> Static Semantics: UTF16Decode( lead, trail )
===============================================================================================================================================================================================

Two code units, lead and trail, that form a UTF-16 surrogate pair are converted to a code point by performing the following steps:

1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): 0xD800 ≤ *lead* ≤ 0xDBFF and 0xDC00 ≤ *trail* ≤ 0xDFFF.
2.  Let *cp* be (*lead* – 0xD800) × 1024 + (*trail* – 0xDC00) + 0x10000.
3.  Return the code point *cp*.

<span id="sec-10.2" class="secnum">[10.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-types-of-source-code "link to this section")</span> Types of Source Code
============================================================================================================================================================================

There are four types of ECMAScript code:

-   *Global code* is source text that is treated as an ECMAScript *Script*. The global code of a particular *Script* does not include any source text that is parsed as part of a *FunctionDeclaration*, *FunctionExpression*, *GeneratorDeclaration*, *GeneratorExpression*, *MethodDefinition*, *ArrowFunction, ClassDeclaration*, or *ClassExpression*.

-   *Eval code* is the source text supplied to the built-in `eval` function. More precisely, if the parameter to the built-in `eval` function is a String, it is treated as an ECMAScript *Script*. The eval code for a particular invocation of `eval` is the global code portion of that *Script*.

-   *Function code* is source text that is parsed to supply the value of the \[\[ECMAScriptCode\]\] and \[\[FormalParameters\]\] internal slots ([see 9.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-function-objects)) of an [ECMAScript function object](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-function-objects). The function code of a particular ECMAScript function does not include any source text that is parsed as the function code of a nested *FunctionDeclaration*, *FunctionExpression*, *GeneratorDeclaration*, *GeneratorExpression*, *MethodDefinition*, *ArrowFunction, ClassDeclaration*, or *ClassExpression*.

-   *Module code* is source text that is code that is provided as a *ModuleBody*. It is the code that is directly evaluated when a module is initialized. The module code of a particular module does not include any source text that is parsed as part of a nested *FunctionDeclaration*, *FunctionExpression*, *GeneratorDeclaration*, *GeneratorExpression*, *MethodDefinition*, *ArrowFunction, ClassDeclaration*, or *ClassExpression*.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> Function code is generally provided as the bodies of Function Definitions ([14.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-function-definitions)), Arrow Function Definitions ([14.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-arrow-function-definitions)), Method Definitions ([14.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-method-definitions)) and Generator Definitions ([14.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-generator-function-definitions)). Function code is also derived from the arguments to the `Function` constructor ([19.2.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-function-p1-p2-pn-body)) and the GeneratorFunction constructor ([25.2.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-generatorfunction)).

<span id="sec-10.2.1" class="secnum">[10.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code "link to this section")</span> Strict Mode Code
========================================================================================================================================================================

An ECMAScript *Script* syntactic unit may be processed using either unrestricted or strict mode syntax and semantics. Code is interpreted as *strict mode code* in the following situations:

-   Global code is strict mode code if it begins with a [Directive Prologue](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-directive-prologues-and-the-use-strict-directive) that contains a [Use Strict Directive](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-directive-prologues-and-the-use-strict-directive) (see [14.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-directive-prologues-and-the-use-strict-directive)).

-   Module code is always strict mode code.

-   All parts of a *ClassDeclaration* or a *ClassExpression* are strict mode code.

-   Eval code is strict mode code if it begins with a [Directive Prologue](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-directive-prologues-and-the-use-strict-directive) that contains a [Use Strict Directive](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-directive-prologues-and-the-use-strict-directive) or if the call to eval is a direct eval ([see 12.3.4.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-function-calls-runtime-semantics-evaluation)) that is contained in strict mode code.

-   Function code is strict mode code if the associated *FunctionDeclaration*, *FunctionExpression*, *GeneratorDeclaration*, *GeneratorExpression*, *MethodDefinition*, or *ArrowFunction* is contained in strict mode code or if the code that produces the value of the function’s \[\[ECMAScriptCode\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) begins with a [Directive Prologue](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-directive-prologues-and-the-use-strict-directive) that contains a [Use Strict Directive](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-directive-prologues-and-the-use-strict-directive).

-   Function code that is supplied as the arguments to the built-in `Function` and `Generator` constructors is strict mode code if the last argument is a String that when processed is a *FunctionBody* that begins with a [Directive Prologue](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-directive-prologues-and-the-use-strict-directive) that contains a [Use Strict Directive](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-directive-prologues-and-the-use-strict-directive).

ECMAScript code that is not strict mode code is called *non-strict code*.

<span id="sec-10.2.2" class="secnum">[10.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-non-ecmascript-functions "link to this section")</span> Non-ECMAScript Functions
========================================================================================================================================================================================

An ECMAScript implementation may support the evaluation of exotic function objects whose evaluative behaviour is expressed in some implementation defined form of executable code other than via ECMAScript code. Whether a function object is an ECMAScript code function or a non-ECMAScript function is not semantically observable from the perspective of an ECMAScript code function that calls or is called by such a non-ECMAScript function.

<span id="sec-11" class="secnum">[11](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-lexical-grammar "link to this section")</span> ECMAScript Language: Lexical Grammar
=======================================================================================================================================================================================================

The source text of an ECMAScript *Script* or *Module* is first converted into a sequence of input elements, which are tokens, line terminators, comments, or white space. The source text is scanned from left to right, repeatedly taking the longest possible sequence of code points as the next input element.

There are several situations where the identification of lexical input elements is sensitive to the syntactic grammar context that is consuming the input elements. This requires multiple goal symbols for the lexical grammar. The *InputElementRegExpOrTemplateTail* goal is used in syntactic grammar contexts where a RegularExpressionLiteral, a TemplateMiddle, or a *TemplateTail* is permitted. The *InputElementRegExp* goal symbol is used in all syntactic grammar contexts where a *RegularExpressionLiteral* is permitted but neither a TemplateMiddle, nor a *TemplateTail* is permitted. The *InputElementTemplateTail* goal is used in all syntactic grammar contexts where a *TemplateMiddle* or a *TemplateTail* is permitted but a *RegularExpressionLiteral* is not permitted. In all other contexts, *InputElementDiv* is used as the lexical goal symbol.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The use of multiple lexical goals ensures that there are no lexical ambiguities that would affect [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion). For example, there are no syntactic grammar contexts where both a leading division or division-assignment, and a leading *RegularExpressionLiteral* are permitted. This is not affected by semicolon insertion ([see 11.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion)); in examples such as the following:

    a = b
    /hi/g.exec(c).map(d);

where the first non-whitespace, non-comment code point after a *LineTerminator* is U+002F (SOLIDUS) and the syntactic context allows division or division-assignment, no semicolon is inserted at the *LineTerminator*. That is, the above example is interpreted in the same way as:

    a = b / hi / g.exec(c).map(d);

Syntax
------

*InputElementDiv* <span class="geq">::</span>

*WhiteSpace*

*LineTerminator*

*Comment*

*CommonToken*

*DivPunctuator*

*RightBracePunctuator*

*InputElementRegExp* <span class="geq">::</span>

*WhiteSpace*

*LineTerminator*

*Comment*

*CommonToken*

*RightBracePunctuator*

*RegularExpressionLiteral*

*InputElementRegExpOrTemplateTail* <span class="geq">::</span>

*WhiteSpace*

*LineTerminator*

*Comment*

*CommonToken*

*RegularExpressionLiteral*

*TemplateSubstitutionTail*

*InputElementTemplateTail* <span class="geq">::</span>

*WhiteSpace*

*LineTerminator*

*Comment*

*CommonToken*

*DivPunctuator*

*TemplateSubstitutionTail*

<span id="sec-11.1" class="secnum">[11.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-unicode-format-control-characters "link to this section")</span> Unicode Format-Control Characters
======================================================================================================================================================================================================

The Unicode format-control characters (i.e., the characters in category “Cf” in the Unicode Character Database such as left-to-right mark or right-to-left mark) are control codes used to control the formatting of a range of text in the absence of higher-level protocols for this (such as mark-up languages).

It is useful to allow format-control characters in source text to facilitate editing and display. All format control characters may be used within comments, and within string literals, template literals, and regular expression literals.

U+200C <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">(</span>Zero width non-joiner<span style="font-family: Times New
    Roman">)</span> and U+200D <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">(</span>Zero width joiner<span style="font-family: Times
    New Roman">)</span> are format-control characters that are used to make necessary distinctions when forming words or phrases in certain languages. In ECMAScript source text these code points may also be used in an *IdentifierName* ([see 11.6.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-identifier-names)) after the first character.

U+FEFF <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">(</span>Zero Width no-break space<span style="font-family: Times New
    Roman">)</span> is a format-control character used primarily at the start of a text to mark it as Unicode and to allow detection of the text's encoding and byte order. <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">&lt;ZWNBSP&gt;</span> characters intended for this purpose can sometimes also appear after the start of a text, for example as a result of concatenating files. In ECMAScript source text &lt;ZWNBSP&gt; code points are treated as white space characters ([see 11.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-white-space)).

The special treatment of certain format-control characters outside of comments, string literals, and regular expression literals is summarized in [Table 31](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#table-31).

<span id="table-31">Table 31</span> — Format-Control Code Point Usage

| Code Point | Name                      | Abbreviation   | Usage            |
|------------|---------------------------|----------------|------------------|
| `U+200C`   | Zero width non-joiner     | &lt;ZWNJ&gt;   | *IdentifierPart* |
| `U+200D`   | Zero width joiner         | &lt;ZWJ&gt;    | *IdentifierPart* |
| `U+FEFF`   | ZERO WIDTH NO-BREAK SPACE | &lt;ZWNBSP&gt; | *WhiteSpace*     |

<span id="sec-11.2" class="secnum">[11.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-white-space "link to this section")</span> White Space
==========================================================================================================================================================

White space code points are used to improve source text readability and to separate tokens (indivisible lexical units) from each other, but are otherwise insignificant. White space code points may occur between any two tokens and at the start or end of input. White space code points may occur within a *StringLiteral*, a *RegularExpressionLiteral*, a *Template*, or a *TemplateSubstitutionTail* where they are considered significant code points forming part of a literal value. They may also occur within a *Comment*, but cannot appear within any other kind of token.

The ECMAScript white space code points are listed in [Table 32](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#table-32).

<span id="table-32">Table 32</span> — White Space Code Points

| Code Point          | Name                                            | Abbreviation   |
|---------------------|-------------------------------------------------|----------------|
| `U+0009`            | Character Tabulation                            | &lt;TAB&gt;    |
| `U+000B`            | LINE TABULATION                                 | &lt;VT&gt;     |
| `U+000C`            | Form Feed (ff)                                  | &lt;FF&gt;     |
| `U+0020`            | Space                                           | &lt;SP&gt;     |
| `U+00A0`            | No-break space                                  | &lt;NBSP&gt;   |
| `U+FEFF`            | ZERO wIDTH nO-bREAK SPACE                       | &lt;ZWNBSP&gt; |
| Other category “Zs” | Any other Unicode “Separator, space” code point | &lt;USP&gt;    |

ECMAScript implementations must recognize as *WhiteSpace* code points listed in the “Separator, space” (Zs) category by Unicode 5.1. ECMAScript implementations may also recognize as *WhiteSpace* additional category Zs code points from subsequent editions of the Unicode Standard.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> Other than for the code points listed in [Table 32](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#table-32), ECMAScript *WhiteSpace* intentionally excludes all code points that have the Unicode “White\_Space” property but which are not classified in category “Zs”.

Syntax
------

*WhiteSpace* <span class="geq">::</span>

&lt;TAB&gt;

&lt;VT&gt;

&lt;FF&gt;

&lt;SP&gt;

<span id="sec-11.3" class="secnum">[11.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-line-terminators "link to this section")</span> Line Terminators
====================================================================================================================================================================

Like white space code points, line terminator code points are used to improve source text readability and to separate tokens (indivisible lexical units) from each other. However, unlike white space code points, line terminators have some influence over the behaviour of the syntactic grammar. In general, line terminators may occur between any two tokens, but there are a few places where they are forbidden by the syntactic grammar. Line terminators also affect the process of [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion) ([11.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion)). A line terminator cannot occur within any token except a *StringLiteral*, *Template*, or *TemplateSubstitutionTail*. Line terminators may only occur within a *StringLiteral* token as part of a *LineContinuation*.

A line terminator can occur within a *MultiLineComment* ([11.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-comments)) but cannot occur within a *SingleLineComment*.

Line terminators are included in the set of white space code points that are matched by the `\s` class in regular expressions.

The ECMAScript line terminator code points are listed in [Table 33](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#table-33).

<span id="table-33">Table 33</span> — Line Terminator Code Points

| Code Point | Unicode Name         | Abbreviation |
|------------|----------------------|--------------|
| `U+000A`   | Line Feed (LF)       | &lt;LF&gt;   |
| `U+000D`   | Carriage Return (CR) | &lt;CR&gt;   |
| `U+2028`   | Line separator       | &lt;LS&gt;   |
| `U+2029`   | Paragraph separator  | &lt;PS&gt;   |

Only the Unicode code points in [Table 33](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#table-33) are treated as line terminators. Other new line or line breaking Unicode code points are not treated as line terminators but are treated as white space if they meet the requirements listed in [Table 32](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#table-32). The sequence &lt;CR&gt;&lt;LF&gt; is commonly used as a line terminator. It should be considered a single *SourceCharacter* for the purpose of reporting line numbers.

Syntax
------

*LineTerminator* <span class="geq">::</span>

&lt;LF&gt;

&lt;CR&gt;

&lt;LS&gt;

&lt;PS&gt;

*LineTerminatorSequence* <span class="geq">::</span>

&lt;LF&gt;

&lt;CR&gt; <span class="grhsannot">\[lookahead ≠ &lt;LF&gt; \]</span>

&lt;LS&gt;

&lt;PS&gt;

&lt;CR&gt; &lt;LF&gt;

<span id="sec-11.4" class="secnum">[11.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-comments "link to this section")</span> Comments
====================================================================================================================================================

Comments can be either single or multi-line. Multi-line comments cannot nest.

Because a single-line comment can contain any Unicode code point except a *LineTerminator* code point, and because of the general rule that a token is always as long as possible, a single-line comment always consists of all code points from the `//` marker to the end of the line. However, the *LineTerminator* at the end of the line is not considered to be part of the single-line comment; it is recognized separately by the lexical grammar and becomes part of the stream of input elements for the syntactic grammar. This point is very important, because it implies that the presence or absence of single-line comments does not affect the process of [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion) ([see 11.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion)).

Comments behave like white space and are discarded except that, if a *MultiLineComment* contains a line terminator code point, then the entire comment is considered to be a *LineTerminator* for purposes of parsing by the syntactic grammar.

<span id="sec-11.6" class="secnum">[11.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-names-and-keywords "link to this section")</span> Names and Keywords
========================================================================================================================================================================

*IdentifierName* and *ReservedWord* are tokens that are interpreted according to the Default Identifier Syntax given in Unicode Standard Annex \#31, Identifier and Pattern Syntax, with some small modifications. *ReservedWord* is an enumerated subset of <span style="font-family: Times New
      Roman">*IdentifierName*.</span> The syntactic grammar defines *Identifier* as an *IdentifierName* that is not a *ReservedWord* ([see 11.6.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-reserved-words)). The Unicode identifier grammar is based on character properties specified by the Unicode Standard. The Unicode code points in the specified categories in version 5.1.0 of the Unicode standard must be treated as in those categories by all conforming ECMAScript implementations. ECMAScript implementations may recognize identifier code points defined in later editions of the Unicode Standard.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> This standard specifies specific code point additions: <span style="font-family:
        sans-serif">U+0024</span> (dollar sign) and <span style="font-family: sans-serif">U+005F</span> (<span style="font-family:
        sans-serif">LOW LINE</span>) are permitted anywhere in an *IdentifierName*<span style="font-family: sans-serif">, and the code points</span> <span style="font-family: sans-serif">U+200C (zero-width non-joiner) and U+200D (zero-width joiner) are permitted anywhere after the first code point</span> <span style="font-family: sans-serif">of an</span> *IdentifierName*.

Unicode escape sequences are permitted in an *IdentifierName*, where they contribute a single Unicode code point to the *IdentifierName*. The code point is expressed by the *HexDigits* of the *UnicodeEscapeSequence* ([see 11.8.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-literals-string-literals)). The `\` preceding the *UnicodeEscapeSequence* and the `u` and `{ }` code units, if they appear, do not contribute code points to the *IdentifierName*. A *UnicodeEscapeSequence* cannot be used to put a code point into an *IdentifierName* that would otherwise be illegal. In other words, if a `\` *UnicodeEscapeSequence* sequence were replaced by the *SourceCharacter* it contributes, the result must still be a valid *IdentifierName* that has the exact same sequence of *SourceCharacter* elements as the original *IdentifierName*. All interpretations of *IdentifierName* within this specification are based upon their actual code points regardless of whether or not an escape sequence was used to contribute any particular code point.

Two *IdentifierName* that are canonically equivalent according to the Unicode standard are *not* equal unless, after replacement of each *UnicodeEscapeSequence*, they are represented by the exact same sequence of code points.

The *SourceCharacter* immediately following a *NumericLiteral* must not be an *IdentifierStart* or *DecimalDigit*.

    3in

is an error and not the two input elements `3` and `in`.

A conforming implementation, when processing [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code) ([see 10.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code)), must not extend, as described in [B.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-syntax-numeric-literals), the syntax of *NumericLiteral* to include *Legacy<span style="font-family: Times New Roman">OctalIntegerLiteral</span>*, nor extend the syntax of *DecimalIntegerLiteral* to include *NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral*.

<span id="sec-11.8.3.1" class="secnum">[11.8.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-static-semantics-mv-s "link to this section")</span> Static Semantics: MV’s
=======================================================================================================================================================================================

A numeric literal stands for a value of the Number type. This value is determined in two steps: first, a mathematical value (MV) is derived from the literal; second, this mathematical value is rounded as described below.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*NumericLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *DecimalLiteral*</span> is the MV of *DecimalLiteral*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*NumericLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *BinaryIntegerLiteral*</span> is the MV of *BinaryIntegerLiteral*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*NumericLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *OctalIntegerLiteral*</span> is the MV of *OctalIntegerLiteral*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*NumericLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *HexIntegerLiteral*</span> is the MV of *HexIntegerLiteral*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *DecimalIntegerLiteral* `.`</span> is the MV of *DecimalIntegerLiteral*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *DecimalIntegerLiteral* `.` *DecimalDigits*</span> is the MV of *DecimalIntegerLiteral* plus (the MV of *DecimalDigits* × 10<sup>–*n*</sup>), where *n* is the number of code points in *DecimalDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *DecimalIntegerLiteral* `.` *ExponentPart*</span> is the MV of *DecimalIntegerLiteral* × 10<sup>*e*</sup>, where *e* is the MV of *ExponentPart*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *DecimalIntegerLiteral* `.` *DecimalDigits* *ExponentPart*</span> is (the MV of *DecimalIntegerLiteral* plus (the MV of *DecimalDigits* × 10<sup>–*n*</sup>)) × 10<sup>*e*</sup>, where *n* is the number of code points in *DecimalDigits* and *e* is the MV of *ExponentPart*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `.` *DecimalDigits*</span> is the MV of *DecimalDigits* × 10<sup>–*n*</sup>, where *n* is the number of code points in *DecimalDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `.` *DecimalDigits* *ExponentPart*</span> is the MV of *DecimalDigits* × 10<sup>*e*–*n*</sup>, where *n* is the number of code points in *DecimalDigits* and *e* is the MV of *ExponentPart*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *DecimalIntegerLiteral*</span> is the MV of *DecimalIntegerLiteral*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *DecimalIntegerLiteral* *ExponentPart*</span> is the MV of *DecimalIntegerLiteral* × 10<sup>*e*</sup>, where *e* is the MV of *ExponentPart*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `0`</span> is 0.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *NonZeroDigit*</span> is the MV of *NonZeroDigit.*

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *NonZeroDigit* *DecimalDigits*</span> is (the MV of *NonZeroDigit* × 10<sup>*n*</sup>) plus the MV of *DecimalDigits*, where *n* is the number of code points in *DecimalDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigits* <span class="geq">::</span> *DecimalDigit*</span> is the MV of *DecimalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigits* <span class="geq">::</span> *DecimalDigits* *DecimalDigit*</span> is (the MV of *DecimalDigits* × 10) plus the MV of *DecimalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*ExponentPart* <span class="geq">::</span> *ExponentIndicator* *SignedInteger*</span> is the MV of *SignedInteger*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*SignedInteger* <span class="geq">::</span> *DecimalDigits*</span> is the MV of *DecimalDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*SignedInteger* <span class="geq">::</span> `+` *DecimalDigits*</span> is the MV of *DecimalDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*SignedInteger* <span class="geq">::</span> `-` *DecimalDigits*</span> is the negative of the MV of *DecimalDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `0`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `0`</span> or of <span class="prod">*OctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `0`</span> or of <span class="prod">*BinaryDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `0`</span> is 0.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `1`</span> or of <span class="prod">*NonZeroDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `1`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `1`</span> or of <span class="prod">*OctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `1`</span> or
    of <span class="prod">*BinaryDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `1`</span> is 1.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `2`</span> or of <span class="prod">*NonZeroDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `2`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `2`</span> or of <span class="prod">*OctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `2`</span> is 2.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `3`</span> or of <span class="prod">*NonZeroDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `3`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `3`</span> or of <span class="prod">*OctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `3`</span> is 3.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `4`</span> or of <span class="prod">*NonZeroDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `4`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `4`</span> or of <span class="prod">*OctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `4`</span> is 4.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `5`</span> or of <span class="prod">*NonZeroDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `5`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `5`</span> or of <span class="prod">*OctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `5`</span> is 5.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `6`</span> or of <span class="prod">*NonZeroDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `6`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `6`</span> or of <span class="prod">*OctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `6`</span> is 6.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `7`</span> or of <span class="prod">*NonZeroDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `7`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `7`</span> or of <span class="prod">*OctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `7`</span> is 7.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `8`</span> or of <span class="prod">*NonZeroDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `8`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `8`</span> is 8.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `9`</span> or of <span class="prod">*NonZeroDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `9`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `9`</span> is 9.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `a`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `A`</span> is 10.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `b`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `B`</span> is 11.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `c`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `C`</span> is 12.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `d`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `D`</span> is 13.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `e`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `E`</span> is 14.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `f`</span> or of <span class="prod">*HexDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `F`</span> is 15.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*BinaryIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `0b` *BinaryDigits*</span> is the MV of *BinaryDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*BinaryIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `0B` *BinaryDigits*</span> is the MV of *BinaryDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*BinaryDigits* <span class="geq">::</span> *BinaryDigit*</span> is the MV of *BinaryDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*BinaryDigits* <span class="geq">::</span> *BinaryDigits* *BinaryDigit*</span> is (the MV of *BinaryDigits* × 2) plus the MV of *BinaryDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*OctalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `0o` *OctalDigits*</span> is the MV of *OctalDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*OctalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `0O` *OctalDigits*</span> is the MV of *OctalDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*OctalDigits* <span class="geq">::</span> *OctalDigit*</span> is the MV of *OctalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*OctalDigits* <span class="geq">::</span> *OctalDigits* *OctalDigit*</span> is (the MV of *OctalDigits* × 8) plus the MV of *OctalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*HexIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `0x` *HexDigits*</span> is the MV of *HexDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*HexIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `0X` *HexDigits*</span> is the MV of *HexDigits*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*HexDigits* <span class="geq">::</span> *HexDigit*</span> is the MV of *HexDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*HexDigits* <span class="geq">::</span> *HexDigits* *HexDigit*</span> is (the MV of *HexDigits* × 16) plus the MV of *HexDigit*.

Once the exact MV for a numeric literal has been determined, it is then rounded to a value of the Number type. If the MV is 0, then the rounded value is <span class="value">+0</span>; otherwise, the rounded value must be the Number value for the MV (as specified in [6.1.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-number-type)), unless the literal is a *DecimalLiteral* and the literal has more than 20 significant digits, in which case the Number value may be either the Number value for the MV of a literal produced by replacing each significant digit after the 20th with a `0` digit or the Number value for the MV of a literal produced by replacing each significant digit after the 20th with a `0` digit and then incrementing the literal at the 20th significant digit position. A digit is *significant* if it is not part of an *ExponentPart* and

-   it is not `0`; or
-   there is a nonzero digit to its left and there is a nonzero digit, not in the *ExponentPart*, to its right.

<span id="sec-11.8.4" class="secnum">[11.8.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-literals-string-literals "link to this section")</span> String Literals
===============================================================================================================================================================================

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> A string literal is zero or more Unicode code points enclosed in single or double quotes. Unicode code points may also be represented by an escape sequence. All <span style="font-family:
          sans-serif">code points</span> may appear literally in a string literal except for the closing quote <span style="font-family: sans-serif">code points</span>, U+005C (REVERSE SOLIDUS), U+000D (carriage return), U+2028 (line separator), U+2029 (paragraph separator), and U+000A (line feed). Any <span style="font-family: sans-serif">code points</span> may appear in the form of an escape sequence. String literals evaluate to ECMAScript String values. When generating these string values Unicode code points are UTF-16 encoded as defined in [10.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding). Code points belonging to the Basic Multilingual Plane are encoded as a single code unit element of the string. All other code points are encoded as two code unit elements of the string.

<span id="sec-11.8.4.1" class="secnum">[11.8.4.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string-literals-static-semantics-early-errors "link to this section")</span> Static Semantics: Early Errors

<span id="sec-11.8.4.2" class="secnum">[11.8.4.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string-literals-static-semantics-stringvalue "link to this section")</span> Static Semantics<span style="font-family: sans-serif">:</span> *StringValue*
====================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

See also: [11.6.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-identifier-names-static-semantics-stringvalue), [12.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-identifiers-static-semantics-stringvalue).

*StringLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span>
