`'` *SingleStringCharacters*<sub>opt</sub> `'`

1.  Return the String value whose elements are the SV of this *StringLiteral*.

<span id="sec-11.8.4.3" class="secnum">[11.8.4.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-static-semantics-sv-s "link to this section")</span> Static Semantics: *SV’s*
=========================================================================================================================================================================================

A string literal stands for a value of the String type. The String value (SV) of the literal is described in terms of code unit values contributed by the various parts of the string literal. As part of this process, some Unicode code points within the string literal are interpreted as having a mathematical value (MV), as described below or in [11.8.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-literals-numeric-literals).

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*StringLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `""`</span> is the empty code unit sequence.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*StringLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `''`</span> is the empty code unit sequence.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*StringLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `"` *DoubleStringCharacters* `"`</span> is the SV of *DoubleStringCharacters*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*StringLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `'` *SingleStringCharacters* `'`</span> is the SV of *SingleStringCharacters*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*DoubleStringCharacters* <span class="geq">::</span> *DoubleStringCharacter*</span> is a sequence of one or two code units that is the SV of *DoubleStringCharacter*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*DoubleStringCharacters* <span class="geq">::</span> *DoubleStringCharacter* *DoubleStringCharacters*</span> is a sequence of one or two code units that is the SV of *DoubleStringCharacter* followed by all the code units in the SV of *DoubleStringCharacters* in order.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*SingleStringCharacters* <span class="geq">::</span> *SingleStringCharacter*</span> is a sequence of one or two code units that is the SV of *SingleStringCharacter*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*SingleStringCharacters* <span class="geq">::</span> *SingleStringCharacter* *SingleStringCharacters*</span> is a sequence of one or two code units that is the SV of *SingleStringCharacter* followed by all the code units in the SV of *SingleStringCharacters* in order.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*DoubleStringCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> *SourceCharacter* <span class="grhsmod">but not one of</span> `"` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> `\` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> *LineTerminator*</span> is the [UTF16Encoding](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding) ([10.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding)) of the code point value of *SourceCharacter*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*DoubleStringCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> `\` *EscapeSequence*</span> is the SV of the *EscapeSequence*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*DoubleStringCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> *LineContinuation*</span> is the empty code unit sequence.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*SingleStringCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> *SourceCharacter* <span class="grhsmod">but not one of</span> `'` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> `\` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> *LineTerminator*</span> is the [UTF16Encoding](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding) ([10.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding)) of the code point value of *SourceCharacter*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*SingleStringCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> `\` *EscapeSequence*</span> is the SV of the *EscapeSequence*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*SingleStringCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> *LineContinuation*</span> is the empty code unit sequence.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*EscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *CharacterEscapeSequence*</span> is the SV of the *CharacterEscapeSequence*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*EscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> `0`</span> is the code unit value 0.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*EscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *HexEscapeSequence*</span> is the SV of the *HexEscapeSequence*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*EscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *UnicodeEscapeSequence*</span> is the SV of the *UnicodeEscapeSequence*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*CharacterEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *SingleEscapeCharacter*</span> is the code unit whose value is determined by the *SingleEscapeCharacter* according to { REF \_Ref365803173 \\h }[Table 34](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#table-34).

<span id="table-34">Table 34</span> — String Single Character Escape Sequences

| Escape Sequence | Code Unit Value | Unicode Character Name | Symbol     |
|-----------------|-----------------|------------------------|------------|
| `\b`            | `0x0008`        | BACKSPACE              | &lt;BS&gt; |
| `\t`            | `0x0009`        | CHARACTER TABULATION   | &lt;HT&gt; |
| `\n`            | `0x000A`        | line feed (lf)         | &lt;LF&gt; |
| `\v`            | `0x000B`        | LINE TABULATION        | &lt;VT&gt; |
| `\f`            | `0x000C`        | form feed (ff)         | &lt;FF&gt; |
| `\r`            | `0x000D`        | carriage return (cr)   | &lt;CR&gt; |
| `\"`            | `0x0022`        | quotation Mark         | `"`        |
| `\'`            | `0x0027`        | apostrophe             | `'`        |
| `\\`            | `0x005C`        | REverse Solidus        | `\`        |

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*CharacterEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *NonEscapeCharacter*</span> is the SV of the *NonEscapeCharacter*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*NonEscapeCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> *SourceCharacter* <span class="grhsmod">but not one of</span> *EscapeCharacter* <span class="grhsmod">or</span> *LineTerminator*</span> is the [UTF16Encoding](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding) ([10.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding)) of the code point value of *SourceCharacter*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*HexEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> `x` *HexDigit* *HexDigit*</span> is the code unit value that is (16 times the MV of the first *HexDigit*) plus the MV of the second *HexDigit*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*UnicodeEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> `u` *Hex4Digits*</span> is the SV of Hex4Digits.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*Hex4Digits* <span class="geq">::</span> *HexDigit* *HexDigit* *HexDigit* *HexDigit*</span> is the code unit value that is (4096 times the MV of the first *HexDigit*) plus (256 times the MV of the second *HexDigit*) plus (16 times the MV of the third *HexDigit*) plus the MV of the fourth *HexDigit*.

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*UnicodeEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> `u{` *HexDigits* `}`</span> is the [UTF16Encoding](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding) ([10.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding)) of the MV of *HexDigits*.

<span id="sec-11.8.5" class="secnum">[11.8.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-literals-regular-expression-literals "link to this section")</span> Regular Expression Literals
=======================================================================================================================================================================================================

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> A regular expression literal is an input element that is converted to a RegExp object ([see 21.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexp-regular-expression-objects)) each time the literal is evaluated. Two regular expression literals in a program evaluate to regular expression objects that never compare as `===` to each other even if the two literals' contents are identical. A RegExp object may also be created at runtime by `new           RegExp` or calling the `RegExp` constructor as a function ([see 21.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexp-constructor)).

The productions below describe the syntax for a regular expression literal and are used by the input element scanner to find the end of the regular expression literal. The source text comprising the *RegularExpressionBody* and the *RegularExpressionFlags* are subsequently parsed again using the more stringent ECMAScript Regular Expression grammar ([21.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-patterns)).

An implementation may extend the ECMAScript Regular Expression grammar defined in [21.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-patterns), but it must not extend the *RegularExpressionBody* and *RegularExpressionFlags* productions defined below or the productions used by these productions.

<span id="sec-11.8.6.1" class="secnum">[11.8.6.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-static-semantics-tv-s-and-trv-s "link to this section")</span> Static Semantics: *TV’s and TRV’s*
=============================================================================================================================================================================================================

A template literal component is interpreted as a sequence of Unicode code points. The Template Value (TV) of a literal component is described in terms of code unit values (SV, [11.8.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-literals-string-literals)) contributed by the various parts of the template literal component. As part of this process, some Unicode code points within the template component are interpreted as having a mathematical value (MV, [11.8.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-literals-numeric-literals)). In determining a TV, escape sequences are replaced by the UTF-16 code unit(s) of the Unicode code point represented by the escape sequence. The Template Raw Value (TRV) is similar to a Template Value with the difference that in TRVs escape sequences are interpreted literally.

-   The TV and TRV of <span class="prod">*NoSubstitutionTemplate* <span class="geq">::</span> ``` `` ```</span> is the empty code unit sequence.

-   The TV and TRV of <span class="prod">*TemplateHead* <span class="geq">::</span> `` `${ ``</span> is the empty code unit sequence.

-   The TV and TRV of <span class="prod">*TemplateMiddle* <span class="geq">::</span> `}${`</span> is the empty code unit sequence.

-   The TV and TRV of <span class="prod">*TemplateTail* <span class="geq">::</span> `` }` ``</span> is the empty code unit sequence.

-   The TV of <span class="prod">*NoSubstitutionTemplate* <span class="geq">::</span> `` ` `` *TemplateCharacters* `` ` ``</span> is the TV of *TemplateCharacters*.

-   The TV of <span class="prod">*TemplateHead* <span class="geq">::</span> `` ` `` *TemplateCharacters* `${`</span> is the TV of *TemplateCharacters*.

-   The TV of <span class="prod">*TemplateMiddle* <span class="geq">::</span> `}` *TemplateCharacters* `${`</span> is the TV of *TemplateCharacters*.

-   The TV of <span class="prod">*TemplateTail* <span class="geq">::</span> `}` *TemplateCharacters* `` ` ``</span> is the TV of *TemplateCharacters*.

-   The TV of <span class="prod">*TemplateCharacters* <span class="geq">::</span> *TemplateCharacter*</span> is the TV of *TemplateCharacter*.

-   The TV of <span class="prod">*TemplateCharacters* <span class="geq">::</span> *TemplateCharacter* *TemplateCharacters*</span> is a sequence consisting of the code units in the TV of *TemplateCharacter* followed by all the code units in the TV of *TemplateCharacters* in order.

-   The TV of <span class="prod">*TemplateCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> *SourceCharacter* <span class="grhsmod">but not one of</span> `` ` `` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> `\` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> `$` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> *LineTerminator*</span> is the [UTF16Encoding](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding) ([10.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding)) of the code point value of *SourceCharacter*.

-   The TV of <span class="prod">*TemplateCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> `$`</span> is the code unit value 0x0024.

-   The TV of <span class="prod">*TemplateCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> *LineTerminatorSequence*</span> is the TRV of *LineTerminatorSequence*.

-   The TV of <span class="prod">*LineContinuation* <span class="geq">::</span> `\` *LineTerminatorSequence*</span> is the empty code unit sequence.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*NoSubstitutionTemplate* <span class="geq">::</span> `` ` `` *TemplateCharacters* `` ` ``</span> is the TRV of *TemplateCharacters*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*TemplateHead* <span class="geq">::</span> `` ` `` *TemplateCharacters* `${`</span> is the TRV of *TemplateCharacters*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*TemplateMiddle* <span class="geq">::</span> `}` *TemplateCharacters* `${`</span> is the TRV of *TemplateCharacters*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*TemplateTail* <span class="geq">::</span> `}` *TemplateCharacters* `` ` ``</span> is the TRV of *TemplateCharacters*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*TemplateCharacters* <span class="geq">::</span> *TemplateCharacter*</span> is the TRV of *TemplateCharacter*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*TemplateCharacters* <span class="geq">::</span> *TemplateCharacter* *TemplateCharacters*</span> is a sequence consisting of the code units in the TRV of *TemplateCharacter* followed by all the code units in the TRV of *TemplateCharacters,* in order.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*TemplateCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> *SourceCharacter* <span class="grhsmod">but not one of</span> `` ` `` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> `\` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> `$` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> *LineTerminator*</span> is the [UTF16Encoding](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding) ([10.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding)) of the code point value of *SourceCharacter*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*EscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *HexEscapeSequence*</span> is the TRV of the *HexEscapeSequence*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*EscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *UnicodeEscapeSequence*</span> is the TRV of the *UnicodeEscapeSequence*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*CharacterEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *SingleEscapeCharacter*</span> is the TRV of the *SingleEscapeCharacter*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*CharacterEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *NonEscapeCharacter*</span> is the SV of the *NonEscapeCharacter*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*SingleEscapeCharacter* <span class="geq">::</span> <span class="grhsmod">one of</span> `'` `"` `\` `b` `f` `n` `r` `t` `v`</span> is the SV of the *SourceCharacter* that is that single code point.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*HexEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> `x` *HexDigit* *HexDigit*</span> is the sequence consisting of code unit value 0x0078 followed by TRV of the first *HexDigit* followed by the TRV of the second *HexDigit*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*UnicodeEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> `u` *Hex4Digits*</span> is the sequence consisting of code unit value 0x0075 followed by TRV of *Hex4Digits*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*UnicodeEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> `u{` *HexDigits* `}`</span> is the sequence consisting of code unit value 0x0075 followed by code unit value 0x007B followed by TRV of *HexDigits* followed by code unit value 0x007D.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*Hex4Digits* <span class="geq">::</span> *HexDigit* *HexDigit* *HexDigit* *HexDigit*</span> is the sequence consisting of the TRV of the first *HexDigit* followed by the TRV of the second *HexDigit* followed by the TRV of the third *HexDigit* followed by the TRV of the fourth *HexDigit*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*HexDigits* <span class="geq">::</span> *HexDigit*</span> is the TRV of *HexDigit*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*HexDigits* <span class="geq">::</span> *HexDigits* *HexDigit*</span> is the sequence consisting of TRV of *HexDigits* followed by TRV of *HexDigit*.

-   The TRV of a *HexDigit* is the SV of the *SourceCharacter* that is that *HexDigit*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*LineContinuation* <span class="geq">::</span> `\` *LineTerminatorSequence*</span> is the sequence consisting of the code unit value 0x005C followed by the code units of TRV of *LineTerminatorSequence*.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*LineTerminatorSequence* <span class="geq">::</span></span> &lt;LF&gt; is the code unit value 0x000A.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*LineTerminatorSequence* <span class="geq">::</span></span> &lt;CR&gt; is the code unit value 0x000A.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*LineTerminatorSequence* <span class="geq">::</span></span> &lt;LS&gt; is the code unit value 0x2028.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*LineTerminatorSequence* <span class="geq">::</span></span> &lt;PS&gt; is the code unit value 0x2029.

-   The TRV of <span class="prod">*LineTerminatorSequence* <span class="geq">::</span></span> &lt;CR&gt;&lt;LF&gt; is the sequence consisting of the code unit value 0x000A.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> TV excludes the code units of *LineContinuation* while TRV includes them. &lt;CR&gt;&lt;LF&gt; and &lt;CR&gt; *LineTerminatorSequences* are normalized to &lt;LF&gt; for both TV and TRV. An explicit *EscapeSequence* is needed to include a &lt;CR&gt; or &lt;CR&gt;&lt;LF&gt; sequence.

<span id="sec-11.9" class="secnum">[11.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion "link to this section")</span> Automatic Semicolon Insertion
==============================================================================================================================================================================================

Certain ECMAScript statements (empty statement, `let`, `const`, `import`, and `export` declarations, variable statement, expression statement, `debugger` statement, `continue` statement, `break` statement, `return` statement, and `throw` statement) must be terminated with semicolons. Such semicolons may always appear explicitly in the source text. For convenience, however, such semicolons may be omitted from the source text in certain situations. These situations are described by saying that semicolons are automatically inserted into the source code token stream in those situations.

<span id="sec-11.9.1" class="secnum">[11.9.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-rules-of-automatic-semicolon-insertion "link to this section")</span> Rules of Automatic Semicolon Insertion
====================================================================================================================================================================================================================

In the following rules, “token” means the actual recognized lexical token determined using the current lexical goal symbol as described in [clause 11](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-lexical-grammar).

There are three basic rules of semicolon insertion:

1.  When, as a <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*Script* or *Module*</span> is parsed from left to right, a token (called the *offending token*) is encountered that is not allowed by any production of the grammar, then a semicolon is automatically inserted before the offending token if one or more of the following conditions is true:
    -   The offending token is separated from the previous token by at least one *LineTerminator*.

    -   The offending token is `}`.

    -   The previous token is `)` and the inserted semicolon would then be parsed as the terminating semicolon of a do-while statement ([13.6.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-do-while-statement)).

2.  When, as the <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*Script* or *Module*</span> is parsed from left to right, the end of the input stream of tokens is encountered and the parser is unable to parse the input token stream as a single complete ECMAScript <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*Script* or *Module*</span>, then a semicolon is automatically inserted at the end of the input stream.
3.  When, as the <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*Script* or *Module*</span> is parsed from left to right, a token is encountered that is allowed by some production of the grammar, but the production is a *restricted production* and the token would be the first token for a terminal or nonterminal immediately following the annotation <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">“</span>\[no <span style="font-family: Times New
                Roman">*LineTerminator*</span> here\]” within the restricted production (and therefore such a token is called a restricted token), and the restricted token is separated from the previous token by at least one *LineTerminator*, then a semicolon is automatically inserted before the restricted token.

However, there is an additional overriding condition on the preceding rules: a semicolon is never inserted automatically if the semicolon would then be parsed as an empty statement or if that semicolon would become one of the two semicolons in the header of a `for` statement ([see 13.6.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-for-statement)).

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The following are the only restricted productions in the grammar:

*PostfixExpression*<sub>\[Yield\]</sub> <span class="geq">:</span>

*LeftHandSideExpression*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub> <span class="grhsannot">\[no *LineTerminator* here\]</span> `++`

*LeftHandSideExpression*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub> <span class="grhsannot">\[no *LineTerminator* here\]</span> `--`

*ContinueStatement*<sub>\[Yield\]</sub> <span class="geq">:</span>

`continue;`

`continue` <span class="grhsannot">\[no *LineTerminator* here\]</span> *LabelIdentifier*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub> `;`

*BreakStatement*<sub>\[Yield\]</sub> <span class="geq">:</span>

`break` `;`

`break` <span class="grhsannot">\[no *LineTerminator* here\]</span> *LabelIdentifier*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub> `;`

*ReturnStatement*<sub>\[Yield\]</sub> <span class="geq">:</span>

`return` <span class="grhsannot">\[no *LineTerminator* here\]</span> *Expression* `;`

`return` <span class="grhsannot">\[no *LineTerminator* here\]</span> *Expression*<sub>\[In,\\ ?Yield\]</sub> `;`

*ThrowStatement*<sub>\[Yield\]</sub> <span class="geq">:</span>

`throw` <span class="grhsannot">\[no *LineTerminator* here\]</span> *Expression*<sub>\[In,\\ ?Yield\]</sub> `;`

*ArrowFunction*<sub>\[In,\\ Yield\]</sub> <span class="geq">:</span>

*ArrowParameters*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub> <span class="grhsannot">\[no *LineTerminator* here\]</span> `=>` *ConciseBody*<sub>\[?In\]</sub>

*YieldExpression*<sub>\[In\]</sub> <span class="geq">:</span>

`yield` <span class="grhsannot">\[no *LineTerminator* here\]</span> `*` *AssignmentExpression*<sub>\[?In,\\ Yield\]</sub>

`yield` <span class="grhsannot">\[no *LineTerminator* here\]</span> *AssignmentExpression*<sub>\[?In,\\ Yield\]</sub>

The practical effect of these restricted productions is as follows:

When a `++` or `--` token is encountered where the parser would treat it as a postfix operator, and at least one *LineTerminator* occurred between the preceding token and the `++` or `--` token, then a semicolon is automatically inserted before the `++` or `--` token.

When a `continue`, `break`, `return`, `throw`, or `yield` token is encountered and a *LineTerminator* is encountered before the next token, a semicolon is automatically inserted after the `continue`, `break`, `return`, `throw`, or `yield` token.

The resulting practical advice to ECMAScript programmers is:

A postfix `++` or `--` operator should appear on the same line as its operand.

An *Expression* in a `return` or `throw` statement or an *AssignmentExpression* in a `yield` expression should start on the same line as the `return`, `throw`, or `yield` token.

An *IdentifierReference* in a `break` or `continue` statement should be on the same line as the `break` or `continue` token.

<span id="sec-11.9.2" class="secnum">[11.9.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-examples-of-automatic-semicolon-insertion "link to this section")</span> Examples of Automatic Semicolon Insertion
==========================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The source

    { 1 2 } 3

is not a valid sentence in the ECMAScript grammar, even with the [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion) rules. In contrast, the source

    { 1
    2 } 3

is also not a valid ECMAScript sentence, but is transformed by [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion) into the following:

    { 1
    ;2 ;} 3;

which is a valid ECMAScript sentence.

The source

    for (a; b
    )

is not a valid ECMAScript sentence and is not altered by [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion) because the semicolon is needed for the header of a `for` statement. Automatic semicolon insertion never inserts one of the two semicolons in the header of a `for` statement.

The source

    return
    a + b

is transformed by [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion) into the following:

    return;
    a + b;

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The expression `a + b` is not treated as a value to be returned by the `return` statement, because a *LineTerminator* separates it from the token `return`.

The source

    a = b
    ++c

is transformed by [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion) into the following:

    a = b;
    ++c;

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The token `++` is not treated as a postfix operator applying to the variable `b`, because a *LineTerminator* occurs between `b` and `++`.

The source

    if (a > b)
    else c = d

is not a valid ECMAScript sentence and is not altered by [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion) before the `else` token, even though no production of the grammar applies at that point, because an automatically inserted semicolon would then be parsed as an empty statement.

The source

    a = b + c
    (d + e).print()

is *not* transformed by [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion), because the parenthesized expression that begins the second line can be interpreted as an argument list for a function call:

    a = b + c(d + e).print()

In the circumstance that an assignment statement must begin with a left parenthesis, it is a good idea for the programmer to provide an explicit semicolon at the end of the preceding statement rather than to rely on [automatic semicolon insertion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-automatic-semicolon-insertion).

*Identifier*

<span id="sec-12.1.1" class="secnum">[12.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-identifiers-static-semantics-early-errors "link to this section")</span> Static Semantics: Early Errors
===============================================================================================================================================================================================================

*BindingIdentifier* <span class="geq">:</span> *Identifier*

-   It is a Syntax Error if the code matched by this production is contained in [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code) and the StringValue of *Identifier* is `"arguments"` or `"eval"`.

<span class="prod">*IdentifierReference* <span class="geq">:</span> `yield`</span>

<span class="prod">*BindingIdentifier* <span class="geq">:</span> `yield`</span>

*LabelIdentifier* <span class="geq">:</span> `yield`

-   It is a Syntax Error if the code matched by this production is contained in [strict code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code).

*IdentifierReference*<span style="font-family: sans-serif"><sub>\[Yield\]</sub> **:**</span> *Identifier*

*BindingIdentifier*<span style="font-family: sans-serif"><sub>\[Yield\]</sub> **:**</span> *Identifier*

*LabelIdentifier*<span style="font-family: sans-serif"><sub>\[Yield\]</sub> **:**</span> *Identifier*

-   It is a Syntax Error if this production has a <sub>\[Yield\]</sub> parameter and StringValue of *Identifier* is `"yield"`.

*Identifier* <span class="geq">:</span> *IdentifierName* <span class="grhsmod">but not</span> *ReservedWord*

-   It is a Syntax Error if this phrase is contained in [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code) and the StringValue of *IdentifierName* is: `"implements"`, `"interface"`, `"let"`, `"package"`, `"private"`, `"protected"`, `"public"`, `"static"`, or `"yield"`.

-   It is a Syntax Error if StringValue of *IdentifierName* is the same string value as the StringValue of any *ReservedWord* except for `yield`.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> <span style="font-family: sans-serif">StringValue of</span> *IdentifierName* normalizes any Unicode escape sequences in *IdentifierName* hence such escapes cannot be used to write an *Identifier* whose code point sequence is the same as a *ReservedWord*.

<span id="sec-12.1.5" class="secnum">[12.1.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-identifiers-runtime-semantics-bindinginitialization "link to this section")</span> Runtime Semantics: BindingInitialization
===================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

With arguments value and environment.

See also: [13.2.3.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-destructuring-binding-patterns-runtime-semantics-bindinginitialization), [13.6.4.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-for-in-and-for-of-statements-runtime-semantics-bindinginitialization).

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> **undefined** is passed for environment to indicate that a [PutValue](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-putvalue) operation should be used to assign the initialization value. This is the case for `var` statements and formal parameter lists of some non-strict functions (See [9.2.12](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-functiondeclarationinstantiation)). In those cases a lexical binding is hoisted and preinitialized prior to evaluation of its initializer.

*BindingIdentifier* <span class="geq">:</span> *Identifier*

1.  Let *name* be StringValue of *Identifier*.
2.  Return [InitializeBoundName](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-initializeboundname)( *name*, *value*, *environment*).

*BindingIdentifier* <span class="geq">:</span> `yield`

1.  Return [InitializeBoundName](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-initializeboundname)(`"yield"`, *value*, *environment*).

<span id="sec-12.1.5.1" class="secnum">[12.1.5.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-initializeboundname "link to this section")</span> Runtime Semantics: InitializeBoundName(name, value, environment)
===============================================================================================================================================================================================================================

1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*name*) is String.
2.  If *environment* is not **undefined**, then
    1.  Let *env* be the [EnvironmentRecord](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-lexical-environments) component of *environment*.
    2.  Perform *env*.InitializeBinding(*name*, *value*).
    3.  Return [NormalCompletion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-normalcompletion)(**undefined**).

3.  Else
    1.  Let *lhs* be [ResolveBinding](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-resolvebinding)(*name*).
    2.  Return [PutValue](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-putvalue)(*lhs*, *value*).

<span id="sec-12.1.6" class="secnum">[12.1.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-identifiers-runtime-semantics-evaluation "link to this section")</span> Runtime Semantics: Evaluation
=============================================================================================================================================================================================================

*IdentifierReference* <span class="geq">:</span> *Identifier*

1.  Return [ResolveBinding](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-resolvebinding)(StringValue of *Identifier*).

*IdentifierReference* <span class="geq">:</span> `yield`

1.  Return [ResolveBinding](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-resolvebinding)(`"yield"`).

<span class="nh">NOTE 1:</span> The result of evaluating an *IdentifierReference* is always a value of type [Reference](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-reference-specification-type).

<span class="nh">NOTE 2:</span> In non-[strict code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code), the keyword `yield` may be used as an identifier. Evaluating the *IdentifierReference* production resolves the binding of `yield` as if it was an *Identifier*. Early Error restriction ensures that such an evaluation only can occur for non-[strict code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code). See [13.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-let-and-const-declarations) for the handling of `yield` in binding creation contexts.

[12.12.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-binary-logical-operators-static-semantics-isvalidsimpleassignmenttarget), [12.13.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-conditional-operator-static-semantics-isvalidsimpleassignmenttarget), [12.14.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-assignment-operators-static-semantics-isvalidsimpleassignmenttarget), [12.15.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-comma-operator-static-semantics-isvalidsimpleassignmenttarget).
