<span id="sec-19.4.3.3" class="secnum">[19.4.3.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-symbol.prototype.valueof "link to this section")</span> Symbol.prototype.valueOf ( )
================================================================================================================================================================================================

The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *s* be the **this** value.
2.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*s*) is Symbol, return *s*.
3.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*s*) is not Object, throw a **TypeError** exception.
4.  If *s* does not have a \[\[SymbolData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots), throw a **TypeError** exception.
5.  Return the value of *s’s* \[\[SymbolData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

<span id="sec-19.4.3.4" class="secnum">[19.4.3.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-symbol.prototype-@@toprimitive "link to this section")</span> Symbol.prototype \[ @@toPrimitive \] ( hint )
=======================================================================================================================================================================================================================

This function is called by ECMAScript language operators to convert a Symbol object to a primitive value. The allowed values for hint are `"default"`, `"number"`, and `"string"`.

When the `@@toPrimitive` method is called with argument hint, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *s* be the **this** value.
2.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*s*) is Symbol, return *s*.
3.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*s*) is not Object, throw a **TypeError** exception.
4.  If *s* does not have a \[\[SymbolData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots), throw a **TypeError** exception.
5.  Return the value of *s’s* \[\[SymbolData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

The value of the `name` property of this function is `"[Symbol.toPrimitive]"`.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Configurable\]\]: <span class="value">true</span> }.

<span id="sec-19.4.3.5" class="secnum">[19.4.3.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-symbol.prototype-@@tostringtag "link to this section")</span> Symbol.prototype \[ @@toStringTag \]
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of the @@toStringTag property is the string value `"Symbol"`.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Configurable\]\]: <span class="value">true</span> }.

<span id="sec-19.4.4" class="secnum">[19.4.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-symbol-instances "link to this section")</span> Properties of Symbol Instances
====================================================================================================================================================================================================

Symbol instances are ordinary objects that inherit properties from the Symbol prototype object. Symbol instances have a \[\[SymbolData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots). The \[\[SymbolData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) is the Symbol value represented by this Symbol object.

<span id="sec-19.5" class="secnum">[19.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-error-objects "link to this section")</span> Error Objects
==============================================================================================================================================================

Instances of Error objects are thrown as exceptions when runtime errors occur. The Error objects may also serve as base objects for user-defined exception classes.

<span id="sec-19.5.1" class="secnum">[19.5.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-error-constructor "link to this section")</span> The Error Constructor
==============================================================================================================================================================================

The Error constructor is the %Error% intrinsic object and the initial value of the `Error` property of the global object. When `Error` is called as a function rather than as a constructor, it creates and initializes a new Error object. Thus the function call `Error(…)` is equivalent to the object creation expression `new Error(…)` with the same arguments.

The `Error` constructor is designed to be subclassable. It may be used as the value of an `extends` clause of a class definition. Subclass constructors that intend to inherit the specified `Error` behaviour must include a `super` call to the `Error` constructor to create and initialize subclass instances with a \[\[ErrorData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

<span id="sec-19.5.1.1" class="secnum">[19.5.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-error-message "link to this section")</span> Error ( message )
==========================================================================================================================================================================

When the `Error` function is called with argument *message* the following steps are taken:

1.  If NewTarget is **undefined***,* let *newTarget* be the active function object, else let *newTarget* be NewTarget.
2.  Let *O* be [OrdinaryCreateFromConstructor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ordinarycreatefromconstructor)(*newTarget*, `"%ErrorPrototype%"`, «\[\[ErrorData\]\]»).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*O*).
4.  If *message* is not **undefined**, then
    1.  Let *msg* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*message*).
    2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*msg*).
    3.  Let *msgDesc* be the PropertyDescriptor{\[\[Value\]\]: *msg*, \[\[Writable\]\]: **true**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **true**}.
    4.  Let *status* be [DefinePropertyOrThrow](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-definepropertyorthrow)(*O*, "`message`", *msgDesc*).
    5.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *status* is not an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type).

5.  Return *O*.

<span id="sec-19.5.2" class="secnum">[19.5.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-error-constructor "link to this section")</span> Properties of the Error Constructor
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of the Error constructor is the intrinsic object %FunctionPrototype% ([19.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-function-prototype-object)).

Besides the `length` property (whose value is **1**), the Error constructor has the following properties:

<span id="sec-19.5.2.1" class="secnum">[19.5.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-error.prototype "link to this section")</span> Error.prototype
==========================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of `Error.prototype` is the intrinsic object %ErrorPrototype% ([19.5.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-error-prototype-object)).

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-19.5.3" class="secnum">[19.5.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-error-prototype-object "link to this section")</span> Properties of the Error Prototype Object
========================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The Error prototype object is the intrinsic object %ErrorPrototype%. The Error prototype object is an ordinary object. It is not an Error instance and does not have an \[\[ErrorData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

The value of the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of the Error prototype object is the intrinsic object %ObjectPrototype% ([19.1.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-object-prototype-object)).

<span id="sec-19.5.3.1" class="secnum">[19.5.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-error.prototype.constructor "link to this section")</span> Error.prototype.constructor
==================================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of `Error.prototype.constructor` is the intrinsic object %Error%.

<span id="sec-19.5.3.2" class="secnum">[19.5.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-error.prototype.message "link to this section")</span> Error.prototype.message
==========================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of `Error.prototype.message` is the empty String.

<span id="sec-19.5.3.3" class="secnum">[19.5.3.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-error.prototype.name "link to this section")</span> Error.prototype.name
====================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of `Error.prototype.name` is `"Error"`.

<span id="sec-19.5.3.4" class="secnum">[19.5.3.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-error.prototype.tostring "link to this section")</span> Error.prototype.toString ( )
================================================================================================================================================================================================

The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be the **this** value.
2.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*O*) is not Object, throw a **TypeError** exception.
3.  Let *name* be [Get](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-get-o-p)(*O*, `"name"`).
4.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*name*).
5.  If *name* is **undefined**, let *name* be `"Error"`; otherwise let *name* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*name*).
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*name*).
7.  Let *msg* be [Get](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-get-o-p)(*O*, `"message"`).
8.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*msg*).
9.  If *msg* is **undefined**, let *msg* be the empty String; otherwise let *msg* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*msg*).
10. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*msg*).
11. If *name* is the empty String, return *msg*.
12. If *msg* is the empty String, return *name*.
13. Return the result of concatenating *name*, the code unit 0x003A (COLON), the code unit 0x0020 (SPACE), and *msg*.

<span id="sec-19.5.4" class="secnum">[19.5.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-error-instances "link to this section")</span> Properties of Error Instances
==================================================================================================================================================================================================

Error instances are ordinary objects that inherit properties from the Error prototype object and have an \[\[ErrorData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) whose value is <span class="value">undefined</span>. The only specified uses of \[\[ErrorData\]\] is to identify Error and *NativeError* instances as Error objects within `Object.prototype.toString`.

<span id="sec-19.5.5" class="secnum">[19.5.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-native-error-types-used-in-this-standard "link to this section")</span> Native Error Types Used in This Standard
========================================================================================================================================================================================================================

A new instance of one of the *NativeError* objects below is thrown when a runtime error is detected. All of these objects share the same structure, as described in [19.5.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-nativeerror-object-structure).

<span id="sec-19.5.5.1" class="secnum">[19.5.5.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-native-error-types-used-in-this-standard-evalerror "link to this section")</span> EvalError
=======================================================================================================================================================================================================

This exception is not currently used within this specification. This object remains for compatibility with previous editions of this specification.

<span id="sec-19.5.5.2" class="secnum">[19.5.5.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-native-error-types-used-in-this-standard-rangeerror "link to this section")</span> RangeError
=========================================================================================================================================================================================================

Indicates a value that is not in the set or range of allowable values.

<span id="sec-19.5.5.3" class="secnum">[19.5.5.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-native-error-types-used-in-this-standard-referenceerror "link to this section")</span> ReferenceError
=================================================================================================================================================================================================================

Indicate that an invalid reference value has been detected.

<span id="sec-19.5.5.4" class="secnum">[19.5.5.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-native-error-types-used-in-this-standard-syntaxerror "link to this section")</span> SyntaxError
===========================================================================================================================================================================================================

Indicates that a parsing error has occurred.

<span id="sec-19.5.5.5" class="secnum">[19.5.5.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-native-error-types-used-in-this-standard-typeerror "link to this section")</span> TypeError
=======================================================================================================================================================================================================

Indicates the actual type of an operand is different than the expected type.

<span id="sec-19.5.5.6" class="secnum">[19.5.5.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-native-error-types-used-in-this-standard-urierror "link to this section")</span> URIError
=====================================================================================================================================================================================================

Indicates that one of the global URI handling functions was used in a way that is incompatible with its definition.

<span id="sec-19.5.6" class="secnum">[19.5.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-nativeerror-object-structure "link to this section")</span> *NativeError* Object Structure
==================================================================================================================================================================================================

When an ECMAScript implementation detects a runtime error, it throws a new instance of one of the *NativeError* objects defined in [19.5.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-native-error-types-used-in-this-standard). Each of these objects has the structure described below, differing only in the name used as the constructor name instead of *NativeError*, in the **name** property of the prototype object, and in the implementation-defined `message` property of the prototype object.

For each error object, references to *NativeError* in the definition should be replaced with the appropriate error object name from [19.5.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-native-error-types-used-in-this-standard).

<span id="sec-19.5.6.1" class="secnum">[19.5.6.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-nativeerror-constructors "link to this section")</span> *NativeError* Constructors
==============================================================================================================================================================================================

When a *NativeError* constructor is called as a function rather than as a constructor, it creates and initializes a new *NativeError* object. A call of the object as a function is equivalent to calling it as a constructor with the same arguments. Thus the function call *NativeError*`(…)` is equivalent to the object creation expression `new` *NativeError*`(…)` with the same arguments.

Each *NativeError* constructor is designed to be subclassable. It may be used as the value of an `extends` clause of a class definition. Subclass constructors that intend to inherit the specified *NativeError* behaviour must include a `super` call to the *NativeError* constructor to create and initialize subclass instances with a \[\[ErrorData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

<span id="sec-19.5.6.1.1" class="secnum">[19.5.6.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-nativeerror "link to this section")</span> NativeError ( message )
==================================================================================================================================================================================

When a *NativeError* function is called with argument *message* the following steps are taken:

1.  If NewTarget is **undefined***,* let *newTarget* be the active function object, else let *newTarget* be NewTarget.
2.  Let *O* be [OrdinaryCreateFromConstructor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ordinarycreatefromconstructor)(*newTarget*, `"%NativeErrorPrototype%"`, «\[\[ErrorData\]\]» ).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*O*).
4.  If *message* is not **undefined**, then
    1.  Let *msg* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*message*).
    2.  Let *msgDesc* be the PropertyDescriptor{\[\[Value\]\]: *msg*, \[\[Writable\]\]: **true**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **true**}.
    3.  Let *status* be [DefinePropertyOrThrow](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-definepropertyorthrow)(*O*, "`message`", *msgDesc*).
    4.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *status* is not an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type).

5.  Return *O*.

The actual value of the string passed in step 2 is either `"%EvalErrorPrototype%"`, `"%RangeErrorPrototype%"`, `"%ReferenceErrorPrototype%"`, `"%SyntaxErrorPrototype%"`, `"%TypeErrorPrototype%"`, or `"%URIErrorPrototype%"` corresponding to which *NativeError* constructor is being defined.

<span id="sec-19.5.6.2" class="secnum">[19.5.6.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-nativeerror-constructors "link to this section")</span> Properties of the *NativeError* Constructors
==================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of a *NativeError* constructor is the intrinsic object %Error% ([19.5.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-error-constructor)).

Besides the `length` property (whose value is **1**), each *NativeError* constructor has the following properties:

<span id="sec-19.5.6.2.1" class="secnum">[19.5.6.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-nativeerror.prototype "link to this section")</span> NativeError.prototype
==========================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of ***NativeError*`.prototype`** is a *NativeError* prototype object ([19.5.6.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-nativeerror-prototype-objects)). Each *NativeError* constructor has a distinct prototype object.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-19.5.6.3" class="secnum">[19.5.6.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-nativeerror-prototype-objects "link to this section")</span> Properties of the *NativeError* Prototype Objects
============================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

Each *NativeError* prototype object is an ordinary object. It is not an Error instance and does not have an \[\[ErrorData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

The value of the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of each *NativeError* prototype object is the intrinsic object %ErrorPrototype% ([19.5.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-error-prototype-object)).

<span id="sec-19.5.6.3.1" class="secnum">[19.5.6.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-nativeerror.prototype.constructor "link to this section")</span> *NativeError*.prototype.constructor
====================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of the `constructor` property of the prototype for a given *NativeError* constructor is the corresponding intrinsic object %*NativeError*% ([19.5.6.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-nativeerror-constructors)).

<span id="sec-19.5.6.3.2" class="secnum">[19.5.6.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-nativeerror.prototype.message "link to this section")</span> *NativeError*.prototype.message
============================================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of the `message` property of the prototype for a given *NativeError* constructor is the empty String.

<span id="sec-19.5.6.3.3" class="secnum">[19.5.6.3.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-nativeerror.prototype.name "link to this section")</span> *NativeError*.prototype.name
======================================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of the `name` property of the prototype for a given *NativeError* constructor is a string consisting of the name of the constructor (the name used instead of *NativeError*).

<span id="sec-19.5.6.4" class="secnum">[19.5.6.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-nativeerror-instances "link to this section")</span> Properties of *NativeError* Instances
====================================================================================================================================================================================================================

*NativeError* instances are ordinary objects that inherit properties from their *NativeError* prototype object and have an \[\[ErrorData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) whose value is <span class="value">undefined</span>. The only specified use of \[\[ErrorData\]\] is by `Object.prototype.toString` ([19.1.3.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.prototype.tostring)) to identify Error or *NativeError* instances.

<span id="sec-20" class="secnum">[20](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-numbers-and-dates "link to this section")</span> Numbers and Dates
==================================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-20.1" class="secnum">[20.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number-objects "link to this section")</span> Number Objects
================================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-20.1.1" class="secnum">[20.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number-constructor "link to this section")</span> The Number Constructor
================================================================================================================================================================================

The Number constructor is the %Number% intrinsic object and the initial value of the `Number` property of the global object. When called as a constructor, it creates and initializes a new Number object. When `Number` is called as a function rather than as a constructor, it performs a type conversion.

The `Number` constructor is designed to be subclassable. It may be used as the value of an `extends` clause of a class definition. Subclass constructors that intend to inherit the specified `Number` behaviour must include a `super` call to the `Number` constructor to create and initialize the subclass instance with a \[\[NumberData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

<span id="sec-20.1.1.1" class="secnum">[20.1.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number-constructor-number-value "link to this section")</span> Number ( \[ value \] )
=================================================================================================================================================================================================

When `Number` is called with argument number, the following steps are taken:

1.  If no arguments were passed to this function invocation, let *n* be +0.
2.  Else, let *n* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*value*).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*n*).
4.  If NewTarget is **undefined***,* return *n*.
5.  Let *O* be [OrdinaryCreateFromConstructor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ordinarycreatefromconstructor)(NewTarget, `"%NumberPrototype%"`, «\[\[NumberData\]\]» ).
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*O*).
7.  Set the value of *O’s* \[\[NumberData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) to *n*.
8.  Return *O*.

<span id="sec-20.1.2" class="secnum">[20.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-number-constructor "link to this section")</span> Properties of the Number Constructor
================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of the Number constructor is the intrinsic object %FunctionPrototype% ([19.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-function-prototype-object)).

Besides the `length` property (whose value is **1**), the Number constructor has the following properties:

<span id="sec-20.1.2.1" class="secnum">[20.1.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.epsilon "link to this section")</span> Number.EPSILON
========================================================================================================================================================================

The value of Number.EPSILON is the difference between 1 and the smallest value greater than 1 that is representable as a Number value, which is approximately 2.2204460492503130808472633361816 x 10‍<sup>−‍16</sup>.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.2" class="secnum">[20.1.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.isfinite "link to this section")</span> Number.isFinite ( number )
=====================================================================================================================================================================================

When the `Number.isFinite` is called with one argument number, the following steps are taken:

1.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*number*) is not Number, return **false**.
2.  If *number* is **NaN**, **+∞**, or **−∞**, return **false**.
3.  Otherwise, return **true**.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.3" class="secnum">[20.1.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.isinteger "link to this section")</span> Number.isInteger ( number )
=======================================================================================================================================================================================

When the `Number.isInteger` is called with one argument number, the following steps are taken:

1.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*number*) is not Number, return **false**.
2.  If *number* is **NaN**, **+∞**, or **−∞**, return **false**.
3.  Let *integer* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*number*).
4.  If *integer* is not equal to *number*, return **false**.
5.  Otherwise, return **true**.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.4" class="secnum">[20.1.2.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.isnan "link to this section")</span> Number.isNaN ( number )
===============================================================================================================================================================================

When the `Number.isNaN` is called with one argument number, the following steps are taken:

1.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*number*) is not Number, return **false**.
2.  If *number* is **NaN**, return **true**.
3.  Otherwise, return **false**.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> This function differs from the global isNaN function ([18.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-isnan-number)) is that it does not convert its argument to a Number before determining whether it is NaN.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.5" class="secnum">[20.1.2.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.issafeinteger "link to this section")</span> Number.isSafeInteger ( number )
===============================================================================================================================================================================================

When the `Number.isSafeInteger` is called with one argument number, the following steps are taken:

1.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*number*) is not Number, return **false**.
2.  If *number* is **NaN**, **+∞**, or **−∞**, return **false**.
3.  Let *integer* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*number*).
4.  If *integer* is not equal to *number*, return **false**.
5.  If [abs](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*integer*) ≤ 2<sup>53</sup>−1, return **true**.
6.  Otherwise, return **false**.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.6" class="secnum">[20.1.2.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.max_safe_integer "link to this section")</span> Number.MAX\_SAFE\_INTEGER
============================================================================================================================================================================================

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The value of `Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER` is the largest integer n such that n and n + 1 are both exactly representable as a Number value.

The value of Number.MAX\_SAFE\_INTEGER is 9007199254740991 (2<sup>53</sup>−1).

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.7" class="secnum">[20.1.2.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.max_value "link to this section")</span> Number.MAX\_VALUE
=============================================================================================================================================================================

The value of `Number.MAX_VALUE` is the largest positive finite value of the Number type, which is approximately <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">1.7976931348623157 × 10<sup>308</sup></span>.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.8" class="secnum">[20.1.2.8](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.min_safe_integer "link to this section")</span> Number.MIN\_SAFE\_INTEGER
============================================================================================================================================================================================

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The value of `Number.MIN_SAFE_INTEGER` is the smallest integer n such that n and n − 1 are both exactly representable as a Number value.

The value of Number.MIN\_SAFE\_INTEGER is −9007199254740991 (−(2<sup>53</sup>−1)).

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.9" class="secnum">[20.1.2.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.min_value "link to this section")</span> Number.MIN\_VALUE
=============================================================================================================================================================================

The value of `Number.MIN_VALUE` is the smallest positive value of the Number type, which is approximately <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">5 × 10<sup>−324</sup></span>.

In the IEEE 754-2008 double precision binary representation, the smallest possible value is a denormalized number. If an implementation does not support denormalized values, the value of `Number.MIN_VALUE` must be the smallest non-zero positive value that can actually be represented by the implementation.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.10" class="secnum">[20.1.2.10](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.nan "link to this section")</span> Number.NaN
==================================================================================================================================================================

The value of `Number.NaN` is **NaN**.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.11" class="secnum">[20.1.2.11](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.negative_infinity "link to this section")</span> Number.NEGATIVE\_INFINITY
===============================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of Number.NEGATIVE\_INFINITY is −∞.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.12" class="secnum">[20.1.2.12](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.parsefloat "link to this section")</span> Number.parseFloat ( string )
===========================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of the `Number.parseFloat` data property is the same built-in function object that is the value of the `parseFloat` property of the global object defined in [18.2.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-parsefloat-string).

<span id="sec-20.1.2.13" class="secnum">[20.1.2.13](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.parseint "link to this section")</span> Number.parseInt ( string, radix )
==============================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of the `Number.parseInt` data property is the same built-in function object that is the value of the `parseInt` property of the global object defined in [18.2.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-parseint-string-radix).

<span id="sec-20.1.2.14" class="secnum">[20.1.2.14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.positive_infinity "link to this section")</span> Number.POSITIVE\_INFINITY
===============================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of Number.POSITIVE\_INFINITY is +∞.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.1.2.15" class="secnum">[20.1.2.15](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.prototype "link to this section")</span> Number.prototype
==============================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of `Number.prototype` is the intrinsic object %NumberPrototype% ([20.1.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-number-prototype-object)).

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.1.3" class="secnum">[20.1.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-number-prototype-object "link to this section")</span> Properties of the Number Prototype Object
==========================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The Number prototype object is the intrinsic object %NumberPrototype%. The Number prototype object is an ordinary object. It is not a Number instance and does not have a \[\[NumberData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

The value of the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of the Number prototype object is the intrinsic object %ObjectPrototype% ([19.1.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-object-prototype-object)).

Unless explicitly stated otherwise, the methods of the Number prototype object defined below are not generic and the **this** value passed to them must be either a Number value or an object that has a \[\[NumberData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) that has been initialized to a Number value.

The abstract operation <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">thisNumberValue(*value*)</span> performs the following steps:

1.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*value*) is Number, return *value*.
2.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*value*) is Object and *value* has a \[\[NumberData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots), then
    1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *value*’s \[\[NumberData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) is a Number value.
    2.  Return the value of *value’s* \[\[NumberData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

3.  Throw a **TypeError** exception.

The phrase “this Number value” within the specification of a method refers to the result returned by calling the abstract operation <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">thisNumberValue</span> with the **this** value of the method invocation passed as the argument.

<span id="sec-20.1.3.1" class="secnum">[20.1.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.prototype.constructor "link to this section")</span> Number.prototype.constructor
====================================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of `Number.prototype.constructor` is the intrinsic object %Number%.

<span id="sec-20.1.3.2" class="secnum">[20.1.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.prototype.toexponential "link to this section")</span> Number.prototype.toExponential ( fractionDigits )
===========================================================================================================================================================================================================================

Return a String containing this Number value represented in decimal exponential notation with one digit before the significand's decimal point and fractionDigits digits after the significand's decimal point. If fractionDigits is **undefined**, include as many significand digits as necessary to uniquely specify the Number (just like in [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring) except that in this case the Number is always output in exponential notation). Specifically, perform the following steps:

1.  Let *x* be thisNumberValue(**this** value).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*x*).
3.  Let *f* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*fractionDigits*).
4.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *f* is 0, when *fractionDigits* is **undefined**.
5.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*f*).
6.  If *x* is **NaN**, return the String `"NaN"`.
7.  Let *s* be the empty String.
8.  If *x* *&lt;* 0, then
    1.  Let *s* be `"-"`.
    2.  Let *x* = –*x*.

9.  If *x* = +∞, then
    1.  Return the concatenation of the Strings *s* and `"Infinity"`.

10. If *f* &lt; 0 or *f* &gt; 20, throw a **RangeError** exception. However, an implementation is permitted to extend the behaviour of `toExponential` for values of *f* less than 0 or greater than 20. In this case `toExponential` would not necessarily throw **RangeError** for such values.
11. If *x* = 0, then
    1.  Let *m* be the String consisting of *f*+1 occurrences of the code unit 0x0030.
    2.  Let *e* = 0.

12. Else *x* ≠ 0,
    1.  If *fractionDigits* is not **undefined**, then
        1.  Let *e* and *n* be integers such that 10<sup>*f*</sup> ≤ *n* &lt; 10<sup>*f*+1</sup> and for which the exact mathematical value of *n* × 10<sup>*e*–*f*</sup> – *x* is as close to zero as possible. If there are two such sets of *e* and *n*, pick the *e* and *n* for which *n* × 10<sup>*e*–*f*</sup> is larger.

    2.  Else *fractionDigits* is **undefined**,
        1.  Let *e*, *n*, and *f* be integers such that *f* ≥ 0, 10<sup>*f*</sup> ≤ *n* &lt; 10<sup>*f*+1</sup>, the Number value for n × 10<sup>*e*–*f*</sup> is *x*, and *f* is as small as possible. Note that the decimal representation of *n* has *f*+1 digits, *n* is not divisible by 10, and the least significant digit of *n* is not necessarily uniquely determined by these criteria.

    3.  Let *m* be the String consisting of the digits of the decimal representation of *n* (in order, with no leading zeroes).

13. If *f* ≠ 0, then
    1.  Let *a* be the first element of *m*, and let *b* be the remaining *f* elements of *m*.
    2.  Let *m* be the concatenation of the three Strings *a*, `"."`, and *b*.

14. If *e* = 0, then
    1.  Let *c* = `"+".`
    2.  Let *d* = `"0".`

15. Else
    1.  If *e* &gt; 0, let *c* = `"+".`
    2.  Else *e* ≤ 0,
        1.  Let *c* = `"-"`.
        2.  Let *e* = –*e*.

    3.  Let *d* be the String consisting of the digits of the decimal representation of *e* (in order, with no leading zeroes).

16. Let *m* be the concatenation of the four Strings *m*, `"e"`, *c*, and *d*.
17. Return the concatenation of the Strings *s* and *m*.

The `length` property of the `toExponential` method is **1**.

If the `toExponential` method is called with more than one argument, then the behaviour is undefined (see [clause 17](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-standard-built-in-objects)).

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> For implementations that provide more accurate conversions than required by the rules above, it is recommended that the following alternative version of step 12.b.i be used as a guideline:

1.  Let *e*, *n*, and *f* be integers such that *f* ≥ 0, 10<sup>*f*</sup> ≤ n &lt; 10<sup>*f*+1</sup>, the Number value for n × 10<sup>*e*–*f*</sup> is x, and *f* is as small as possible. If there are multiple possibilities for *n*, choose the value of *n* for which *n* × 10<sup>*e*–*f*</sup> is closest in value to *x*. If there are two such possible values of *n*, choose the one that is even.

<span id="sec-20.1.3.3" class="secnum">[20.1.3.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.prototype.tofixed "link to this section")</span> Number.prototype.toFixed ( fractionDigits )
===============================================================================================================================================================================================================

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> `toFixed` returns a String containing this Number value represented in decimal fixed-point notation with *fractionDigits* digits after the decimal point. If *fractionDigits* is **undefined**, 0 is assumed.

The following steps are performed:

1.  Let *x* be thisNumberValue(**this** value).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*x*).
3.  Let *f* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*fractionDigits*). (If *fractionDigits* is **undefined**, this step produces the value `0`).
4.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*f*).
5.  If *f* &lt; 0 or *f* &gt; 20, throw a **RangeError** exception. However, an implementation is permitted to extend the behaviour of `toFixed` for values of *f* less than 0 or greater than 20. In this case `toFixed` would not necessarily throw **RangeError** for such values.
6.  If *x* is **NaN**, return the String `"NaN"`.
7.  Let *s* be the empty String.
8.  If *x* &lt; 0, then
    1.  Let *s* be "`-`".
    2.  Let *x* = –*x*.

9.  If *x* ≥ 10<sup>21</sup>, then
    1.  Let *m* = [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*x*).

10. Else *x* &lt; 10<sup>21</sup>,
    1.  Let *n* be an integer for which the exact mathematical value of *n* ÷ 10<sup>f</sup> – *x* is as close to zero as possible. If there are two such *n*, pick the larger *n*.
    2.  If *n* = 0, let *m* be the String `"0"`. Otherwise, let *m* be the String consisting of the digits of the decimal representation of *n* (in order, with no leading zeroes).
    3.  If *f* ≠ 0, then
        1.  Let *k* be the number of elements in *m*.
        2.  If *k* ≤ *f*, then
            1.  Let *z* be the String consisting of *f*+1–*k* occurrences of the code unit 0x0030.
            2.  Let *m* be the concatenation of Strings *z* and *m*.
            3.  Let *k* = *f* + 1.

        3.  Let *a* be the first *k*–*f* elements of *m*, and let *b* be the remaining *f* elements of *m*.
        4.  Let *m* be the concatenation of the three Strings *a*, `"."`, and *b*.

11. Return the concatenation of the Strings *s* and *m*.

The `length` property of the `toFixed` method is **1**.

If the `toFixed` method is called with more than one argument, then the behaviour is undefined (see [clause 17](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-standard-built-in-objects)).

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The output of `toFixed` may be more precise than `toString` for some values because toString only prints enough significant digits to distinguish the number from adjacent number values. For example,

(`1000000000000000128).toString()` returns `"1000000000000000100"`,
while (`1000000000000000128).toFixed(0)` returns `"1000000000000000128"`.

<span id="sec-20.1.3.4" class="secnum">[20.1.3.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.prototype.tolocalestring "link to this section")</span> Number.prototype.toLocaleString( \[ reserved1 \[ , reserved2 \] \])
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

An ECMAScript implementation that includes the ECMA-402 Internationalization API must implement the `Number.prototype.toLocaleString` method as specified in the ECMA-402 specification. If an ECMAScript implementation does not include the ECMA-402 API the following specification of the `toLocaleString` method is used.

Produces a String value that represents this Number value formatted according to the conventions of the host environment’s current locale. This function is implementation-dependent, and it is permissible, but not encouraged, for it to return the same thing as `toString`.

The meanings of the optional parameters to this method are defined in the ECMA-402 specification; implementations that do not include ECMA-402 support must not use those parameter positions for anything else.

The `length` property of the `toLocaleString` method is **0**.

<span id="sec-20.1.3.5" class="secnum">[20.1.3.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.prototype.toprecision "link to this section")</span> Number.prototype.toPrecision ( precision )
==================================================================================================================================================================================================================

Return a String containing this Number value represented either in decimal exponential notation with one digit before the significand's decimal point and <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*precision*–1</span> digits after the significand's decimal point or in decimal fixed notation with precision significant digits. If precision is **undefined**, call [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring) ([7.1.12](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)) instead. Specifically, perform the following steps:

1.  Let *x* be thisNumberValue(**this** value).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*x*).
3.  If *precision* is **undefined**, return [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*x*).
4.  Let *p* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*precision*).
5.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*p*).
6.  If *x* is **NaN**, return the String `"NaN"`.
7.  Let *s* be the empty String.
8.  If *x* &lt; 0, then
    1.  Let *s* be code unit 0x002D (HYPHEN-MINUS).
    2.  Let *x* = –*x*.

9.  If *x* = +∞, then
    1.  Return the String that is the concatenation of *s* and `"Infinity"`.

10. If *p* &lt; 1 or *p* &gt; 21, throw a **RangeError** exception. However, an implementation is permitted to extend the behaviour of `toPrecision` for values of *p* less than 1 or greater than 21. In this case `toPrecision` would not necessarily throw **RangeError** for such values.
11. If *x* = 0, then
    1.  Let *m* be the String consisting of *p* occurrences of the code unit 0x0030 (DIGIT ZERO).
    2.  Let *e* = 0.

12. Else *x* ≠ 0,
    1.  Let *e* and *n* be integers such that 10<sup>*p*–1</sup> ≤ *n* &lt; 10<sup>*p*</sup> and for which the exact mathematical value of *n* × 10<sup>*e*–*p*+1</sup> – *x* is as close to zero as possible. If there are two such sets of *e* and *n*, pick the *e* and *n* for which *n* × 10<sup>*e*–*p*+1</sup> is larger.
    2.  Let *m* be the String consisting of the digits of the decimal representation of *n* (in order, with no leading zeroes).
    3.  If *e* &lt; –6 or *e* ≥ *p*, then
        1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *e* ≠ 0
        2.  Let *a* be the first element of *m*, and let *b* be the remaining *p*–1 elements of *m*.
        3.  Let *m* be the concatenation of *a*, code unit 0x002E (FULL STOP), and *b*.
        4.  If *e* &gt; 0, then
            1.  Let *c* be code unit 0x002B (PLUS SIGN).

        5.  Else *e* &lt; 0,
            1.  Let *c* be code unit 0x002D (HYPHEN-MINUS).
            2.  Let *e* = –*e*.

        6.  Let *d* be the String consisting of the digits of the decimal representation of *e* (in order, with no leading zeroes).
        7.  Return the concatenation of *s*, *m*, code unit 0x0065 (LATIN SMALL LETTER E), *c*, and *d*.

13. If *e* = *p*–1, return the concatenation of the Strings *s* and *m*.
14. If *e* ≥ 0, then
    1.  Let *m* be the concatenation of the first *e*+1 elements of *m*, the code unit 0x002E (FULL STOP), and the remaining *p*– (*e*+1) elements of *m*.

15. Else *e* &lt; 0,
    1.  Let *m* be the String formed by the concatenation of code unit 0x0030 (DIGIT ZERO)**,** code unit 0x002E (FULL STOP), –(*e*+1) occurrences of code unit 0x0030 (DIGIT ZERO), and the String *m*.

16. Return the String that is the concatenation of *s* and *m*.

The `length` property of the `toPrecision` method is **1**.

If the `toPrecision` method is called with more than one argument, then the behaviour is undefined (see [clause 17](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-standard-built-in-objects)).

<span id="sec-20.1.3.6" class="secnum">[20.1.3.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.prototype.tostring "link to this section")</span> Number.prototype.toString ( \[ radix \] )
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The optional *radix* should be an integer value in the inclusive range 2 to 36. If *radix* not present or is **undefined** the Number 10 is used as the value of *radix*.

The following steps are performed:

1.  Let *x* be thisNumberValue(**this** value).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*x*).
3.  If *radix* is not present, let *radixNumber* be 10.
4.  Else if *radix* is **undefined**, let *radixNumber* be 10.
5.  Else let *radixNumber* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*radix*).
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*radixNumber*).
7.  If *radixNumber* &lt; 2 or *radixNumber* &gt; 36, throw a **RangeError** exception.
8.  If *radixNumber* = 10, return [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*x*).
9.  Return the String representation of this Number value using the radix specified by *radixNumber*. Letters `a`-`z` are used for digits with values 10 through 35. The precise algorithm is implementation-dependent, however the algorithm should be a generalization of that specified in [7.1.12.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring-applied-to-the-number-type).

The `toString` function is not generic; it throws a **TypeError** exception if its **this** value is not a Number or a Number object. Therefore, it cannot be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-20.1.3.7" class="secnum">[20.1.3.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-number.prototype.valueof "link to this section")</span> Number.prototype.valueOf ( )
================================================================================================================================================================================================

1.  Let *x* be thisNumberValue(**this** value).
2.  Return *x*.

<span id="sec-20.1.4" class="secnum">[20.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-number-instances "link to this section")</span> Properties of Number Instances
====================================================================================================================================================================================================

Number instances are ordinary objects that inherit properties from the Number prototype object. Number instances also have a \[\[NumberData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots). The \[\[NumberData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) is the Number value represented by this Number object.

<span id="sec-20.2" class="secnum">[20.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math-object "link to this section")</span> The Math Object
==============================================================================================================================================================

The Math object is the %Math% intrinsic object and the initial value of the `Math` property of the global object. The Math object is a single ordinary object.

The value of the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of the Math object is the intrinsic object %ObjectPrototype% ([19.1.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-object-prototype-object)).

The Math object is not a function object. It does not have a \[\[Construct\]\] internal method; it is not possible to use the Math object as a constructor with the `new` operator. The Math object also does not have a \[\[Call\]\] internal method; it is not possible to invoke the Math object as a function.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> In this specification, the phrase “the Number value for *x*” has a technical meaning defined in [6.1.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-number-type).

<span id="sec-20.2.1" class="secnum">[20.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-value-properties-of-the-math-object "link to this section")</span> Value Properties of the Math Object
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-20.2.1.1" class="secnum">[20.2.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.e "link to this section")</span> Math.E
========================================================================================================================================================

The Number value for e, the base of the natural logarithms, which is approximately 2.7182818284590452354.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.2.1.2" class="secnum">[20.2.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.ln10 "link to this section")</span> Math.LN10
==============================================================================================================================================================

The Number value for the natural logarithm of 10, which is approximately 2.302585092994046.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.2.1.3" class="secnum">[20.2.1.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.ln2 "link to this section")</span> Math.LN2
============================================================================================================================================================

The Number value for the natural logarithm of 2, which is approximately 0.6931471805599453.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.2.1.4" class="secnum">[20.2.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.log10e "link to this section")</span> Math.LOG10E
==================================================================================================================================================================

The Number value for the base-<span style="font-family: Times New Roman">10</span> logarithm of e, the base of the natural logarithms; this value is approximately <span style="font-family: Times New
        Roman">0.4342944819032518</span>.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The value of `Math.LOG10E` is approximately the reciprocal of the value of `Math.LN10`.

<span id="sec-20.2.1.5" class="secnum">[20.2.1.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.log2e "link to this section")</span> Math.LOG2E
================================================================================================================================================================

The Number value for the base-<span style="font-family: Times New Roman">2</span> logarithm of e, the base of the natural logarithms; this value is approximately <span style="font-family: Times New
        Roman">1.4426950408889634</span>.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The value of `Math.LOG2E` is approximately the reciprocal of the value of `Math.LN2`.

<span id="sec-20.2.1.6" class="secnum">[20.2.1.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.pi "link to this section")</span> Math.PI
==========================================================================================================================================================

The Number value for <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">π</span>, the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter, which is approximately <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">3.1415926535897932</span>.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.2.1.7" class="secnum">[20.2.1.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.sqrt1_2 "link to this section")</span> Math.SQRT1\_2
=====================================================================================================================================================================

The Number value for the square root of <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">½</span>, which is approximately <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">0.7071067811865476</span>.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The value of `Math.SQRT1_2` is approximately the reciprocal of the value of `Math.SQRT2`.

<span id="sec-20.2.1.8" class="secnum">[20.2.1.8](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.sqrt2 "link to this section")</span> Math.SQRT2
================================================================================================================================================================

The Number value for the square root of <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">2</span>, which is approximately <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">1.4142135623730951</span>.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.2.1.9" class="secnum">[20.2.1.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math-@@tostringtag "link to this section")</span> Math \[ @@toStringTag \]
======================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of the @@toStringTag property is the string value `"Math"`.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Configurable\]\]: <span class="value">true</span> }.

<span id="sec-20.2.2" class="secnum">[20.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-function-properties-of-the-math-object "link to this section")</span> Function Properties of the Math Object
====================================================================================================================================================================================================================

Each of the following `Math` object functions applies the [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber) abstract operation to each of its arguments (in left-to-right order if there is more than one). If [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber) returns an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type), that [Completion Record](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type) is immediately returned. Otherwise, the function performs a computation on the resulting Number value(s). The value returned by each function is a Number.

In the function descriptions below, the symbols NaN, −0, +0, −∞ and +∞ refer to the Number values described in [6.1.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-number-type).

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The behaviour of the functions `acos`, `acosh`, `asin`, `asinh`, `atan`, `atanh`, `atan2`, `cbrt`, `cos`, `cosh`, `exp`, `expm1`, `hypot`, `log`,`log1p`, `log2`, `log10`, `pow`, `random`, `sin`, `sinh`, `sqrt`, `tan`, and `tanh` is not precisely specified here except to require specific results for certain argument values that represent boundary cases of interest. For other argument values, these functions are intended to compute approximations to the results of familiar mathematical functions, but some latitude is allowed in the choice of approximation algorithms. The general intent is that an implementer should be able to use the same mathematical library for ECMAScript on a given hardware platform that is available to C programmers on that platform.

Although the choice of algorithms is left to the implementation, it is recommended (but not specified by this standard) that implementations use the approximation algorithms for IEEE 754-2008 arithmetic contained in `fdlibm`, the freely distributable mathematical library from Sun Microsystems (<http://www.netlib.org/fdlibm>`)`.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.1" class="secnum">[20.2.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.abs "link to this section")</span> Math.abs ( x )
==================================================================================================================================================================

Returns the absolute value of x; the result has the same magnitude as x but has positive sign.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is +∞.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.2" class="secnum">[20.2.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.acos "link to this section")</span> Math.acos ( x )
====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the arc cosine of x. The result is expressed in radians and ranges from <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">+0</span> to <span style="font-family: Times New
        Roman">+π</span>.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is greater than 1, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is less than **−**1, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is exactly 1, the result is +0.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.3" class="secnum">[20.2.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.acosh "link to this section")</span> Math.acosh( x )
=====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the inverse hyperbolic cosine of *x*.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If x is less than 1, the result is NaN.
-   If x is 1, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.4" class="secnum">[20.2.2.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.asin "link to this section")</span> Math.asin ( x )
====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the arc sine of x. The result is expressed in radians and ranges from <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">−π/2</span> to <span style="font-family: Times New
        Roman">+π/2</span>.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is greater than 1, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is less than –1, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.5" class="secnum">[20.2.2.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.asinh "link to this section")</span> Math.asinh( x )
=====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the inverse hyperbolic sine of *x*.

-   I<span style="font-family: Times New Roman">f *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.</span>
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If x is −∞, the result is −∞.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.6" class="secnum">[20.2.2.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.atan "link to this section")</span> Math.atan ( x )
====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the arc tangent of x. The result is expressed in radians and ranges from <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">−π/2</span> to <span style="font-family: Times
        New Roman">+π/2</span>.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to +π/2.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to −π/2.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.7" class="secnum">[20.2.2.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.atanh "link to this section")</span> Math.atanh( x )
=====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the inverse hyperbolic tangent of *x*.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is less than −1, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is greater than 1, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is −1, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is +1, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.8" class="secnum">[20.2.2.8](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.atan2 "link to this section")</span> Math.atan2 ( y, x )
=========================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the arc tangent of the quotient <span style="font-family: Times
        New Roman">*y***/***x*</span> of the arguments y and x, where the signs of y and x are used to determine the quadrant of the result. Note that it is intentional and traditional for the two-argument arc tangent function that the argument named y be first and the argument named x be second. The result is expressed in radians and ranges from <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">−π</span> to <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">+π</span>.

-   If either *x* or *y* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *y*&gt;0 and *x* is +0, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to +π/2.
-   If *y*&gt;0 and *x* is −0, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to +π/2.
-   If *y* is +0 and *x*&gt;0, the result is +0.
-   If *y* is +0 and *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *y* is +0 and *x* is −0, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to +π.
-   If *y* is +0 and *x*&lt;0, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to +π.
-   If *y* is −0 and *x*&gt;0, the result is −0.
-   If *y* is −0 and *x* is +0, the result is −0.
-   If *y* is −0 and *x* is −0, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to −π.
-   If *y* is −0 and *x*&lt;0, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to −π.
-   If *y*&lt;0 and *x* is +0, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to −π/2.
-   If *y*&lt;0 and *x* is −0, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to −π/2.
-   If *y*&gt;0 and *y* is finite and *x* is +∞, the result is +0.
-   If *y*&gt;0 and *y* is finite and *x* is −∞, the result if an implementation-dependent approximation to +π.
