-   If *y*&lt;0 and *y* is finite and *x* is +∞, the result is −0.
-   If *y*&lt;0 and *y* is finite and *x* is −∞, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to −π.
-   If *y* is +∞ and *x* is finite, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to +π/2.
-   If *y* is −∞ and *x* is finite, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to −π/2.
-   If *y* is +∞ and *x* is +∞, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to +π/4.
-   If *y* is +∞ and *x* is −∞, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to +3π/4.
-   If *y* is −∞ and *x* is +∞, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to −π/4.
-   If *y* is −∞ and *x* is −∞, the result is an implementation-dependent approximation to −3π/4.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.9" class="secnum">[20.2.2.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.cbrt "link to this section")</span> Math.cbrt ( x )
====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the cube root of *x*.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is −∞.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.10" class="secnum">[20.2.2.10](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.ceil "link to this section")</span> Math.ceil ( x )
======================================================================================================================================================================

Returns the smallest (closest to **−∞**) Number value that is not less than x and is equal to a mathematical integer. If x is already an integer, the result is x.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is less than 0 but greater than -1, the result is −0.

The value of `Math.ceil(x)` is the same as the value of `-Math.floor(-x)`.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.11" class="secnum">[20.2.2.11](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.clz32 "link to this section")</span> Math.clz32 ( x )
========================================================================================================================================================================

When `Math.clz32` is called with one argument x, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *n* be [ToUint32](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-touint32)(*x*).
2.  Let *p* be the number of leading zero bits in the 32-bit binary representation of *n*.
3.  Return *p*.

NOTE If *n* is 0, *p* will be 32. If the most significant bit of the 32-bit binary encoding of *n* is 1, *p* will be 0.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.12" class="secnum">[20.2.2.12](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.cos "link to this section")</span> Math.cos ( x )
====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the cosine of x. The argument is expressed in radians.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is 1.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is 1.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is NaN.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.13" class="secnum">[20.2.2.13](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.cosh "link to this section")</span> Math.cosh ( x )
======================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the hyperbolic cosine of *x*.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is 1.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is 1.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is +∞.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The value of cosh(x) is the same as *(exp(x) + exp(-x))/2*.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.14" class="secnum">[20.2.2.14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.exp "link to this section")</span> Math.exp ( x )
====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the exponential function of x (e raised to the power of x, where e is the base of the natural logarithms).

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is 1.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is 1.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is +0.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.15" class="secnum">[20.2.2.15](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.expm1 "link to this section")</span> Math.expm1 ( x )
========================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to subtracting 1 from the exponential function of *x* (*e* raised to the power of *x*, where *e* is the base of the natural logarithms). The result is computed in a way that is accurate even when the value of x is close 0.

-   I<span style="font-family: Times New Roman">f *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.</span>
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is −1.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.16" class="secnum">[20.2.2.16](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.floor "link to this section")</span> Math.floor ( x )
========================================================================================================================================================================

Returns the greatest (closest to **+∞**) Number value that is not greater than x and is equal to a mathematical integer. If x is already an integer, the result is x.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is greater than 0 but less than 1, the result is +0.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The value of `Math.floor(x)` is the same as the value of `-Math.ceil(-x)`.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.17" class="secnum">[20.2.2.17](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.fround "link to this section")</span> Math.fround ( x )
==========================================================================================================================================================================

When `Math.fround` is called with argument *x* the following steps are taken:

1.  If *x* is NaN, return NaN.
2.  If *x* is one of +0, −0, +∞, −∞, return *x*.
3.  Let *x32* be the result of converting *x* to a value in IEEE 754-2008 binary32 format using roundTiesToEven.
4.  Let *x64* be the result of converting *x32* to a value in IEEE 754-2008 binary64 format.
5.  Return the ECMAScript Number value corresponding to *x64*.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.18" class="secnum">[20.2.2.18](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.hypot "link to this section")</span> Math.hypot ( value1 , value2 , …values )
================================================================================================================================================================================================

`Math.hypot` returns an implementation-dependent approximation of the square root of the sum of squares of its arguments.

-   If no arguments are passed, the result is +0.
-   If any argument is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If any argument is −∞, the result is +∞.
-   If no argument is +∞ or −∞, and any argument is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If all arguments are either +0 or −0, the result is +0.

The length property of the `hypot` function is 2.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> Implementations should take care to avoid the loss of precision from overflows and underflows that are prone to occur in naive implementations when this function is called with two or more arguments.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.19" class="secnum">[20.2.2.19](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.imul "link to this section")</span> Math.imul ( x, y )
=========================================================================================================================================================================

When the `Math.imul` is called with arguments x and y the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *a* be [ToUint32](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-touint32)(*x*).
2.  Let *b* be [ToUint32](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-touint32)(*y*).
3.  Let *product* be (*a* × *b*) [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) 2<sup>32</sup>.
4.  If *product* ≥ 2<sup>31</sup>, return *product* − 2<sup>32</sup>, otherwise return *product*.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.20" class="secnum">[20.2.2.20](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.log "link to this section")</span> Math.log ( x )
====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the natural logarithm of x.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is less than 0, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0 or −0, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is 1, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.21" class="secnum">[20.2.2.21](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.log1p "link to this section")</span> Math.log1p ( x )
========================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the natural logarithm of 1 + *x*. The result is computed in a way that is accurate even when the value of x is close to zero.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is less than -1, the result is NaN.
-   If x is -1, the result is -∞.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.22" class="secnum">[20.2.2.22](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.log10 "link to this section")</span> Math.log10 ( x )
========================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the base 10 logarithm of *x*.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is less than 0, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is 1, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.23" class="secnum">[20.2.2.23](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.log2 "link to this section")</span> Math.log2 ( x )
======================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the base 2 logarithm of *x*.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is less than 0, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is 1, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.24" class="secnum">[20.2.2.24](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.max "link to this section")</span> Math.max ( value1, value2 , …values )
===========================================================================================================================================================================================

Given zero or more arguments, calls [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber) on each of the arguments and returns the largest of the resulting values.

-   If no arguments are given, the result is −∞.

-   If any value is NaN, the result is NaN.

-   The comparison of values to determine the largest value is done using the Abstract Relational Comparison algorithm ([7.2.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ispropertykey)) except that +0 is considered to be larger than −0.

The `length` property of the `max` method is **2**.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.25" class="secnum">[20.2.2.25](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.min "link to this section")</span> Math.min ( value1, value2 , …values )
===========================================================================================================================================================================================

Given zero or more arguments, calls [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber) on each of the arguments and returns the smallest of the resulting values.

-   If no arguments are given, the result is +∞.

-   If any value is NaN, the result is NaN.

-   The comparison of values to determine the smallest value is done using the Abstract Relational Comparison algorithm ([7.2.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ispropertykey)) except that +0 is considered to be larger than −0.

The `length` property of the `min` method is **2**.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.26" class="secnum">[20.2.2.26](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.pow "link to this section")</span> Math.pow ( x, y )
=======================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the result of raising x to the power y.

-   If *y* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *y* is +0, the result is 1, even if *x* is NaN.
-   If *y* is −0, the result is 1, even if *x* is NaN.
-   If *x* is NaN and *y* is nonzero, the result is NaN.
-   If [abs](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*x*)&gt;1 and *y* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If [abs](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*x*)&gt;1 and *y* is −∞, the result is +0.
-   If [abs](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*x*) is 1 and *y* is +∞, the result is NaN.
-   If [abs](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*x*) is 1 and *y* is −∞, the result is NaN.
-   If [abs](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*x*)&lt;1 and *y* is +∞, the result is +0.
-   If [abs](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*x*)&lt;1 and *y* is −∞, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is +∞ and *y*&gt;0, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is +∞ and *y*&lt;0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −∞ and *y*&gt;0 and *y* is an odd integer, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is −∞ and *y*&gt;0 and *y* is not an odd integer, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is −∞ and *y*&lt;0 and *y* is an odd integer, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is −∞ and *y*&lt;0 and *y* is not an odd integer, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is +0 and *y*&gt;0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is +0 and *y*&lt;0, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is −0 and *y*&gt;0 and *y* is an odd integer, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is −0 and *y*&gt;0 and *y* is not an odd integer, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0 and *y*&lt;0 and *y* is an odd integer, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is −0 and *y*&lt;0 and *y* is not an odd integer, the result is +∞.
-   If *x*&lt;0 and *x* is finite and *y* is finite and *y* is not an integer, the result is NaN.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.27" class="secnum">[20.2.2.27](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.random "link to this section")</span> Math.random ( )
========================================================================================================================================================================

Returns a Number value with positive sign, greater than or equal to 0 but less than 1, chosen randomly or pseudo randomly with approximately uniform distribution over that range, using an implementation-dependent algorithm or strategy. This function takes no arguments.

Each `Math.random` function created for distinct code Realms must produce a distinct sequence of values from successive calls.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.28" class="secnum">[20.2.2.28](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.round "link to this section")</span> Math.round ( x )
========================================================================================================================================================================

Returns the Number value that is closest to x and is equal to a mathematical integer. If two integer Number values are equally close to x, then the result is the Number value that is closer to <span style="font-family:
        Times New Roman">+∞</span>. If x is already an integer, the result is x.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is greater than 0 but less than 0.5, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is less than 0 but greater than or equal to -0.5, the result is −0.

<span class="nh">NOTE 1</span> `Math.round(3.5)` returns 4, but `Math.round(–3.5)` returns –3.

<span class="nh">NOTE 2</span> The value of `Math.round(x)` is not always the same as the value of `Math.floor(x+0.5)`. When `x` is −0 or is less than 0 but greater than or equal to -0.5, `Math.round(x)` returns −0, but `Math.floor(x+0.5)` returns +0. `Math.round(x)` may also differ from the value of `Math.floor(x+0.5)`<span style="font-family: sans-serif">because of internal rounding when computing</span> `x+0.5`<span style="font-family: sans-serif">.</span>

<span id="sec-20.2.2.29" class="secnum">[20.2.2.29](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.sign "link to this section")</span> Math.sign(x)
===================================================================================================================================================================

Returns the sign of the x, indicating whether x is positive, negative or zero.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is negative and not −0, the result is −1.
-   If *x* is positive and not +0, the result is +1.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.30" class="secnum">[20.2.2.30](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.sin "link to this section")</span> Math.sin ( x )
====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the sine of x. The argument is expressed in radians.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞ or −∞, the result is NaN.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.31" class="secnum">[20.2.2.31](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.sinh "link to this section")</span> Math.sinh( x )
=====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the hyperbolic sine of *x*.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If x is −∞, the result is −∞.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The value of sinh(x) is the same as *(exp(x) - exp(-x))/2*.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.32" class="secnum">[20.2.2.32](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.sqrt "link to this section")</span> Math.sqrt ( x )
======================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the square root of x.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is less than 0, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.33" class="secnum">[20.2.2.33](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.tan "link to this section")</span> Math.tan ( x )
====================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the tangent of x. The argument is expressed in radians.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞ or −∞, the result is NaN.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.34" class="secnum">[20.2.2.34](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.tanh "link to this section")</span> Math.tanh ( x )
======================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an implementation-dependent approximation to the hyperbolic tangent of *x*.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +1.
-   If *x* is −∞, the result is -1.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The value of tanh(x) is the same as *(exp(x) - exp(-x))/(exp(x) + exp(-x))*.

<span id="sec-20.2.2.35" class="secnum">[20.2.2.35](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-math.trunc "link to this section")</span> Math.trunc ( x )
========================================================================================================================================================================

Returns the integral part of the number x, removing any fractional digits. If x is already an integer, the result is x.

-   If *x* is NaN, the result is NaN.
-   If *x* is −0, the result is −0.
-   If *x* is +0, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is +∞, the result is +∞.
-   If x is −∞, the result is −∞.
-   If *x* is greater than 0 but less than 1, the result is +0.
-   If *x* is less than 0 but greater than −1, the result is −0.

<span id="sec-20.3" class="secnum">[20.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-objects "link to this section")</span> Date Objects
============================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-20.3.1" class="secnum">[20.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-overview-of-date-objects-and-definitions-of-abstract-operations "link to this section")</span> Overview of Date Objects and Definitions of Abstract Operations
======================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The following functions are abstract operations that operate on time values (defined in [20.3.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range)). Note that, in every case, if any argument to one of these functions is **NaN**, the result will be **NaN**.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.1" class="secnum">[20.3.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range "link to this section")</span> Time Values and Time Range
================================================================================================================================================================================================

A Date object contains a Number indicating a particular instant in time to within a millisecond. Such a Number is called a *time value*. A time value may also be **NaN**, indicating that the Date object does not represent a specific instant of time.

Time is measured in ECMAScript in milliseconds since 01 January, 1970 UTC. In time values leap seconds are ignored. It is assumed that there are exactly 86,400,000 milliseconds per day. ECMAScript Number values can represent all integers from –9,007,199,254,740,992 to 9,007,199,254,740,992; this range suffices to measure times to millisecond precision for any instant that is within approximately 285,616 years, either forward or backward, from 01 January, 1970 UTC.

The actual range of times supported by ECMAScript Date objects is slightly smaller: exactly –100,000,000 days to 100,000,000 days measured relative to midnight at the beginning of 01 January, 1970 UTC. This gives a range of 8,640,000,000,000,000 milliseconds to either side of 01 January, 1970 UTC.

The exact moment of midnight at the beginning of 01 January, 1970 UTC is represented by the value **+0**.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.2" class="secnum">[20.3.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-day-number-and-time-within-day "link to this section")</span> Day Number and Time within Day
========================================================================================================================================================================================================

A given [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) *t* belongs to day number

Day(*t*) = [floor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*t* / msPerDay)

where the number of milliseconds per day is

msPerDay = 86400000

The remainder is called the time within the day:

TimeWithinDay(*t*) = *t* [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) msPerDay

<span id="sec-20.3.1.3" class="secnum">[20.3.1.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number "link to this section")</span> Year Number
==================================================================================================================================================================

ECMAScript uses an extrapolated Gregorian system to map a day number to a year number and to determine the month and date within that year. In this system, leap years are precisely those which are (divisible by <span style="font-family:
        Times New Roman">4</span>) and ((not divisible by <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">100</span>) or (divisible by <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">400</span>)). The number of days in year number y is therefore defined by

DaysInYear(*y*) = 365 if (*y* [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) 4) ≠ 0
= 366 if (*y* [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) 4) = 0 and (*y* [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) 100) ≠ 0
= 365 if (*y* [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) 100) = 0 and (*y* [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) 400) ≠ 0
= 366 if (*y* [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) 400) = 0

All non-leap years have <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">365</span> days with the usual number of days per month and leap years have an extra day in February. The day number of the first day of year y is given by:

DayFromYear(*y*) = 365 × (*y*−1970) + [floor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)((*y*−1969)/4) − [floor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)((*y*−1901)/100) + [floor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)((*y*−1601)/400)

The [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) of the start of a year is:

TimeFromYear(*y*) = [msPerDay](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-day-number-and-time-within-day) × DayFromYear(*y*)

A [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) determines a year by:

YearFromTime(*t*) = the largest integer *y* (closest to positive infinity) such that TimeFromYear(*y*) ≤ *t*

The leap-year function is 1 for a time within a leap year and otherwise is zero:

InLeapYear(*t*) = 0 if DaysInYear(YearFromTime(*t*)) = 365
= 1 if DaysInYear(YearFromTime(*t*)) = 366

<span id="sec-20.3.1.4" class="secnum">[20.3.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number "link to this section")</span> Month Number
====================================================================================================================================================================

Months are identified by an integer in the range <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">0</span> to <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">11</span>, inclusive. The mapping MonthFromTime(*t*) from a [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) *t* to a month number is defined by:

MonthFromTime(*t*) = 0 if 0 ≤ DayWithinYear(*t*) &lt; 31
 = 1 if 31 ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 59+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)
 = 2 if 59+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 90+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)
 = 3 if 90+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 120+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)
 = 4 if 120+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 151+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)
 = 5 if 151+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 181+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)
 = 6 if 181+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 212+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)
 = 7 if 212+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 243+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)
 = 8 if 243+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 273+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)
 = 9 if 273+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 304+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)
 = 10 if 304+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 334+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)
 = 11 if 334+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) ≤ DayWithinYear (*t*) &lt; 365+[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*)

where

DayWithinYear(*t*) = [Day](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-day-number-and-time-within-day)(*t*)−DayFromYear([YearFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*))

A month value of <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">0</span> specifies January; <span style="font-family: Times
        New Roman">1</span> specifies February; <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">2</span> specifies March; <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">3</span> specifies April; <span style="font-family: Times New
        Roman">4</span> specifies May; <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">5</span> specifies June; <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">6</span> specifies July; <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">7</span> specifies August; <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">8</span> specifies September; <span style="font-family: Times
        New Roman">9</span> specifies October; <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">10</span> specifies November; and <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">11</span> specifies December. Note that <span style="font-family: Times New
        Roman">MonthFromTime(0) = 0</span>, corresponding to Thursday, 01 January, 1970.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.5" class="secnum">[20.3.1.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-number "link to this section")</span> Date Number
==================================================================================================================================================================

A date number is identified by an integer in the range <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">1</span> through <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">31</span>, inclusive. The mapping DateFromTime(*t*) from a [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) *t* to a date number is defined by:

DateFromTime(*t*) = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)+1 if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=0
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−30 if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=1
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−58−[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=2
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−89−[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=3
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−119−[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=4
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−150−[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=5
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−180−[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=6
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−211−[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=7
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−242−[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=8
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−272−[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=9
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−303−[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=10
 = [DayWithinYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)−333−[InLeapYear](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) if [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*)=11

<span id="sec-20.3.1.6" class="secnum">[20.3.1.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-week-day "link to this section")</span> Week Day
============================================================================================================================================================

The weekday for a particular [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) t is defined as

WeekDay(*t*) = ([Day](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-day-number-and-time-within-day)(*t*) + 4) [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) 7

A weekday value of <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">0</span> specifies Sunday; <span style="font-family:
        Times New Roman">1</span> specifies Monday; <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">2</span> specifies Tuesday; <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">3</span> specifies Wednesday; <span style="font-family: Times New
        Roman">4</span> specifies Thursday; <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">5</span> specifies Friday; and <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">6</span> specifies Saturday. Note that <span style="font-family: Times New
        Roman">WeekDay(0) = 4</span>, corresponding to Thursday, 01 January, 1970.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.7" class="secnum">[20.3.1.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-local-time-zone-adjustment "link to this section")</span> Local Time Zone Adjustment
================================================================================================================================================================================================

An implementation of ECMAScript is expected to determine the local time zone adjustment. The local time zone adjustment is a value LocalTZA measured in milliseconds which when added to UTC represents the local *standard* time. Daylight saving time is *not* reflected by LocalTZA.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> It is recommended that implementations use the time zone information of the IANA Time Zone Database <http://www.iana.org/time-zones/>.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.8" class="secnum">[20.3.1.8](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-daylight-saving-time-adjustment "link to this section")</span> Daylight Saving Time Adjustment
==========================================================================================================================================================================================================

An implementation dependent algorithm using best available information on time zones to determine the local daylight saving time adjustment DaylightSavingTA(*t*), measured in milliseconds. An implementation of ECMAScript is expected to make its best effort to determine the local daylight saving time adjustment.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> It is recommended that implementations use the time zone information of the IANA Time Zone Database <http://www.iana.org/time-zones/>.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.9" class="secnum">[20.3.1.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-localtime "link to this section")</span> LocalTime ( t )
====================================================================================================================================================================

The abstract operation LocalTime with argument t converts t from UTC to local time by performing the following steps:

1.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*t*).
2.  Return *t* + [LocalTZA](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-local-time-zone-adjustment) + [DaylightSavingTA](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-daylight-saving-time-adjustment)(*t*).

<span id="sec-20.3.1.10" class="secnum">[20.3.1.10](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utc-t "link to this section")</span> UTC ( t )
============================================================================================================================================================

The abstract operation UTC with argument t converts t from local time to UTC is defined by performing the following steps:

1.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*t*).
2.  Return *t* – [LocalTZA](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-local-time-zone-adjustment) – [DaylightSavingTA](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-daylight-saving-time-adjustment)(*t* – [LocalTZA](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-local-time-zone-adjustment)).

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> UTC([LocalTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-localtime)(*t*)) is not necessarily always equal to *t*.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.11" class="secnum">[20.3.1.11](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-hours-minutes-second-and-milliseconds "link to this section")</span> Hours, Minutes, Second, and Milliseconds
===========================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The following abstract operations are useful in decomposing time values:

HourFromTime(*t*) = [floor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*t* / msPerHour) [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) HoursPerDay

MinFromTime(*t*) = [floor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*t* / msPerMinute) [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) MinutesPerHour

SecFromTime(*t*) = [floor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*t* / msPerSecond) [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) SecondsPerMinute

msFromTime(*t*) = *t* [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) msPerSecond

where

HoursPerDay = 24

MinutesPerHour = 60

SecondsPerMinute = 60

msPerSecond = 1000

msPerMinute = 60000 = msPerSecond × SecondsPerMinute

msPerHour = 3600000 = msPerMinute × MinutesPerHour

<span id="sec-20.3.1.12" class="secnum">[20.3.1.12](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-maketime "link to this section")</span> MakeTime (hour, min, sec, ms)
===================================================================================================================================================================================

The abstract operation MakeTime calculates a number of milliseconds from its four arguments, which must be ECMAScript Number values. This operator functions as follows:

1.  If *hour* is not finite or *min* is not finite or *sec* is not finite or *ms* is not finite, return **NaN**.
2.  Let *h* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*hour*).
3.  Let *m* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*min*).
4.  Let *s* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*sec*).
5.  Let *milli* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*ms*).
6.  Let *t* be *h* `*` [msPerHour](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-hours-minutes-second-and-milliseconds) `+` *m* `*` [msPerMinute](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-hours-minutes-second-and-milliseconds) `+` *s* `*` [msPerSecond](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-hours-minutes-second-and-milliseconds) `+` *milli*, performing the arithmetic according to IEEE 754-2008 rules (that is, as if using the ECMAScript operators `*` and `+`).
7.  Return *t*.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.13" class="secnum">[20.3.1.13](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-makeday "link to this section")</span> MakeDay (year, month, date)
================================================================================================================================================================================

The abstract operation MakeDay calculates a number of days from its three arguments, which must be ECMAScript Number values. This operator functions as follows:

1.  If *year* is not finite or *month* is not finite or *date* is not finite, return **NaN**.
2.  Let *y* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*year*).
3.  Let *m* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*month*).
4.  Let *dt* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*date*).
5.  Let *ym* be *y* + [floor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*m* /12).
6.  Let *mn* be *m* [modulo](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions) 12.
7.  Find a value *t* such that [YearFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)(*t*) is *ym* and [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*) is *mn* and [DateFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-number)(*t*) is 1; but if this is not possible (because some argument is out of range), return **NaN**.
8.  Return [Day](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-day-number-and-time-within-day)(*t*) + *dt* − 1.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.14" class="secnum">[20.3.1.14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-makedate "link to this section")</span> MakeDate (day, time)
==========================================================================================================================================================================

The abstract operation MakeDate calculates a number of milliseconds from its two arguments, which must be ECMAScript Number values. This operator functions as follows:

1.  If *day* is not finite or *time* is not finite, return **NaN**.
2.  Return *day* × [msPerDay](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-day-number-and-time-within-day) + *time*.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.15" class="secnum">[20.3.1.15](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-timeclip "link to this section")</span> TimeClip (time)
=====================================================================================================================================================================

The abstract operation TimeClip calculates a number of milliseconds from its argument, which must be an ECMAScript Number value. This operator functions as follows:

1.  If *time* is not finite, return **NaN**.
2.  If [abs](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions)(*time*) &gt; 8.64 <span style="font-family:
                  sans-serif">×</span> 10<sup>15</sup>, return **NaN**.
3.  Return [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*time*) + (**+0**). (Adding a positive zero converts **−0** to **+0**.)

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The point of step 3 is that an implementation is permitted a choice of internal representations of time values, for example as a 64-bit signed integer or as a 64-bit floating-point value. Depending on the implementation, this internal representation may or may not distinguish **−0** and **+0**.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.16" class="secnum">[20.3.1.16](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-time-string-format "link to this section")</span> Date Time String Format
============================================================================================================================================================================================

ECMAScript defines a string interchange format for date-times based upon a simplification of the ISO 8601 Extended Format. The format is as follows: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ`

Where the fields are as follows:

`YYYY` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">is the decimal digits of the year 0000 to 9999 in the Gregorian calendar.</span>

`-` `"-"` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">(hyphen) appears literally twice in the string.</span>

`MM` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">is the month of the year from 01 (January) to 12 (December).</span>

`DD` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">is the day of the month from 01 to 31.</span>

`T` `"T"` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">appears literally in the string, to indicate the beginning of the time element.</span>

`HH` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">is the number of complete hours that have passed since midnight as two decimal digits from 00 to 24.</span>

`:` `":"` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">(colon) appears literally twice in the string.</span>

`mm` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">is the number of complete minutes since the start of the hour as two decimal digits from 00 to 59.</span>

`ss` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">is the number of complete seconds since the start of the minute as two decimal digits from 00 to 59.</span>

`.` `"."` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">(dot) appears literally in the string.</span>

`sss` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">is the number of complete milliseconds since the start of the second as three decimal digits.</span>

`Z` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">is the time zone offset specified as</span> `"Z"` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">(for UTC) or either</span> `"+"` <span style="font-family:
          sans-serif">or</span> `"-"` <span style="font-family: sans-serif">followed by a time expression</span> `HH:mm`

This format includes date-only forms:

    YYYY
    YYYY-MM
    YYYY-MM-DD

It also includes “date-time” forms that consist of one of the above date-only forms immediately followed by one of the following time forms with an optional time zone offset appended:

    THH:mm
    THH:mm:ss
    THH:mm:ss.sss

All numbers must be base <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">10</span>. If the `MM` or `DD` fields are absent `"01"` is used as the value. If the `HH`, `mm`, or `ss` fields are absent `"00"` is used as the value and the value of an absent `sss` field is `"000"`. If the time zone offset is absent, the date-time is interpreted as a local time.

Illegal values (out-of-bounds as well as syntax errors) in a format string means that the format string is not a valid instance of this format.

<span class="nh">NOTE 1</span> As every day both starts and ends with midnight, the two notations `00:00` and `24:00` are available to distinguish the two midnights that can be associated with one date. This means that the following two notations refer to exactly the same point in time: `1995-02-04T24:00` and `1995-02-05T00:00`

<span class="nh">NOTE 2</span> There exists no international standard that specifies abbreviations for civil time zones like CET, EST, etc. and sometimes the same abbreviation is even used for two very different time zones. For this reason, ISO 8601 and this format specifies numeric representations of date and time.

<span id="sec-20.3.1.16.1" class="secnum">[20.3.1.16.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-extended-years "link to this section")</span> Extended years
==============================================================================================================================================================================

ECMAScript requires the ability to specify <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">6</span> digit years (extended years); approximately <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">285,426</span> years, either forward or backward, from 01 January, 1970 UTC. To represent years before <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">0</span> or after <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">9999</span>, ISO 8601 permits the expansion of the year representation, but only by prior agreement between the sender and the receiver. In the simplified ECMAScript format such an expanded year representation shall have <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">2</span> extra year digits and is always prefixed with a + or – sign. The year <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">0</span> is considered positive and hence prefixed with a + sign.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> Examples of extended years:

-283457-03-21T15:00:59.008Z 283458 B.C.<span style="font-family: Times New
            Roman">
</span>-000001-01-01T00:00:00Z 2 B.C.<span style="font-family: Times New
            Roman">
</span>+000000-01-01T00:00:00Z 1 B.C.<span style="font-family: Times New
            Roman">
</span>+000001-01-01T00:00:00Z 1 A.D.<span style="font-family: Times New
            Roman">
</span>+001970-01-01T00:00:00Z 1970 A.D.<span style="font-family: Times New
            Roman">
</span>+002009-12-15T00:00:00Z 2009 A.D.<span style="font-family: Times New
            Roman">
</span>+287396-10-12T08:59:00.992Z 287396 A.D.

<span id="sec-20.3.2" class="secnum">[20.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-constructor "link to this section")</span> The Date Constructor
============================================================================================================================================================================

The Date constructor is the %Date% intrinsic object and the initial value of the `Date` property of the global object. When called as a constructor it creates and initializes a new Date object. When `Date` is called as a function rather than as a constructor, it returns a String representing the current time (UTC).

The `Date` constructor is a single function whose behaviour is overloaded based upon the number and types of its arguments.

The `Date` constructor is designed to be subclassable. It may be used as the value of an `extends` clause of a class definition. Subclass constructors that intend to inherit the specified `Date` behaviour must include a `super` call to the `Date` constructor to create and initialize the subclass instance with a \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

<span id="sec-20.3.2.1" class="secnum">[20.3.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-year-month-date-hours-minutes-seconds-ms "link to this section")</span> Date ( year, month \[, date \[ , hours \[ , minutes \[ , seconds \[ , ms \] \] \] \] \] )
==================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

This description applies only if the Date constructor is called with at least two arguments.

When the `Date` function is called the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *numberOfArgs* be the number of arguments passed to this function call.
2.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *numberOfArgs* ≥ 2.
3.  If NewTarget is not **undefined**, then
    1.  Let *y* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*year*).
    2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*y*).
    3.  Let *m* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*month*).
    4.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*m*).
    5.  If *date* is supplied, let *dt* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*date*); else let *dt* be **1**.
    6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*dt*).
    7.  If *hours* is supplied, let *h* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*hours*); else let *h* be **0**.
    8.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*h*).
    9.  If *minutes* is supplied, let *min* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*minutes*); else let *min* be **0**.
    10. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*min*).
    11. If *seconds* is supplied, let *s* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*seconds*); else let *s* be **0**.
    12. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*s*).
    13. If *ms* is supplied, let *milli* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*ms*); else let *milli* be **0**.
    14. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*milli*).
    15. If *y* is not **NaN** and 0 ≤ [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*y*) ≤ 99, let *yr* be 1900+[ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*y*); otherwise, let *yr* be *y*.
    16. Let *finalDate* be [MakeDate](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-makedate)([MakeDay](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-makeday)(*yr*, *m*, *dt*), [MakeTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-maketime)(*h*, *min*, *s*, *milli*)).
    17. Let *O* be [OrdinaryCreateFromConstructor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ordinarycreatefromconstructor)(NewTarget, `"%DatePrototype%"`, «‍ \[\[DateValue\]\]»).
    18. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*O*).
    19. Set the \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O* to [TimeClip](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-timeclip)([UTC](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utc-t)(*finalDate*)).
    20. Return *O*.

4.  Else,
    1.  Let *now* be the Number that is the [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) (UTC) identifying the current time.
    2.  Return [ToDateString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-todatestring) (*now*).

<span id="sec-20.3.2.2" class="secnum">[20.3.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-value "link to this section")</span> Date ( value )
====================================================================================================================================================================

This description applies only if the Date constructor is called with exactly one argument.

When the `Date` function is called the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *numberOfArgs* be the number of arguments passed to this function call.
2.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *numberOfArgs* = 1.
3.  If NewTarget is not **undefined**, then
    1.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*value*) is Object and *value* has a \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots), then
        1.  Let *tv* be thisTimeValue(*value*).

    2.  Else,
        1.  Let *v* be [ToPrimitive](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-toprimitive)(*value*).
        2.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*v*) is String, then
            1.  Let *tv* be the result of parsing *v* as a date, in exactly the same manner as for the `parse` method ([20.3.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.parse)). If the parse resulted in an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type), *tv* is the [Completion Record](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type).

        3.  Else,
            1.  Let *tv* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*v*).

    3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*tv*).
    4.  Let *O* be [OrdinaryCreateFromConstructor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ordinarycreatefromconstructor)(NewTarget, `"%DatePrototype%"`, «‍ \[\[DateValue\]\]»).
    5.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*O*).
    6.  Set the \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O* to [TimeClip](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-timeclip)(*tv*).
    7.  Return *O*.

4.  Else,
    1.  Let *now* be the Number that is the [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) (UTC) identifying the current time.
    2.  Return [ToDateString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-todatestring) (*now*).

<span id="sec-20.3.2.3" class="secnum">[20.3.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-constructor-date "link to this section")</span> Date ( )
=========================================================================================================================================================================

This description applies only if the Date constructor is called with no arguments.

When the `Date` function is called the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *numberOfArgs* be the number of arguments passed to this function call.
2.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *numberOfArgs* = 0.
3.  If NewTarget is not **undefined**, then
    1.  Let *O* be [OrdinaryCreateFromConstructor](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ordinarycreatefromconstructor)(NewTarget, `"%DatePrototype%"`, «‍ \[\[DateValue\]\]»).
    2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*O*).
    3.  Set the \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O* to the [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) (UTC) identifying the current time.
    4.  Return *O*.

4.  Else,
    1.  Let *now* be the Number that is the [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) (UTC) identifying the current time.
    2.  Return [ToDateString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-todatestring) (*now*).

<span id="sec-20.3.3" class="secnum">[20.3.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-date-constructor "link to this section")</span> Properties of the Date Constructor
============================================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of the Date constructor is the intrinsic object %FunctionPrototype% ([19.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-function-prototype-object)).

Besides the `length` property (whose value is `7`), the Date constructor has the following properties:

<span id="sec-20.3.3.1" class="secnum">[20.3.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.now "link to this section")</span> Date.now ( )
================================================================================================================================================================

The `now` function returns a Number value that is the [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) designating the UTC date and time of the occurrence of the call to `now`.

<span id="sec-20.3.3.2" class="secnum">[20.3.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.parse "link to this section")</span> Date.parse ( string )
===========================================================================================================================================================================

The `parse` function applies the [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring) operator to its argument. If [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring) results in an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type) the [Completion Record](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type) is immediately returned. Otherwise, `parse` interprets the resulting String as a date and time; it returns a Number, the UTC [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) corresponding to the date and time. The String may be interpreted as a local time, a UTC time, or a time in some other time zone, depending on the contents of the String. The function first attempts to parse the format of the String according to the rules (including extended years) called out in Date Time String Format ([20.3.1.16](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-time-string-format)). If the String does not conform to that format the function may fall back to any implementation-specific heuristics or implementation-specific date formats. Unrecognizable Strings or dates containing illegal element values in the format String shall cause `Date.parse` to return **NaN**.

If x is any Date object whose milliseconds amount is zero within a particular implementation of ECMAScript, then all of the following expressions should produce the same numeric value in that implementation, if all the properties referenced have their initial values:

    x.valueOf()

    Date.parse(x.toString())

    Date.parse(x.toUTCString())

    Date.parse(x.toISOString())

However, the expression

    Date.parse(x.toLocaleString())

is not required to produce the same Number value as the preceding three expressions and, in general, the value produced by `Date.parse` is implementation-dependent when given any String value that does not conform to the Date Time String Format ([20.3.1.16](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-time-string-format)) and that could not be produced in that implementation by the `toString` or `toUTCString` method.

<span id="sec-20.3.3.3" class="secnum">[20.3.3.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.prototype "link to this section")</span> Date.prototype
========================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of `Date.prototype` is the intrinsic object %DatePrototype% ([20.3.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-date-prototype-object)).

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-20.3.3.4" class="secnum">[20.3.3.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.utc "link to this section")</span> Date.UTC ( year, month \[ , date \[ , hours \[ , minutes \[ , seconds \[ , ms \] \] \] \] \] )
==================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the `UTC` function is called with fewer than two arguments, the behaviour is implementation-dependent. When the `UTC` function is called with two to seven arguments, it computes the date from year, month and (optionally) date, hours, minutes, seconds and ms. The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *y* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*year*).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*y*).
3.  Let *m* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*month*).
4.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*m*).
5.  If *date* is supplied, let *dt* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*date*); else let *dt* be **1**.
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*dt*).
7.  If *hours* is supplied, let *h* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*hours*); else let *h* be **0**.
8.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*h*).
9.  If *minutes* is supplied, let *min* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*minutes*); else let *min* be **0**.
10. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*min*).
11. If *seconds* is supplied, let *s* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*seconds*); else let *s* be **0**.
12. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*s*).
13. If *ms* is supplied, let *milli* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*ms*); else let *milli* be **0**.
14. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*milli*).
15. If *y* is not **NaN** and 0 ≤ [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*y*) ≤ 99, let *yr* be 1900+[ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*y*); otherwise, let *yr* be *y*.
16. Return [TimeClip](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-timeclip)([MakeDate](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-makedate)([MakeDay](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-makeday)(*yr*, *m*, *dt*), [MakeTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-maketime)(*h*, *min*, *s*, *milli*))).

The `length` property of the `UTC` function is **7**.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `UTC` function differs from the `Date` constructor in two ways: it returns a [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) as a Number, rather than creating a Date object, and it interprets the arguments in UTC rather than as local time.

<span id="sec-20.3.4" class="secnum">[20.3.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-date-prototype-object "link to this section")</span> Properties of the Date Prototype Object
======================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The Date prototype object is the intrinsic object %DatePrototype%. The Date prototype object is itself an ordinary object. It is not a Date instance and does not have a \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

The value of the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of the Date prototype object is the intrinsic object %ObjectPrototype% ([20.3.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-date-prototype-object)).

Unless explicitly defined otherwise, the methods of the Date prototype object defined below are not generic and the **this** value passed to them must be an object that has a \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) that has been initialized to a [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range).

The abstract operation <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">thisTimeValue(*value*)</span> performs the following steps:

1.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*value*) is Object and *value* has a \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots), then
    1.  Return the value of *value’s* \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

2.  Throw a **TypeError** exception.

In following descriptions of functions that are properties of the Date prototype object, the phrase “this Date object” refers to the object that is the **this** value for the invocation of the function. If the Type of the **this** value is not Object, a <span class="value">TypeError</span> exception is thrown. The phrase “this [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range)” within the specification of a method refers to the result returned by calling the abstract operation thisTimeValue with the **this** value of the method invocation passed as the argument.

<span id="sec-20.3.4.1" class="secnum">[20.3.4.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.prototype.constructor "link to this section")</span> Date.prototype.constructor
================================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of `Date.prototype.constructor` is the intrinsic object %Date%.

<span id="sec-20.3.4.2" class="secnum">[20.3.4.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.prototype.getdate "link to this section")</span> Date.prototype.getDate ( )

4.  Return [DateFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-number)([LocalTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-localtime)(*t*)).

<span id="sec-20.3.4.16" class="secnum">[20.3.4.16](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.prototype.getutcmilliseconds "link to this section")</span> Date.prototype.getUTCMilliseconds ( )
