<span id="sec-21.1.3.15" class="secnum">[21.1.3.15](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.search "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.search ( regexp )
=======================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the search method is called with argument regexp, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(**this** value).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*O*).
3.  If *regexp* is not **undefined*,*** then
    1.  Let *searcher* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*regexp*, @@search).
    2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*searcher*).
    3.  If *searcher* is not **undefined** , then
        1.  Return [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*searcher*, *regexp*, «*O*»)

4.  Let *string* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*O*).
5.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*string*).
6.  Let *rx* be [RegExpCreate](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexpcreate)(*regexp*, **undefined**) ([see 21.2.3.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexpcreate)).
7.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*rx*).
8.  Return [Invoke](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-invoke)(*rx*, @@search, «‍*string*»).

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `search` function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore, it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.16" class="secnum">[21.1.3.16](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.slice "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.slice ( start, end )
=========================================================================================================================================================================================================

The `slice` method takes two arguments, start and end, and returns a substring of the result of converting this object to a String, starting from index start and running to, but not including, index end (or through the end of the String if end is **undefined**). If start is negative, it is treated as <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*sourceLength*+*start*</span> where sourceLength is the length of the String. If end is negative, it is treated as <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*sourceLength*+*end*</span> where sourceLength is the length of the String. The result is a String value, not a String object. The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(**this** value).
2.  Let *S* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*O*).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*S*).
4.  Let *len* be the number of elements in *S*.
5.  Let *intStart* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*start*).
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*intStart*).
7.  If *end* is **undefined**, let *intEnd* be *len*; else let *intEnd* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*end*).
8.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*intEnd*).
9.  If *intStart* &lt; 0, let *from* be max(*len* + *intStart*,0); otherwise let *from* be min(*intStart*, *len*).
10. If *intEnd* &lt; 0, let *to* be max(*len* + *intEnd*,0); otherwise let *to* be min(*intEnd*, *len*).
11. Let *span* be max(*to* – *from*,0).
12. Return a String value containing *span* consecutive elements from *S* beginning with the element at index *from*.

The `length` property of the `slice` method is **2**.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `slice` function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.17" class="secnum">[21.1.3.17](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.split "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.split ( separator, limit )
===============================================================================================================================================================================================================

Returns an Array object into which substrings of the result of converting this object to a String have been stored. The substrings are determined by searching from left to right for occurrences of separator; these occurrences are not part of any substring in the returned array, but serve to divide up the String value. The value of separator may be a String of any length or it may be a RegExp object.

When the `split` method is called, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(**this** value).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*O*).
3.  If *separator* is not **undefined**, then
    1.  Let *splitter* be [GetMethod](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getmethod)(*separator*, @@split).
    2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*splitter*).
    3.  If *splitter* is not **undefined** , then
        1.  Return [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call)(*splitter*, *separator*, «‍*O*, *limit*»).

4.  Let *S* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*O*).
5.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*S*).
6.  Let *A* be [ArrayCreate](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-arraycreate)(0).
7.  Let *lengthA* be 0.
8.  If *limit* is **undefined**, let *lim* = 2<sup>53</sup>–1; else let *lim* = [ToLength](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tolength)(*limit*).
9.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*lim*).
10. Let *s* be the number of elements in *S*.
11. Let *p* = 0.
12. Let *R* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*separator*).
13. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*R*).
14. If *lim* = 0, return *A*.
15. If *separator* is **undefined**, then
    1.  Perform [CreateDataProperty](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createdataproperty)(*A*, `"0"`, *S*).
    2.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): The above call will never result in an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type).
    3.  Return *A*.

16. If *s* = 0, then
    1.  Let *z* be [SplitMatch](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-splitmatch)(*S*, 0, *R*).
    2.  If *z* is not **false**, return *A*.
    3.  Perform [CreateDataProperty](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createdataproperty)(*A*, `"0"`, *S*).
    4.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): The above call will never result in an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type).
    5.  Return *A*.

17. Let *q* = *p*.
18. Repeat, while *q* ≠ *s*
    1.  Let *e* be [SplitMatch](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-splitmatch)(*S, q, R*).
    2.  If *e* is **false**, let *q* = *q*+1.
    3.  Else *e* is an integer index into *S*,
        1.  If *e* = *p*, let *q* = *q*+1.
        2.  Else *e* ≠ *p*,
            1.  Let *T* be a String value equal to the substring of *S* consisting of the code units at indices *p* (inclusive) through *q* (exclusive).
            2.  Perform [CreateDataProperty](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createdataproperty)(*A*, [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*lengthA*), *T*).
            3.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): The above call will never result in an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type).
            4.  Increment *lengthA* by 1.
            5.  If *lengthA* = *lim*, return *A*.
            6.  Let *p* = *e*.
            7.  Let *q* = *p*.

19. Let *T* be a String value equal to the substring of *S* consisting of the code units at indices *p* (inclusive) through *s* (exclusive).
20. Perform [CreateDataProperty](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createdataproperty)(*A*, [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*lengthA*), *T*).
21. [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): The above call will never result in an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type).
22. Return *A*.

The `length` property of the `split` method is **2**.

<span class="nh">NOTE 1</span> The value of *separator* may be an empty String, an empty regular expression, or a regular expression that can match an empty String. In this case, *separator* does not match the empty substring at the beginning or end of the input String, nor does it match the empty substring at the end of the previous separator match. (For example, if *separator* is the empty String, the String is split up into individual code unit elements; the length of the result array equals the length of the String, and each substring contains one code unit.) If *separator* is a regular expression, only the first match at a given index of the **this** String is considered, even if backtracking could yield a non-empty-substring match at that index. (For example, `"ab".split(/a*?/)` evaluates to the array `["a","b"]`, while `"ab".split(/a*/)` evaluates to the array`["","b"]`.)

If the **this** object is (or converts to) the empty String, the result depends on whether *separator* can match the empty String. If it can, the result array contains no elements. Otherwise, the result array contains one element, which is the empty String.

If *separator* is a regular expression that contains capturing parentheses, then each time *separator* is matched the results (including any **undefined** results) of the capturing parentheses are spliced into the output array. For example,

    "A<B>bold</B>and<CODE>coded</CODE>".split(/<(\/)?([^<>]+)>/)

evaluates to the array

    ["A", undefined, "B", "bold", "/", "B", "and", undefined,
     "CODE", "coded", "/", "CODE", ""]

If *separator* is **undefined**, then the result array contains just one String, which is the **this** value (converted to a String). If *limit* is not **undefined**, then the output array is truncated so that it contains no more than *limit* elements.

<span class="nh">NOTE 2</span> The `split` function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore, it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.17.1" class="secnum">[21.1.3.17.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-splitmatch "link to this section")</span> Runtime Semantics: SplitMatch ( S, q, R )
=====================================================================================================================================================================================================

The abstract operation SplitMatch takes three parameters, a String S, an integer q, and a String R, and performs the following steps in order to return either **false** or the end index of a match:

1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*R*) is String.
2.  Let *r* be the number of code units in *R*.
3.  Let *s* be the number of code units in *S*.
4.  If *q*+*r* &gt; *s*, return **false**.
5.  If there exists an integer *i* between 0 (inclusive) and *r* (exclusive) such that the code unit at index *q*+*i* of *S* is different from the code unit at index *i* of *R*, return **false**.
6.  Return *q*+*r*.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.18" class="secnum">[21.1.3.18](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.startswith "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.startsWith ( searchString \[, position \] )
=====================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(**this** value).
2.  Let *S* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*O*).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*S*).
4.  Let *isRegExp* be [IsRegExp](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-isregexp)(*searchString*).
5.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*isRegExp*).
6.  If *isRegExp* is **true**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
7.  Let *searchStr* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*searchString*).
8.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*searchString*).
9.  Let *pos* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*position*). (If *position* is **undefined**, this step produces the value **0**).
10. [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*pos*).
11. Let *len* be the number of elements in *S*.
12. Let *start* be min(max(*pos*, 0), *len*).
13. Let *searchLength* be the number of elements in *searchStr*.
14. If *searchLength+start* is greater than *len*, return **false***.*
15. If the sequence of elements of *S* starting at *start* of length *searchLength* is the same as the full element sequence of *searchStr*, return **true**.
16. Otherwise, return **false**.

The **length** property of the **startsWith** method is **1**.

<span class="nh">NOTE 1</span> This method returns **true** if the sequence of elements of *searchString* converted to a String is the same as the corresponding elements of this object (converted to a String) starting at index *position*. Otherwise returns **false**.

<span class="nh">NOTE 2</span> Throwing an exception if the first argument is a RegExp is specified in order to allow future editions to define extensions that allow such argument values.

<span class="nh">NOTE 3</span> The **startsWith** function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore, it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.19" class="secnum">[21.1.3.19](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.substring "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.substring ( start, end )
=================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The **substring** method takes two arguments, start and end, and returns a substring of the result of converting this object to a String, starting from index start and running to, but not including, index end of the String (or through the end of the String is end is **undefined**). The result is a String value, not a String object.

If either argument is **NaN** or negative, it is replaced with zero; if either argument is larger than the length of the String, it is replaced with the length of the String.

If start is larger than end, they are swapped.

The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(**this** value).
2.  Let *S* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*O*).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*S*).
4.  Let *len* be the number of elements in *S*.
5.  Let *intStart* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*start*).
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*intStart*).
7.  If *end* is **undefined**, let *intEnd* be *len*; else let *intEnd* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*end*).
8.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*intEnd*).
9.  Let *finalStart* be min(max(*intStart*, 0), *len*).
10. Let *finalEnd* be min(max(*intEnd*, 0), *len*).
11. Let *from* be min(*finalStart*, *finalEnd*).
12. Let *to* be max(*finalStart*, *finalEnd*).
13. Return a String whose length is *to* - *from*, containing code units from *S*, namely the code units with indices *from* through *to* −1, in ascending order.

The `length` property of the `substring` method is **2**.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `substring` function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore, it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.20" class="secnum">[21.1.3.20](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.tolocalelowercase "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.toLocaleLowerCase ( \[ reserved1 \[ , reserved2 \] \] )
========================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

An ECMAScript implementation that includes the ECMA-402 Internationalization API must implement the `toLocaleLowerCase` method as specified in the ECMA-402 specification. If an ECMAScript implementation does not include the ECMA-402 API the following specification of the `toLocaleLowerCase` method is used.

This function interprets a string value as a sequence of UTF-16 encoded code points, as described in [6.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-string-type).

This function works exactly the same as `toLowerCase` except that its result is intended to yield the correct result for the host environment’s current locale, rather than a locale-independent result. There will only be a difference in the few cases (such as Turkish) where the rules for that language conflict with the regular Unicode case mappings.

The **length** property of the **toLocaleLowerCase** method is **0**.

The meaning of the optional parameters to this method are defined in the ECMA-402 specification; implementations that do not include ECMA-402 support must not use those parameter positions for anything else.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `toLocaleLowerCase` function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore, it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.21" class="secnum">[21.1.3.21](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.tolocaleuppercase "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.toLocaleUpperCase (\[ reserved1 \[ , reserved2 \] \] )
=======================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

An ECMAScript implementation that includes the ECMA-402 Internationalization API must implement the `toLocaleUpperCase` method as specified in the ECMA-402 specification. If an ECMAScript implementation does not include the ECMA-402 API the following specification of the `toLocaleUpperCase` method is used.

This function interprets a string value as a sequence of UTF-16 encoded code points, as described in [6.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-string-type).

This function works exactly the same as `toUpperCase` except that its result is intended to yield the correct result for the host environment’s current locale, rather than a locale-independent result. There will only be a difference in the few cases (such as Turkish) where the rules for that language conflict with the regular Unicode case mappings.

The **length** property of the **toLocaleUpperCase** method is **0**.

The meaning of the optional parameters to this method are defined in the ECMA-402 specification; implementations that do not include ECMA-402 support must not use those parameter positions for anything else.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `toLocaleUpperCase` function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore, it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.22" class="secnum">[21.1.3.22](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.tolowercase "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.toLowerCase ( )
==========================================================================================================================================================================================================

This function interprets a string value as a sequence of UTF-16 encoded code points, as described in [6.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-string-type). The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(**this** value).
2.  Let *S* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*O*).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*S*).
4.  Let *cpList* be a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) containing in order the code points as defined in [6.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-string-type) of *S*, starting at the first element of *S*.
5.  For each code point *c* in *cpList*, if the Unicode Character Database provides a language insensitive lower case equivalent of *c* then replace *c* in *cpList* with that equivalent code point(s).
6.  Let *cuList* be a new [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type).
7.  For each code point *c* in *cpList*, in order, append to *cuList* the elements of the [UTF16Encoding](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding) ([10.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16encoding)) of *c*.
8.  Let *L* be a String whose elements are, in order, the elements of *cuList* .
9.  Return *L*.

The result must be derived according to the locale-insensitive case mappings in the Unicode Character Database (this explicitly includes not only the UnicodeData.txt file, but also all locale-insensitive mappings in the SpecialCasings.txt file that accompanies it).

<span class="nh">NOTE 1</span> The case mapping of some code points may produce multiple code points . In this case the result String may not be the same length as the source String. Because both `toUpperCase` and `toLowerCase` have context-sensitive behaviour, the functions are not symmetrical. In other words, `s.toUpperCase().toLowerCase()` is not necessarily equal to `s.toLowerCase()`.

<span class="nh">NOTE 2</span> The `toLowerCase` function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore, it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.23" class="secnum">[21.1.3.23](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.tostring "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.toString ( )
====================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the `toString` method is called, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *s* be thisStringValue(**this** value).
2.  Return *s*.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> For a String object, the `toString` method happens to return the same thing as the `valueOf` method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.24" class="secnum">[21.1.3.24](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.touppercase "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.toUpperCase ( )
==========================================================================================================================================================================================================

This function interprets a string value as a sequence of UTF-16 encoded code points, as described in [6.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-string-type).

This function behaves in exactly the same way as `String.prototype.toLowerCase`, except that code points are mapped to their uppercase equivalents as specified in the Unicode Character Database.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `toUpperCase` function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore, it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.25" class="secnum">[21.1.3.25](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.trim "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.trim ( )
============================================================================================================================================================================================

This function interprets a string value as a sequence of UTF-16 encoded code points, as described in [6.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-string-type).

The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(**this** value).
2.  Let *S* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*O*).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*S*).
4.  Let *T* be a String value that is a copy of *S* with both leading and trailing white space removed. The definition of white space is the union of *WhiteSpace* and *LineTerminator*. When determining whether a Unicode code point is in Unicode general category “Zs”, code unit sequences are interpreted as UTF-16 encoded code point sequences as specified in [6.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-string-type).
5.  Return *T*.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `trim` function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore, it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.26" class="secnum">[21.1.3.26](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.valueof "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.valueOf ( )
==================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the `valueOf` method is called, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *s* be thisStringValue(**this** value).
2.  Return *s*.

<span id="sec-21.1.3.27" class="secnum">[21.1.3.27](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype-@@iterator "link to this section")</span> String.prototype \[ @@iterator \]( )
=============================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the @@iterator method is called it returns an Iterator object ([25.1.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-iterator-interface)) that iterates over the code points of a String value, returning each code point as a String value. The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(**this** value).
2.  Let *S* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*O*).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*S*).
4.  Return [CreateStringIterator](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createstringiterator)(*S*).

The value of the `name` property of this function is `"[Symbol.iterator]"`.

<span id="sec-21.1.4" class="secnum">[21.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-string-instances "link to this section")</span> Properties of String Instances
====================================================================================================================================================================================================

String instances are String exotic objects and have the internal methods specified for such objects. String instances inherit properties from the String prototype object. String instances also have a \[\[StringData\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

String instances have a `length` property, and a set of enumerable properties with integer indexed names.

<span id="sec-21.1.4.1" class="secnum">[21.1.4.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-string-instances-length "link to this section")</span> length
=======================================================================================================================================================================================

The number of elements in the String value represented by this String object.

Once a String object is initialized, this property is unchanging. It has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: **false**, \[\[Configurable\]\]: **false** }.

<span id="sec-21.1.5" class="secnum">[21.1.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string-iterator-objects "link to this section")</span> String Iterator Objects
======================================================================================================================================================================================

An String Iterator is an object, that represents a specific iteration over some specific String instance object. There is not a named constructor for String Iterator objects. Instead, String iterator objects are created by calling certain methods of String instance objects.

<span id="sec-21.1.5.1" class="secnum">[21.1.5.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createstringiterator "link to this section")</span> CreateStringIterator Abstract Operation
=======================================================================================================================================================================================================

Several methods of String objects return Iterator objects. The abstract operation CreateStringIterator with argument string is used to create such iterator objects. It performs the following steps:

1.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*string*) is String.
2.  Let *iterator* be [ObjectCreate](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-objectcreate)(%StringIteratorPrototype%, «\[\[IteratedString\]\], \[\[StringIteratorNextIndex\]\] »).
3.  Set *iterator’s* \[\[IteratedString\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) to *string*.
4.  Set *iterator’s* \[\[StringIteratorNextIndex\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) to 0.
5.  Return *iterator*.

<span id="sec-21.1.5.2" class="secnum">[21.1.5.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-%stringiteratorprototype%-object "link to this section")</span> The %StringIteratorPrototype% Object
================================================================================================================================================================================================================

All String Iterator Objects inherit properties from the %StringIteratorPrototype% intrinsic object. The %StringIteratorPrototype% object is an ordinary object and its \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) is the %IteratorPrototype% intrinsic object ([25.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-%iteratorprototype%-object)). In addition, %StringIteratorPrototype% has the following properties:

<span id="sec-21.1.5.2.1" class="secnum">[21.1.5.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-%stringiteratorprototype%.next "link to this section")</span> %StringIteratorPrototype%.next ( )
================================================================================================================================================================================================================

1.  Let *O* be the **this** value.
2.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*O*) is not Object, throw a **TypeError** exception.
3.  If *O* does not have all of the internal slots of an String Iterator Instance ([21.1.5.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-string-iterator-instances)), throw a **TypeError** exception.
4.  Let *s* be the value of the \[\[IteratedString\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
5.  If *s* is **undefined**, return [CreateIterResultObject](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createiterresultobject)(**undefined**, **true**).
6.  Let *position* be the value of the \[\[StringIteratorNextIndex\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O*.
7.  Let *len* be the number of elements in *s*.
8.  If *position* ≥ *len*, then
    1.  Set the value of the \[\[IteratedString\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O* to **undefined**.
    2.  Return [CreateIterResultObject](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createiterresultobject)(**undefined**, **true**).

9.  Let *first* be the code unit value at index *position* in *s*.
10. If *first* &lt; 0xD800 or *first* &gt; 0xDBFF or *position*+1 = *len*, let *resultString* be the string consisting of the single code unit *first*.
11. Else,
    1.  Let *second* be the code unit value at index *position*+1 in the String *S*.
    2.  If *second* &lt; 0xDC00 or *second* &gt; 0xDFFF, let *resultString* be the string consisting of the single code unit *first*.
    3.  Else, let *resultString* be the string consisting of the code unit *first* followed by the code unit *second*.

12. Let *resultSize* be the number of code units in *resultString*.
13. Set the value of the \[\[StringIteratorNextIndex\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *O* to *position*+ *resultSize*.
14. Return [CreateIterResultObject](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createiterresultobject)(*resultString*, **false**).

<span id="sec-21.1.5.2.2" class="secnum">[21.1.5.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-%stringiteratorprototype%-@@tostringtag "link to this section")</span> %StringIteratorPrototype% \[ @@toStringTag \]
====================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of the @@toStringTag property is the string value `"String Iterator"`.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Configurable\]\]: <span class="value">true</span> }.

<span id="sec-21.1.5.3" class="secnum">[21.1.5.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-string-iterator-instances "link to this section")</span> Properties of String Iterator Instances
==========================================================================================================================================================================================================================

String Iterator instances are ordinary objects that inherit properties from the %StringIteratorPrototype% intrinsic object. String Iterator instances are initially created with the internal slots listed in [Table 46](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#table-46).

<span id="table-46">Table 46</span> — Internal Slots of String Iterator Instances

| Internal Slot                   | Description                                                                  |
|---------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| \[\[IteratedString\]\]          | The String value whose elements are being iterated.                          |
| \[\[StringIteratorNextIndex\]\] | The integer index of the next string index to be examined by this iteration. |

<span id="sec-21.2" class="secnum">[21.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexp-regular-expression-objects "link to this section")</span> RegExp (Regular Expression) Objects
========================================================================================================================================================================================================

A RegExp object contains a regular expression and the associated flags.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The form and functionality of regular expressions is modelled after the regular expression facility in the Perl 5 programming language.

<span id="sec-21.2.1" class="secnum">[21.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-patterns "link to this section")</span> Patterns

<span id="sec-21.2.2" class="secnum">[21.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-pattern-semantics "link to this section")</span> Pattern Semantics
==========================================================================================================================================================================

A regular expression pattern is converted into an internal procedure using the process described below. An implementation is encouraged to use more efficient algorithms than the ones listed below, as long as the results are the same. The internal procedure is used as the value of a RegExp object’s \[\[RegExpMatcher\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

A *Pattern* is either a BMP pattern or a Unicode pattern depending upon whether or not its associated flags contain a `"u"`. A BMP pattern matches against a String interpreted as consisting of a sequence of 16-bit values that are Unicode code points in the range of the Basic Multilingual Plane. A Unicode pattern matches against a String interpreted as consisting of Unicode code points encoded using UTF-16. In the context of describing the behaviour of a BMP pattern “character” means a single 16-bit Unicode BMP code point. In the context of describing the behaviour of a Unicode pattern “character” means a UTF-16 encoded code point ([6.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-string-type)). In either context, “character value” means the numeric value of the corresponding non-encoded code point.

The syntax and semantics of *Pattern* is defined as if the source code for the *Pattern* was a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) of *SourceCharacter* values where each *SourceCharacter* corresponds to a Unicode code point. If a BMP pattern contains a non-BMP *SourceCharacter* the entire pattern is encoded using UTF-16 and the individual code units of that encoding are used as the elements of the [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type).

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> For example, consider a pattern expressed in source text as the single non-BMP character <span style="font-family: sans-serif">U+1D11E (MUSICAL SYMBOL G CLEF). Interpreted as a Unicode pattern, it would be a single element (character) [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) consisting of the single code point 0x1D11E. However, interpreted as a BMP pattern, it is first UTF-16 encoded to produce a two element [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) consisting of the code units 0xD834 and 0xDD1E.</span>

Patterns are passed to the RegExp constructor as ECMAScript string values in which non-BMP characters are UTF-16 encoded. For example, the single character MUSICAL SYMBOL G CLEF pattern, expressed as a string value, is a String of length 2 whose elements were the code units 0xD834 and 0xDD1E. So no further translation of the string would be necessary to process it as a BMP pattern consisting of two pattern characters. However, to process it as a Unicode pattern [UTF16Decode](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16decode) ([see 10.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utf16decode)) must be used in producing a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) consisting of a single pattern character, the code point U+1D11E.

An implementation may not actually perform such translations to or from UTF-16, but the semantics of this specification requires that the result of pattern matching be as if such translations were performed.

<span id="sec-21.2.2.1" class="secnum">[21.2.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-notation "link to this section")</span> Notation
============================================================================================================================================================

The descriptions below use the following variables:

-   *Input* is a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) consisting of all of the characters, in order, of the String being matched by the regular expression pattern. Each character is either a code unit or a code point, depending upon the kind of pattern involved. The notation <span style="font-family: Times
                New Roman">*Input*\[*n*\]</span> means the <span style="font-family: Times New
                Roman">*n<sup>th</sup>*</span> character of *Input*, where n can range between 0 (inclusive) and *InputLength* (exclusive).

-   *InputLength* is the number of characters in *Input*.

-   *NcapturingParens* is the total number of left capturing parentheses (i.e. the total number of times the <span class="prod">*Atom* <span class="geq">::</span> `(` *Disjunction* `)`</span> production is expanded) in the pattern. A left capturing parenthesis is any `(` pattern character that is matched by the `(` terminal of the <span class="prod">*Atom* <span class="geq">::</span> `(` *Disjunction* `)`</span> production.

-   *IgnoreCase* is **true** if the RegExp object's \[\[OriginalFlags\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) contains `"i"` and otherwise is **false**.

-   *Multiline* is **true** if the RegExp object’s \[\[OriginalFlags\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) contains `"m"` and otherwise is **false**.

-   *Unicode* is **true** if the RegExp object’s \[\[OriginalFlags\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) contains `"u"` and otherwise is **false**.

Furthermore, the descriptions below use the following internal data structures:

-   A *CharSet* is a mathematical set of characters, either code units or code points depending up the state of the *Unicode* flag. “All characters” means either all code unit values or all code point values also depending upon the state if *Unicode*.

-   A *State* is an ordered pair <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">(*endIndex*, *captures*)</span> where endIndex is an integer and captures is a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) of *NcapturingParens* values. *States* are used to represent partial match states in the regular expression matching algorithms. The endIndex is one plus the index of the last input character matched so far by the pattern, while captures holds the results of capturing parentheses. The <span style="font-family: Times New
                Roman">*n<sup>th</sup>*</span> element of captures is either a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) that represents the value obtained by the <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*n<sup>th</sup>*</span> set of capturing parentheses or **undefined** if the <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*n<sup>th</sup>*</span> set of capturing parentheses hasn’t been reached yet. Due to backtracking, many *States* may be in use at any time during the matching process.

-   A *MatchResult* is either a *State* or the special token **failure** that indicates that the match failed.

-   A *Continuation* procedure is an internal closure (i.e. an internal procedure with some arguments already bound to values) that takes one *State* argument and returns a *MatchResult* result. If an internal closure references variables which are bound in the function that creates the closure, the closure uses the values that these variables had at the time the closure was created. The *Continuation* attempts to match the remaining portion (specified by the closure's already-bound arguments) of the pattern against *Input*, starting at the intermediate state given by its *State* argument. If the match succeeds, the *Continuation* returns the final *State* that it reached; if the match fails, the *Continuation* returns **failure**.

-   A *Matcher* procedure is an internal closure that takes two arguments — a *State* and a *Continuation* — and returns a *MatchResult* result. A *Matcher* attempts to match a middle subpattern (specified by the closure's already-bound arguments) of the pattern against *Input*, starting at the intermediate state given by its *State* argument. The *Continuation* argument should be a closure that matches the rest of the pattern. After matching the subpattern of a pattern to obtain a new *State*, the *Matcher* then calls *Continuation* on that new *State* to test if the rest of the pattern can match as well. If it can, the *Matcher* returns the *State* returned by *Continuation*; if not, the *Matcher* may try different choices at its choice points, repeatedly calling *Continuation* until it either succeeds or all possibilities have been exhausted.

-   An *AssertionTester* procedure is an internal closure that takes a *State* argument and returns a Boolean result. The assertion tester tests a specific condition (specified by the closure's already-bound arguments) against the current place in *Input* and returns **true** if the condition matched or **false** if not.

-   An *EscapeValue* is either a character or an integer. An *EscapeValue* is used to denote the interpretation of a *DecimalEscape* escape sequence: a character ch means that the escape sequence is interpreted as the character ch, while an integer n means that the escape sequence is interpreted as a backreference to the <span style="font-family: Times
                New Roman">*n*<sup>th</sup></span> set of capturing parentheses.

<span id="sec-21.2.2.2" class="secnum">[21.2.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-pattern "link to this section")</span> Pattern
==========================================================================================================================================================

The production <span class="prod">*Pattern* <span class="geq">::</span> *Disjunction*</span> evaluates as follows:

1.  Evaluate *Disjunction* to obtain a Matcher *m*.
2.  Return an internal closure that takes two arguments, a String *str* and an integer *index*, and performs the following steps:
    1.  If *Unicode* is **true**, let *Input* be a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) consisting of the sequence of code points of *str* interpreted as a UTF-16 encoded ([6.1.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-types-string-type)) Unicode string. Otherwise, let *Input* be a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) consisting of the sequence of code units that are the elements of *str*. *Input* will be used throughout the algorithms in [21.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-pattern-semantics). Each element of *Input* is considered to be a character.
    2.  Let *listIndex* be the index into *Input* of the character that was obtained from element *index* of *str*.
    3.  Let *InputLength* be the number of characters contained in *Input*. This variable will be used throughout the algorithms in [21.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-pattern-semantics).
    4.  Let *c* be a Continuation that always returns its State argument as a successful MatchResult.
    5.  Let *cap* be a [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) of *NcapturingParens* **undefined** values, indexed 1 through *NcapturingParens*.
    6.  Let *x* be the State (*listIndex*, *cap*).
    7.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *m*(*x*, *c*) and return its result.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> A Pattern evaluates (“compiles”) to an internal procedure value. `RegExp.prototype.exec` and other methods can then apply this procedure to a String and an offset within the String to determine whether the pattern would match starting at exactly that offset within the String, and, if it does match, what the values of the capturing parentheses would be. The algorithms in [21.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-pattern-semantics) are designed so that compiling a pattern may throw a **SyntaxError** exception; on the other hand, once the pattern is successfully compiled, applying the resulting internal procedure to find a match in a String cannot throw an exception (except for any host-defined exceptions that can occur anywhere such as out-of-memory).

<span id="sec-21.2.2.3" class="secnum">[21.2.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-disjunction "link to this section")</span> Disjunction
==================================================================================================================================================================

The production <span class="prod">*Disjunction* <span class="geq">::</span> *Alternative*</span> evaluates by evaluating *Alternative* to obtain a <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">Matcher</span> and returning that <span style="font-family: Times New
        Roman">Matcher</span>.

The production <span class="prod">*Disjunction* <span class="geq">::</span> *Alternative* `|` *Disjunction*</span> evaluates as follows:

1.  Evaluate *Alternative* to obtain a Matcher *m1*.
2.  Evaluate *Disjunction* to obtain a Matcher *m2*.
3.  Return an internal Matcher closure that takes two arguments, a State *x* and a Continuation *c*, and performs the following steps when evaluated:
    1.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *m1*(*x*, *c*) and let *r* be its result.
    2.  If *r* is not **failure**, return *r*.
    3.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *m2*(*x*, *c*) and return its result.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `|` regular expression operator separates two alternatives. The pattern first tries to match the left *Alternative* (followed by the sequel of the regular expression); if it fails, it tries to match the right *Disjunction* (followed by the sequel of the regular expression). If the left *Alternative*, the right *Disjunction*, and the sequel all have choice points, all choices in the sequel are tried before moving on to the next choice in the left *Alternative*. If choices in the left *Alternative* are exhausted, the right *Disjunction* is tried instead of the left *Alternative*. Any capturing parentheses inside a portion of the pattern skipped by `|` produce **undefined** values instead of Strings. Thus, for example,

    /a|ab/.exec("abc")

returns the result `"a"` and not `"ab"`. Moreover,

    /((a)|(ab))((c)|(bc))/.exec("abc")

returns the array

    ["abc", "a", "a", undefined, "bc", undefined, "bc"]

and not

    ["abc", "ab", undefined, "ab", "c", "c", undefined]

<span id="sec-21.2.2.4" class="secnum">[21.2.2.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-alternative "link to this section")</span> Alternative
==================================================================================================================================================================

The production <span class="prod">*Alternative* <span class="geq">::</span> <span class="grhsannot">\[empty\]</span></span> evaluates by returning a Matcher that takes two arguments, a State x and a Continuation c, and returns the result of calling c(x).

The production <span class="prod">*Alternative* <span class="geq">::</span> *Alternative* *Term*</span> evaluates as follows:

1.  Evaluate *Alternative* to obtain a Matcher *m1*.
2.  Evaluate *Term* to obtain a Matcher *m2*.
3.  Return an internal Matcher closure that takes two arguments, a State *x* and a Continuation *c*, and performs the following steps when evaluated:
    1.  Create a Continuation *d* that takes a State argument *y* and returns the result of calling *m2*(*y*, *c*).
    2.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *m1*(*x*, *d*) and return its result.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> Consecutive *Terms* try to simultaneously match consecutive portions of *Input*. If the left *Alternative*, the right *Term*, and the sequel of the regular expression all have choice points, all choices in the sequel are tried before moving on to the next choice in the right *Term*, and all choices in the right *Term* are tried before moving on to the next choice in the left *Alternative*.

<span id="sec-21.2.2.5" class="secnum">[21.2.2.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-term "link to this section")</span> Term
====================================================================================================================================================

The production <span class="prod">*Term* <span class="geq">::</span> *Assertion*</span> evaluates by returning an internal Matcher closure that takes two arguments, a State x and a Continuation c, and performs the following steps when evaluated:

1.  Evaluate *Assertion* to obtain an AssertionTester *t*.
2.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *t*(*x*) and let *r* be the resulting Boolean value.
3.  If *r* is **false**, return **failure**.
4.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *c*(*x*) and return its result.

The production <span class="prod">*Term* <span class="geq">::</span> *Atom*</span> evaluates as follows:

1.  Return the Matcher that is the result of evaluating *Atom*.

The production <span class="prod">*Term* <span class="geq">::</span> *Atom* *Quantifier*</span> evaluates as follows:

1.  Evaluate *Atom* to obtain a Matcher *m*.
2.  Evaluate *Quantifier* to obtain the three results: an integer *min*, an integer (or ∞) *max*, and Boolean *greedy*.
3.  If *max* is finite and less than *min*, throw a **SyntaxError** exception.
4.  Let *parenIndex* be the number of left capturing parentheses in the entire regular expression that occur to the left of this production expansion's *Term*. This is the total number of times the <span class="prod">*Atom* <span class="geq">::</span> `(` *Disjunction* `)`</span> production is expanded prior to this production's *Term* plus the total number of <span class="prod">*Atom* <span class="geq">::</span> `(` *Disjunction* `)`</span> productions enclosing this *Term*.
5.  Let *parenCount* be the number of left capturing parentheses in the expansion of this production's *Atom*. This is the total number of <span class="prod">*Atom* <span class="geq">::</span> `(` *Disjunction* `)`</span> productions enclosed by this production's *Atom*.
6.  Return an internal Matcher closure that takes two arguments, a State *x* and a Continuation *c*, and performs the following steps when evaluated:
    1.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) RepeatMatcher(*m*, *min*, *max*, *greedy*, *x*, *c*, *parenIndex*, *parenCount*) and return its result.

<span id="sec-21.2.2.5.1" class="secnum">[21.2.2.5.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-runtime-semantics-repeatmatcher-abstract-operation "link to this section")</span> Runtime Semantics: RepeatMatcher Abstract Operation
=====================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The abstract operation <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">RepeatMatcher</span> takes eight parameters, a Matcher m, an integer min, an integer (or ∞) max, a Boolean greedy, a State x, a Continuation c, an integer parenIndex, and an integer parenCount, and performs the following steps:

1.  If *max* is zero, return *c*(*x*).
2.  Create an internal Continuation closure *d* that takes one State argument *y* and performs the following steps when evaluated:
    1.  If *min* is zero and *y*'s *endIndex* is equal to *x*'s *endIndex*, return **failure**.
    2.  If *min* is zero, let *min2* be zero; otherwise let *min2* be *min*–1.
    3.  If *max* is ∞, let *max2* be ∞; otherwise let *max2* be *max*–1.
    4.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) RepeatMatcher(*m*, *min2*, *max2*, *greedy*, *y*, *c*, *parenIndex*, *parenCount*) and return its result.

3.  Let *cap* be a fresh copy of *x*'s *captures* [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type).
4.  For every integer *k* that satisfies *parenIndex* &lt; *k* and *k* ≤ *parenIndex*+*parenCount*, set *cap*\[*k*\] to **undefined**.
5.  Let *e* be *x*'s *endIndex*.
6.  Let *xr* be the State (*e*, *cap*).
7.  If *min* is not zero, return *m*(*xr*, *d*).
8.  If *greedy* is **false**, then
    1.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *c*(*x*) and let *z* be its result.
    2.  If *z* is not **failure**, return *z*.
    3.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *m*(*xr*, *d*) and return its result.

9.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *m*(*xr*, *d*) and let *z* be its result.
10. If *z* is not **failure**, return *z*.
11. [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *c*(*x*) and return its result.

<span class="nh">NOTE 1</span> An *Atom* followed by a *Quantifier* is repeated the number of times specified by the *Quantifier*. A *Quantifier* can be non-greedy, in which case the *Atom* pattern is repeated as few times as possible while still matching the sequel, or it can be greedy, in which case the *Atom* pattern is repeated as many times as possible while still matching the sequel. The *Atom* pattern is repeated rather than the input character sequence that it matches, so different repetitions of the *Atom* can match different input substrings.

<span class="nh">NOTE 2</span> If the *Atom* and the sequel of the regular expression all have choice points, the *Atom* is first matched as many (or as few, if non-greedy) times as possible. All choices in the sequel are tried before moving on to the next choice in the last repetition of *Atom*. All choices in the last (n<sup>th</sup>) repetition of *Atom* are tried before moving on to the next choice in the next-to-last (n–1)<sup>st</sup> repetition of *Atom*; at which point it may turn out that more or fewer repetitions of *Atom* are now possible; these are exhausted (again, starting with either as few or as many as possible) before moving on to the next choice in the (n-1)<sup>st</sup> repetition of *Atom* and so on.

Compare

    /a[a-z]{2,4}/.exec("abcdefghi")

which returns `"abcde"` with

    /a[a-z]{2,4}?/.exec("abcdefghi")

which returns `"abc"`.

Consider also

    /(aa|aabaac|ba|b|c)*/.exec("aabaac")

which, by the choice point ordering above, returns the array

    ["aaba", "ba"]

and not any of:

    ["aabaac", "aabaac"]

    ["aabaac", "c"]

The above ordering of choice points can be used to write a regular expression that calculates the greatest common divisor of two numbers (represented in unary notation). The following example calculates the gcd of 10 and 15:

    "aaaaaaaaaa,aaaaaaaaaaaaaaa".replace(/^(a+)\1*,\1+$/,"$1")

which returns the gcd in unary notation `"aaaaa"`.

<span class="nh">NOTE 3</span> Step 5 of the RepeatMatcher clears *Atom's* captures each time *Atom* is repeated. We can see its behaviour in the regular expression

    /(z)((a+)?(b+)?(c))*/.exec("zaacbbbcac")

which returns the array

    ["zaacbbbcac", "z", "ac", "a", undefined, "c"]

and not

    ["zaacbbbcac", "z", "ac", "a", "bbb", "c"]

because each iteration of the outermost `*` clears all captured Strings contained in the quantified *Atom*, which in this case includes capture Strings numbered 2, 3, 4, and 5.

<span class="nh">NOTE 4</span> Step 1 of the RepeatMatcher's *d* closure states that, once the minimum number of repetitions has been satisfied, any more expansions of *Atom* that match the empty character sequence are not considered for further repetitions. This prevents the regular expression engine from falling into an infinite loop on patterns such as:

    /(a*)*/.exec("b")

or the slightly more complicated:

    /(a*)b\1+/.exec("baaaac")

which returns the array

    ["b", ""]

<span id="sec-21.2.2.6" class="secnum">[21.2.2.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-assertion "link to this section")</span> Assertion
==============================================================================================================================================================

The production <span class="prod">*Assertion* <span class="geq">::</span> `^`</span> evaluates by returning an internal AssertionTester closure that takes a State argument x and performs the following steps when evaluated:

1.  Let *e* be *x*'s *endIndex*.
2.  If *e* is zero, return **true**.
3.  If *Multiline* is **false**, return **false**.
4.  If the character *Input*\[*e*–1\] is one of *LineTerminator*, return **true**.
5.  Return **false**.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> Even when the `y` flag is used with a pattern, `^` always matches only at the beginning of *Input*, or (if *Multiline* is **true**) at the beginning of a line.

The production <span class="prod">*Assertion* <span class="geq">::</span> `$`</span> evaluates by returning an internal AssertionTester closure that takes a State argument x and performs the following steps when evaluated:

1.  Let *e* be *x*'s *endIndex*.
2.  If *e* is equal to *InputLength*, return **true**.
3.  If *Multiline* is **false**, return **false**.
4.  If the character *Input*\[*e*\] is one of *LineTerminator*, return **true**.
5.  Return **false**.

The production <span class="prod">*Assertion* <span class="geq">::</span> `\` `b`</span> evaluates by returning an internal AssertionTester closure that takes a State argument x and performs the following steps when evaluated:

1.  Let *e* be *x*'s *endIndex*.
2.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) IsWordChar(*e*–1) and let *a* be the Boolean result.
3.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) IsWordChar(*e*) and let *b* be the Boolean result.
4.  If *a* is **true** and *b* is **false**, return **true**.
5.  If *a* is **false** and *b* is **true**, return **true**.
6.  Return **false**.

The production <span class="prod">*Assertion* <span class="geq">::</span> `\` `B`</span> evaluates by returning an internal AssertionTester closure that takes a State argument x and performs the following steps when evaluated:

1.  Let *e* be *x*'s *endIndex*.
2.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) IsWordChar(*e*–1) and let *a* be the Boolean result.
3.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) IsWordChar(*e*) and let *b* be the Boolean result.
4.  If *a* is **true** and *b* is **false**, return **false**.
5.  If *a* is **false** and *b* is **true**, return **false**.
6.  Return **true**.

The production <span class="prod">*Assertion* <span class="geq">::</span> `(` `?` `=` *Disjunction* `)`</span> evaluates as follows:

1.  Evaluate *Disjunction* to obtain a Matcher *m*.
2.  Return an internal Matcher closure that takes two arguments, a State *x* and a Continuation *c*, and performs the following steps:
    1.  Let *d* be a Continuation that always returns its State argument as a successful MatchResult.
    2.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *m*(*x*, *d*) and let *r* be its result.
    3.  If *r* is **failure**, return **failure**.
    4.  Let *y* be *r*'s State.
    5.  Let *cap* be *y*'s *captures* [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type).
    6.  Let *xe* be *x*'s *endIndex*.
    7.  Let *z* be the State (*xe*, *cap*).
    8.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *c*(*z*) and return its result.

The production <span class="prod">*Assertion* <span class="geq">::</span> `(` `?` `!` *Disjunction* `)`</span> evaluates as follows:

1.  Evaluate *Disjunction* to obtain a Matcher *m*.
2.  Return an internal Matcher closure that takes two arguments, a State *x* and a Continuation *c*, and performs the following steps:
    1.  Let *d* be a Continuation that always returns its State argument as a successful MatchResult.
    2.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *m*(*x*, *d*) and let *r* be its result.
    3.  If *r* is not **failure**, return **failure**.
    4.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) *c*(*x*) and return its result.

<span id="sec-21.2.2.6.1" class="secnum">[21.2.2.6.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-runtime-semantics-iswordchar-abstract-operation "link to this section")</span> Runtime Semantics: IsWordChar Abstract Operation
===============================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

1.  If *e* is –1 or *e* is *InputLength*, return **false**.
2.  Let *c* be the character *Input*\[*e*\].
3.  If *c* is one of the sixty-three characters below, return **true**.
