3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*key*).
4.  If *receiver* is not present, then
    1.  Let *receiver* be *target*.

5.  Return *target.*\[\[Set\]\](*key*, *V*, *receiver*).

The `length` property of the `set` function is **3**.

<span id="sec-26.1.14" class="secnum">[26.1.14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-reflect.setprototypeof "link to this section")</span> Reflect.setPrototypeOf ( target, proto )
========================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the `setPrototypeOf` function is called with arguments <span style="font-family: Times New
      Roman">*target* and *propertyKey*</span>, the following steps are taken:

1.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*target*) is not Object, throw a **TypeError** exception.
2.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*proto*) is not Object and *proto* is not **null**, throw a **TypeError** exception
3.  Return *target.*\[\[SetPrototypeOf\]\](*proto*).

<span id="sec-26.2" class="secnum">[26.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-objects "link to this section")</span> Proxy Objects
==============================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-26.2.1" class="secnum">[26.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-constructor "link to this section")</span> The Proxy Constructor
==============================================================================================================================================================================

The Proxy constructor is the %Proxy% intrinsic object and the initial value of the `Proxy` property of the global object. When called as a constructor it creates and initializes a new proxy exotic object. `Proxy` is not intended to be called as a function and will throw an exception when called in that manner.

<span id="sec-26.2.1.1" class="secnum">[26.2.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-target-handler "link to this section")</span> Proxy ( target, handler )
=========================================================================================================================================================================================

When `Proxy` is called with arguments target and handler performs the following steps:

1.  If NewTarget is **undefined**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
2.  Return [ProxyCreate](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxycreate)(*target*, *handler*).

<span id="sec-26.2.2" class="secnum">[26.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-proxy-constructor "link to this section")</span> Properties of the Proxy Constructor
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of the `Proxy` constructor is the intrinsic object %FunctionPrototype% ([19.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-function-prototype-object)).

The `Proxy` constructor does not have a `prototype` property because proxy exotic objects do not have a \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) that requires initialization.

Besides the `length` property (whose value is **2**), the `Proxy` constructor has the following properties:

<span id="sec-26.2.2.1" class="secnum">[26.2.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy.revocable "link to this section")</span> Proxy.revocable ( target, handler )
==============================================================================================================================================================================================

The `Proxy.revocable` function is used to create a revocable Proxy object. When `Proxy.revocable` is called with arguments target and handler the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *p* be [ProxyCreate](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxycreate)(*target*, *handler*).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*p*).
3.  Let *revoker* be a new built-in function object as defined in [26.2.2.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-revocation-functions).
4.  Set the \[\[RevocableProxy\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *revoker* to *p*.
5.  Let *result* be [ObjectCreate](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-objectcreate)(%ObjectPrototype%).
6.  Perform [CreateDataProperty](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createdataproperty)(*result*, `"proxy"`, *p*).
7.  Perform [CreateDataProperty](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createdataproperty)(*result*, `"revoke"`, *revoker*).
8.  Return *result*.

<span id="sec-26.2.2.1.1" class="secnum">[26.2.2.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-proxy-revocation-functions "link to this section")</span> Proxy Revocation Functions
====================================================================================================================================================================================================

A Proxy revocation function is an anonymous function that has the ability to invalidate a specific Proxy object.

Each Proxy revocation function has a \[\[RevocableProxy\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

When a Proxy revocation function, F, is called the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *p* be the value of *F*’s \[\[RevocableProxy\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).
2.  If *p* is **null**, return **undefined**.
3.  Set the value of *F*’s \[\[RevocableProxy\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) to **null**.
4.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *p* is a Proxy object.
5.  Set the \[\[ProxyTarget\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *p* to **null**.
6.  Set the \[\[ProxyHandler\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of *p* to **null**.
7.  Return **undefined**.

<span id="sec-26.3" class="secnum">[26.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-module-namespace-objects "link to this section")</span> Module Namespace Objects
====================================================================================================================================================================================

A Module Namespace Object is a module namespace exotic object that provides runtime property-based access to a module’s exported bindings. There is no constructor function for Module Namespace Objects. Instead, such an object is created for each module that is imported by an *ImportDeclaration* that includes a *NameSpaceImport* (See [15.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-imports)).

In addition to the properties specified in [9.4.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-module-namespace-exotic-objects) each Module Namespace Object has the own following properties:

<span id="sec-26.3.1" class="secnum">[26.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-@@tostringtag "link to this section")</span> @@toStringTag
==================================================================================================================================================================

The initial value of the @@toStringTag property is the string value `"Module"`.

This property has the attributes { \[\[Writable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Enumerable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Configurable\]\]: <span class="value">true</span> }.

<span id="sec-26.3.2" class="secnum">[26.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-@@iterator "link to this section")</span> \[ @@iterator \] ( )
======================================================================================================================================================================

When the @@iterator method is called with no arguments following steps are taken:

1.  Let *N* be the **this** value.
2.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*N*) is not Object, throw a **TypeError** exception.
3.  Return *N*.\[\[Enumerate\]\]().

The value of the `name` property of this function is `"[Symbol.iterator]"`.

<span id="sec-B" class="secnum">[Annex B](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-ecmascript-features-for-web-browsers "link to this section")</span> <span class="section-status">(normative)</span> Additional ECMAScript Features for Web Browsers
==================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The ECMAScript language syntax and semantics defined in this annex are required when the ECMAScript host is a web browser. The content of this annex is normative but optional if the ECMAScript host is not a web browser.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> This annex describes various legacy features and other characteristics of web browser based ECMAScript implementations. All of the language features and behaviours specified in this annex have one or more undesirable characteristics and in the absence of legacy usage would be removed from this specification. However, the usage of these features by large numbers of existing web pages means that web browsers must continue to support them. The specifications in this annex defined the requirements for interoperable implementations of these legacy features.

These features are not considered part of the core ECMAScript language. Programmers should not use or assume the existence of these features and behaviours when writing new ECMAScript code. ECMAScript implementations are discouraged from implementing these features unless the implementation is part of a web browser or is required to run the same legacy ECMAScript code that web browsers encounter.

<span id="sec-B.1" class="secnum">[B.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-syntax "link to this section")</span> Additional Syntax
====================================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-B.1.1" class="secnum">[B.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-syntax-numeric-literals "link to this section")</span> Numeric Literals
========================================================================================================================================================================================

The syntax and semantics of [11.8.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-literals-numeric-literals) is extended as follows except that this extension is not allowed for [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code):

Syntax
------

*NumericLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span>

*DecimalLiteral*

*BinaryIntegerLiteral*

*OctalIntegerLiteral*

*HexIntegerLiteral*

*LegacyOctalIntegerLiteral*

*LegacyOctalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span>

`0` *OctalDigit*

*LegacyOctalIntegerLiteral* *OctalDigit*

*DecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span>

`0`

*NonZeroDigit* *DecimalDigits*<sub>opt</sub>

*NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral*

*NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span>

`0` *NonOctalDigit*

*LegacyOctalLikeDecimalIntegerLiteral* *NonOctalDigit*

*NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral* *DecimalDigit*

*LegacyOctalLikeDecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span>

`0` *OctalDigit*

*LegacyOctalLikeDecimalIntegerLiteral* *OctalDigit*

*NonOctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> <span class="grhsmod">one of</span>

`8` `9`

<span class="marker">B.1.1.1 </span>**Static Semantics**

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*LegacyOctalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `0` *OctalDigit*</span> is the MV of *OctalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*LegacyOctalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *LegacyOctalIntegerLiteral* *OctalDigit*</span> is (the MV of *LegacyOctalIntegerLiteral* times 8) plus the MV of *OctalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*DecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral*</span> is the MV of *NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `0` *NonOctalDigit*</span> is the MV of *NonOctalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *LegacyOctalLikeDecimalIntegerLiteral* *NonOctalDigit*</span> is (the MV of *LegacyOctalLikeDecimalIntegerLiteral* times 10) plus the MV of *NonOctalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral* *DecimalDigit*</span> is (the MV of *NonOctalDecimalIntegerLiteral* times 10) plus the MV of *DecimalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*LegacyOctalLikeDecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> `0` *OctalDigit*</span> is the MV of *OctalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*LegacyOctalLikeDecimalIntegerLiteral* <span class="geq">::</span> *LegacyOctalLikeDecimalIntegerLiteral* *OctalDigit*</span> is (the MV of *LegacyOctalLikeDecimalIntegerLiteral* times 10) plus the MV of *OctalDigit*.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*NonOctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `8`</span> is 8.

-   The MV of <span class="prod">*NonOctalDigit* <span class="geq">::</span> `9`</span> is 9.

<span id="sec-B.1.2" class="secnum">[B.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-syntax-string-literals "link to this section")</span> String Literals
======================================================================================================================================================================================

The syntax and semantics of [11.8.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-literals-string-literals) is extended as follows except that this extension is not allowed for [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code):

Syntax
------

*EscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span>

*CharacterEscapeSequence*

*LegacyOctalEscapeSequence*

*HexEscapeSequence*

*UnicodeEscapeSequence*

*LegacyOctalEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span>

*OctalDigit* <span class="grhsannot">\[lookahead ∉ *OctalDigit*\]</span>

*ZeroToThree* *OctalDigit* <span class="grhsannot">\[lookahead ∉ *OctalDigit*\]</span>

*FourToSeven* *OctalDigit*

*ZeroToThree* *OctalDigit* *OctalDigit*

*ZeroToThree* <span class="geq">::</span> <span class="grhsmod">one of</span>

`0` `1` `2` `3`

*FourToSeven* <span class="geq">::</span> <span class="grhsmod">one of</span>

`4` `5` `6` `7`

This definition of *EscapeSequence* is not used in strict mode or when parsing *TemplateCharacter* ([11.8.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-template-literal-lexical-components)).

<span class="marker">B.1.2.1 </span>**Static Semantics**

-   The SV of <span class="prod">*EscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *LegacyOctalEscapeSequence*</span> is the SV of the *LegacyOctalEscapeSequence*.
-   The SV of <span class="prod">*LegacyOctalEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *OctalDigit*</span> is the code unit whose value is the MV of the *OctalDigit*.
-   The SV of <span class="prod">*LegacyOctalEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *ZeroToThree* *OctalDigit*</span> is the code unit whose value is (8 times the MV of the *ZeroToThree*) plus the MV of the *OctalDigit*.
-   The SV of <span class="prod">*LegacyOctalEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *FourToSeven* *OctalDigit*</span> is the code unit whose value is (8 times the MV of the *FourToSeven*) plus the MV of the *OctalDigit*.
-   The SV of <span class="prod">*LegacyOctalEscapeSequence* <span class="geq">::</span> *ZeroToThree* *OctalDigit* *OctalDigit*</span> is the code unit whose value is (64 (that is, 8<sup>2</sup>) times the MV of the *ZeroToThree*) plus (8 times the MV of the first *OctalDigit*) plus the MV of the second *OctalDigit*.
-   The MV of <span class="prod">*ZeroToThree* <span class="geq">::</span> `0`</span> is 0.
-   The MV of <span class="prod">*ZeroToThree* <span class="geq">::</span> `1`</span> is 1.
-   The MV of <span class="prod">*ZeroToThree* <span class="geq">::</span> `2`</span> is 2.
-   The MV of <span class="prod">*ZeroToThree* <span class="geq">::</span> `3`</span> is 3.
-   The MV of <span class="prod">*FourToSeven* <span class="geq">::</span> `4`</span> is 4.
-   The MV of <span class="prod">*FourToSeven* <span class="geq">::</span> `5`</span> is 5.
-   The MV of <span class="prod">*FourToSeven* <span class="geq">::</span> `6`</span> is 6.
-   The MV of <span class="prod">*FourToSeven* <span class="geq">::</span> `7`</span> is 7.

<span class="marker">B.1.4.1 </span>**Pattern Semantics**

The semantics of [21.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-pattern-semantics) is extended as follows:

Within [21.2.2.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-term) reference to “<span class="prod">*Atom* <span class="geq">::</span> `(` *Disjunction* `)`</span> ” are to be interpreted as meaning “<span class="prod">*Atom* <span class="geq">::</span> `(` *Disjunction* `)`</span> ” or “<span class="prod">*AtomNoBrace* <span class="geq">::</span> `(` *Disjunction* `)`</span> ”.

Term ([21.2.2.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-term)) includes the following additional evaluation rule:

The production <span class="prod">*Term* <span class="geq">::</span> *QuantifiableAssertion* *Quantifier*</span> evaluates the same as the production <span class="prod">*Term* <span class="geq">::</span> *Atom* *Quantifier*</span> but with *QuantifiableAssertion* substituted for <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*Atom*.</span>

Atom ([21.2.2.8](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-atom)) evaluation rules for the *Atom* productions except for <span class="prod">*Atom* <span class="geq">::</span> *PatternCharacter*</span> are also used for the *AtomNoBrace* productions, but with *AtomNoBrace* substituted for <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*Atom*.</span> The following evaluation rule is also added:

The production <span class="prod">*AtomNoBrace* <span class="geq">::</span> *PatternCharacterNoBrace*</span> evaluates as follows:

1.  Let *ch* be the character represented by *PatternCharacterNoBrace*.
2.  Let *A* be a one-element CharSet containing the character *ch*.
3.  [Call](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-call) CharacterSetMatcher(*A*, **false**) and return its Matcher result.

CharacterEscape ([21.2.2.10](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-characterescape)) includes the following additional evaluation rule:

The production <span class="prod">*CharacterEscape* <span class="geq">::</span> *LegacyOctalEscapeSequence*</span> evaluates by evaluating the SV of the *LegacyOctalEscapeSequence* ([see B.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-syntax-string-literals)) and returning its character result.

ClassAtom ([21.2.2.17](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-classatom)) includes the following additional evaluation rules:

The production <span class="prod">*ClassAtomInRange* <span class="geq">::</span> `-`</span> evaluates by returning the CharSet containing the one character `-`.

The production <span class="prod">*ClassAtomInRange* <span class="geq">::</span> *ClassAtomNoDashInRange*</span> evaluates by evaluating *ClassAtomNoDashInRange* to obtain a CharSet and returning that CharSet.

ClassAtomNoDash ([21.2.2.18](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-classatomnodash)) includes the following additional evaluation rules:

The production <span class="prod">*ClassAtomNoDashInRange* <span class="geq">::</span> *SourceCharacter* <span class="grhsmod">but not one of</span> `\` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> `]` <span class="grhsmod">or</span> `-`</span> evaluates by returning a one-element CharSet containing the character represented by *SourceCharacter*.

The production <span class="prod">*ClassAtomNoDashInRange* <span class="geq">::</span> `\` *ClassEscape*</span> but only if…, evaluates by evaluating *ClassEscape* to obtain a CharSet and returning that CharSet.

The production <span class="prod">*ClassAtomNoDashInRange* <span class="geq">::</span> `\` *IdentityEscape*</span> evaluates by returning the character represented by *IdentityEscape*.

<span id="sec-B.2" class="secnum">[B.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-built-in-properties "link to this section")</span> Additional Built-in Properties
==============================================================================================================================================================================================

When the ECMAScript host is a web browser the following additional properties of the standard built-in objects are defined.

<span id="sec-B.2.1" class="secnum">[B.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-properties-of-the-global-object "link to this section")</span> Additional Properties of the Global Object
==========================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The entries in [Table 60](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#table-60) are added to [Table 7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#table-7).

<span id="table-60">Table 60</span> — Additional Well-known Intrinsic Objects
| Intrinsic Name | Global Name | ECMAScript Language Association                                                                                |
|----------------|-------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| %escape%       | `escape`    | The `escape` function ([B.2.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-escape-string))     |
| %unescape%     | `unescape`  | The `unescape` function ([B.2.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-unescape-string)) |

<span id="sec-B.2.1.1" class="secnum">[B.2.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-escape-string "link to this section")</span> escape (string)
======================================================================================================================================================================

The `escape` function is a property of the global object. It computes a new version of a String value in which certain code units have been replaced by a hexadecimal escape sequence.

For those code units being replaced whose value is `0x00FF` or less, a two-digit escape sequence of the form `%`*xx* is used. For those characters being replaced whose code unit value is greater than `0x00FF`, a four-digit escape sequence of the form `%u`*xxxx* is used.

The `escape` function is the %escape% intrinsic object. When the `escape` function is called with one argument string, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *string* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*string*).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*string*).
3.  Let *length* be the number of code units in *string*.
4.  Let *R* be the empty string.
5.  Let *k* be 0.
6.  Repeat, while *k* &lt; *length*,
    1.  Let *char* be the code unit (represented as a 16-bit unsigned integer) at index *k* within *string*.
    2.  If *char* is one of the code units in **"`ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz0123456789@*_+-./`"**, then
        1.  Let *S* be a String containing the single code unit *char*.

    3.  Else if *char* ≥ 256, then
        1.  Let *S* be a String containing six code units **"`%u`***wxyz***"** where *wxyz* are the code units of the four hexadecimal digits encoding the value of *char*.

    4.  Else, *char* &lt; 256
        1.  Let *S* be a String containing three code units **"`%`***xy***"** where *xy* are the code units of two hexadecimal digits encoding the value of *char*.

    5.  Let *R* be a new String value computed by concatenating the previous value of *R* and *S*.
    6.  Increase *k* by 1.

7.  Return *R*.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The encoding is partly based on the encoding described in RFC 1738, but the entire encoding specified in this standard is described above without regard to the contents of RFC 1738. This encoding does not reflect changes to RFC 1738 made by RFC 3986.

<span id="sec-B.2.1.2" class="secnum">[B.2.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-unescape-string "link to this section")</span> unescape (string)
==========================================================================================================================================================================

The `unescape` function is a property of the global object. It computes a new version of a String value in which each escape sequence of the sort that might be introduced by the `escape` function is replaced with the code unit that it represents.

The `unescape` function is the %unescape% intrinsic object. When the `unescape` function is called with one argument string, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *string* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*string*).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*string*).
3.  Let *length* be the number of code units in *string*.
4.  Let *R* be the empty String.
5.  Let *k* be 0.
6.  Repeat, while *k* ≠ *length*
    1.  Let *c* be the code unit at index *k* within *string*.
    2.  If *c* is `%`,
        1.  If *k* ≤ *length*−6 and the code unit at index *k*+1 within *string* is `u` and the four code units at indices *k*+2, *k*+3, *k*+4, and *k*+5 within *string* are all hexadecimal digits, then
            1.  Let *c* be the code unit whose value is the integer represented by the four hexadecimal digits at indices *k*+2, *k*+3, *k*+4, and *k*+5 within *string*.
            2.  Increase *k* by 5.

        2.  Else if *k* ≤ *length*−3 and the two code units at indices *k*+1 and *k*+2 within *string* are both hexadecimal digits, then
            1.  Let *c* be the code unit whose value is the integer represented by two zeroes plus the two hexadecimal digits at indices *k*+1 and *k*+2 within *string*.
            2.  Increase *k* by 2.

    3.  Let *R* be a new String value computed by concatenating the previous value of *R* and *c*.
    4.  Increase *k* by 1.

7.  Return *R*.

<span id="sec-B.2.2" class="secnum">[B.2.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-properties-of-the-object.prototype-object "link to this section")</span> Additional Properties of the Object.prototype Object
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-B.2.2.1" class="secnum">[B.2.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.prototype.__proto__ "link to this section")</span> Object.prototype.\_\_proto\_\_
==================================================================================================================================================================================================

Object.prototype.\_\_proto\_\_ is an accessor property with attributes { \[\[Enumerable\]\]: <span class="value">false</span>, \[\[Configurable\]\]: <span class="value">true</span> }. The \[\[Get\]\] and \[\[Set\]\] attributes are defined as follows

<span id="sec-B.2.2.1.1" class="secnum">[B.2.2.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-get-object.prototype.__proto__ "link to this section")</span> get Object.prototype.\_\_proto\_\_
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of the \[\[Get\]\] attribute is a built-in function that requires no arguments. It performs the following steps:

1.  Let *O* be [ToObject](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-toobject)(**this** value).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*O*).
3.  Return *O*.\[\[GetPrototypeOf\]\]().

<span id="sec-B.2.2.1.2" class="secnum">[B.2.2.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-set-object.prototype.__proto__ "link to this section")</span> set Object.prototype.\_\_proto\_\_
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================

The value of the \[\[Set\]\] attribute is a built-in function that takes an argument proto. It performs the following steps:

1.  Let *O* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(**this** value)*.*
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*O*).
3.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*proto*) is neither Object nor Null, return **undefined**.
4.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*O*) is not Object, return **undefined**.
5.  Let *status* be *O*.\[\[SetPrototypeOf\]\](*proto*).
6.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*status*).
7.  If *status* is **false**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
8.  Return **undefined**.

<span id="sec-B.2.3" class="secnum">[B.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-properties-of-the-string.prototype-object "link to this section")</span> Additional Properties of the String.prototype Object
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-B.2.3.1" class="secnum">[B.2.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.substr "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.substr (start, length)
========================================================================================================================================================================================================

The `substr` method takes two arguments, start and length, and returns a substring of the result of converting the **this** object to a String, starting from index start and running for length code units (or through the end of the String if length is **undefined**). If start is negative, it is treated as <span style="font-family: Times New
        Roman">(*sourceLength*+*start*)</span> where sourceLength is the length of the String. The result is a String value, not a String object. The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(**this** value).
2.  Let *S* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*O*).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*S*).
4.  Let *intStart* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*start*).
5.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*intStart*).
6.  If *length* is **undefined**, let *end* be **+∞**; otherwise let *end* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*length*).
7.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*end*).
8.  Let *size* be the number of code units in *S*.
9.  If *intStart* &lt; 0, let *intStart* be max(*size* + *intStart*,0).
10. Let *resultLength* be min(max(*end*,0), *size* – *intStart*).
11. If *resultLength* ≤ 0, return the empty String `""`.
12. Return a String containing *resultLength* consecutive code units from *S* beginning with the code unit at index *intStart*.

The `length` property of the `substr` method is **2**.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `substr` function is intentionally generic; it does not require that its **this** value be a String object. Therefore it can be transferred to other kinds of objects for use as a method.

<span id="sec-B.2.3.2" class="secnum">[B.2.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.anchor "link to this section")</span> String.prototype.anchor ( name )
=================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the **anchor** method is called with argument name, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *S* be the **this** value.
2.  Return [CreateHTML](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createhtml)(*S*, `"a"`, `"name"`, *name*).

<span id="sec-B.2.3.2.1" class="secnum">[B.2.3.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createhtml "link to this section")</span> Runtime Semantics: CreateHTML ( string, tag, attribute, value )
=======================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The abstract operation <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">CreateHTML</span> is called with arguments string, tag, attribute, and <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*value*.</span> The arguments tag and attribute must be string values. The following steps are taken:

1.  Let *str* be [RequireObjectCoercible](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-requireobjectcoercible)(*string*).
2.  Let *S* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*str*).
3.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*S*).
4.  Let *p1* be the string value that is the concatenation of `"<"` and *tag*.
5.  If *attribute* is not the empty String, then
    1.  Let *V* be [ToString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tostring)(*value*).
    2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*V*).
    3.  Let *escapedV* be the string value that is the same as *V* except that each occurrence of the code unit 0x0022 (QUOTATION MARK) in *V* has been replaced with the six code unit sequence `"&quot;"`.
    4.  Let *p1* be the string value that is the concatenation of the following string values:
        -   The string value of *p1*
        -   Code unit 0x0020 (SPACE)
        -   The string value of *attribute*
        -   Code unit 0x003D (EQUALS SIGN)
        -   Code unit 0x0022 (QUOTATION MARK)
        -   The string value of *escapedV*
        -   Code unit 0x0022 (QUOTATION MARK)

6.  Let *p2* be the string value that is the concatenation of *p1* and `">"`.
7.  Let *p3* be the string value that is the concatenation of *p2* and *S*.
8.  Let *p4* be the string value that is the concatenation of *p3*, `"</"`, *tag*, and `">"`.
9.  Return *p4*.
