<span id="sec-B.2.4" class="secnum">[B.2.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-properties-of-the-date.prototype-object "link to this section")</span> Additional Properties of the Date.prototype Object
==========================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-B.2.4.1" class="secnum">[B.2.4.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.prototype.getyear "link to this section")</span> Date.prototype.getYear ( )
==========================================================================================================================================================================================

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `getFullYear` method is preferred for nearly all purposes, because it avoids the “year 2000 problem.”

When the **getYear** method is called with no arguments, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *t* be [this time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-date-prototype-object).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*t*).
3.  If *t* is **NaN**, return **NaN**.
4.  Return [YearFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-year-number)([LocalTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-localtime)(*t*)) − 1900.

<span id="sec-B.2.4.2" class="secnum">[B.2.4.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.prototype.setyear "link to this section")</span> Date.prototype.setYear (year)
=============================================================================================================================================================================================

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `setFullYear` method is preferred for nearly all purposes, because it avoids the “year 2000 problem.”

When the **setYear** method is called with one argument year, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *t* be [this time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-date-prototype-object).
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*t*).
3.  If *t* is **NaN**, let *t* be **+0**; otherwise, let *t* be [LocalTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-localtime)(*t*).
4.  Let *y* be [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber)(*year*).
5.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*y*).
6.  If *y* is **NaN**, set the \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of this Date object to **NaN** and return **NaN**.
7.  If *y* is not **NaN** and 0 ≤ [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*y*) ≤ 99, let *yyyy* be [ToInteger](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tointeger)(*y*) + 1900.
8.  Else, let *yyyy* be *y*.
9.  Let *d* be [MakeDay](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-makeday)(*yyyy*, [MonthFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-month-number)(*t*), [DateFromTime](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-number)(*t*)).
10. Let *date* be [UTC](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-utc-t)([MakeDate](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-makedate)(*d*, [TimeWithinDay](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-day-number-and-time-within-day)(*t*))).
11. Set the \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of this Date object to [TimeClip](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-timeclip)(*date*).
12. Return the value of the \[\[DateValue\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of this Date object.

<span id="sec-B.2.4.3" class="secnum">[B.2.4.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.prototype.togmtstring "link to this section")</span> Date.prototype.toGMTString ( )
==================================================================================================================================================================================================

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The property `toUTCString` is preferred. The `toGMTString` property is provided principally for compatibility with old code. It is recommended that the `toUTCString` property be used in new ECMAScript code.

The function object that is the initial value of `Date.prototype.toGMTString` is the same function object that is the initial value of `Date.prototype.toUTCString`.

<span id="sec-B.2.5" class="secnum">[B.2.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-properties-of-the-regexp.prototype-object "link to this section")</span> Additional Properties of the RegExp.prototype Object
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-B.2.5.1" class="secnum">[B.2.5.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexp.prototype.compile "link to this section")</span> RegExp.prototype.compile (pattern, flags )
============================================================================================================================================================================================================

When the **compile** method is called with arguments *pattern* and *flags*, the following steps are taken:

1.  Let *O* be the **this** value.
2.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*O*) is not Object or [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*O*) is Object and *O* does not have a \[\[RegExpMatcher\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots), then
    1.  Throw a **TypeError** exception.

3.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*pattern*) is Object and *pattern* has a \[\[RegExpMatcher\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots), then
    1.  If *flags* is not **undefined**, throw a **TypeError** exception.
    2.  Let *P* be the value of *pattern’s* \[\[OriginalSource\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).
    3.  Let *F* be the value of *pattern’s* \[\[OriginalFlags\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots).

4.  Else,
    1.  Let *P* be *pattern*.
    2.  Let *F* be *flags*.

5.  Return [RegExpInitialize](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexpinitialize)(*O,* *P*, *F*).

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The `compile` method completely reinitializes the **this** object RegExp with a new pattern and flags. An implementation may interpret use of this method as an assertion that the resulting RegExp object will be used multiple times and hence is a candidate for extra optimization.

<span id="sec-B.3" class="secnum">[B.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-other-additional-features "link to this section")</span> Other Additional Features
====================================================================================================================================================================================

<span id="sec-B.3.1" class="secnum">[B.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-__proto__-property-names-in-object-initializers "link to this section")</span> \_\_proto\_\_ Property Names in Object Initializers
========================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The following Early Error rule is added to those in [12.2.5.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-initializer-static-semantics-early-errors):

*ObjectLiteral* <span class="geq">:</span> `{` *PropertyDefinitionList* `}`

and

*ObjectLiteral* <span class="geq">:</span> `{` *PropertyDefinitionList* `,` `}`

-   It is a Syntax Error if <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">PropertyNameList</span> of *PropertyDefinitionList* contains any duplicate entries for `"__proto__"` and at least two of those entries were obtained from productions of the form <span class="prod">*PropertyDefinition* <span class="geq">:</span> *PropertyName* `:` *AssignmentExpression*</span> .

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The [List](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-list-and-record-specification-type) returned by PropertyNameList does not include string literal property names defined as using a *ComputedPropertyName.*

In [12.2.5.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-initializer-runtime-semantics-propertydefinitionevaluation) the PropertyDefinitionEvaluation algorithm for the production
<span class="prod">*PropertyDefinition* <span class="geq">:</span> *PropertyName* `:` *AssignmentExpression*</span>
is replaced with the following definition:

*PropertyDefinition* <span class="geq">:</span> *PropertyName* `:` *AssignmentExpression*

1.  Let *propKey* be the result of evaluating *PropertyName*.
2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*propKey*).
3.  Let *exprValueRef* be the result of evaluating *AssignmentExpression*.
4.  Let *propValue* be [GetValue](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-getvalue)(*exprValueRef*).
5.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*propValue*).
6.  If *propKey* is the string value `"__proto__"` and if IsComputedPropertyKey(*propKey*) is **false**, then
    1.  If [Type](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-data-types-and-values)(*propValue*) is either Object or Null, then
        1.  Return *object*.\[\[SetPrototypeOf\]\](*propValue*).

    2.  Return [NormalCompletion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-normalcompletion)(<span style="font-family:
                        sans-serif">empty</span>).

7.  If [IsAnonymousFunctionDefinition](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-isanonymousfunctiondefinition)(*AssignmentExpression)* is **true**, then
    1.  Let *hasNameProperty* be [HasOwnProperty](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-hasownproperty)(*propValue*, `"name"`).
    2.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*hasNameProperty*).
    3.  If *hasNameProperty* is **false**, perform [SetFunctionName](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-setfunctionname)(*propValue*, *propKey*).

8.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *enumerable* is **true**.
9.  Return [CreateDataPropertyOrThrow](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createdatapropertyorthrow)(*object*, *propKey*, *propValue*).

<span id="sec-B.3.2" class="secnum">[B.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-labelled-function-declarations "link to this section")</span> Labelled Function Declarations
==================================================================================================================================================================================================

Prior to ECMAScript 2015, the specification of *LabelledStatement* did not allow for the association of a statement label with a *FunctionDeclaration*. However, a labelled *FunctionDeclaration* was an allowable extension for non-[strict code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code) and most browser-hosted ECMAScript implementations supported that extension. In ECMAScript 2015, the grammar productions for *LabelledStatement* permits use of *FunctionDeclaration* as a *LabelledItem* but [13.12.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-labelled-statements-static-semantics-early-errors) includes an Early Error rule that produces a Syntax Error if that occurs. For web browser compatibility, that rule is modified with the addition of the underlined text:

*LabelledItem* <span class="geq">:</span> *FunctionDeclaration*

-   It is a Syntax Error if any strict mode source code matches this rule.

<span id="sec-B.3.3" class="secnum">[B.3.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-block-level-function-declarations-web-legacy-compatibility-semantics "link to this section")</span> Block-Level Function Declarations Web Legacy Compatibility Semantics
==============================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

Prior to ECMAScript 2015, the ECMAScript specification did not define the occurrence of a *FunctionDeclaration* as an element of a *Block* statement’s *StatementList*. However, support for that form of *FunctionDeclaration* was an allowable extension and most browser-hosted ECMAScript implementations permitted them. Unfortunately, the semantics of such declarations differ among those implementations. Because of these semantic differences, existing web ECMAScript code that uses *Block* level function declarations is only portable among browser implementation if the usage only depends upon the semantic intersection of all of the browser implementations for such declarations. The following are the use cases that fall within that intersection semantics:

1.  A function is declared and only referenced within a single block
    -   A *FunctionDeclaration* whose *BindingIdentifier* is the name f occurs exactly once within the function code of an enclosing function g and that declaration is nested within a *Block*.

    -   No other declaration of f that is not a `var` declaration occurs within the function code of g

    -   All occurrences of f as an *IdentifierReference* are within the *StatementList* of the *Block* containing the declaration of f.

2.  A function is declared and possibly used within a single *Block* but also referenced by an inner function definition that is not contained within that same *Block*.
    -   A *FunctionDeclaration* whose *BindingIdentifier* is the name f occurs exactly once within the function code of an enclosing function g and that declaration is nested within a *Block*.

    -   No other declaration of f that is not a `var` declaration occurs within the function code of g

    -   There may be occurrences of f as an *IdentifierReference* within the *StatementList* of the *Block* containing the declaration of f.

    -   There is at least one occurrence of f as an *IdentifierReference* within the function code of g that lexically follows the *Block* containing the declaration of f.

3.  A function is declared and possibly used within a single block but also referenced within subsequent blocks.
    -   A *FunctionDeclaration* whose *BindingIdentifier* is the name f occurs exactly once within the function code of an enclosing function g and that declaration is nested within a *Block*.

    -   No other declaration of f that is not a `var` declaration occurs within the function code of g

    -   There may be occurrences of f as an *IdentifierReference* within the *StatementList* of the *Block* containing the declaration of f.

    -   There is at least one occurrence of f as an *IdentifierReference* within another function h that is nested within g and no other declaration of f shadows the references to f from within h.

    -   All invocations of *h* occur after the declaration of *f* has been evaluated.

The first use case is interoperable with the semantics of *Block* level function declarations provided by ECMAScript 2015. Any pre-existing ECMAScript code that employees that use case will operate using the Block level function declarations semantics defined by clauses 9, 13, and 14 of this specification.

ECMAScript 2015 interoperability for the second and third use cases requires the following extensions to the [clause 9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ordinary-and-exotic-objects-behaviours) and [clause 14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ecmascript-language-functions-and-classes) semantics. During [FunctionDeclarationInstantiation](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-functiondeclarationinstantiation) ([9.2.12](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-functiondeclarationinstantiation)) the following steps are performed in place of step 29:

1.  If *strict* is **false**, then
    1.  For each *FunctionDeclaration* *f* in *varDeclarations* that is directly contained in the *StatementList* of a *Block*, *CaseClause*, or *DefaultClause,*
        1.  Let *F* be StringValue of the *BindingIdentifier* of *FunctionDeclaration* *f*.
        2.  If replacing the *FunctionDeclaration* *f* with a *VariableStatement* that has *F* as a *BindingIdentifier* would not produce any Early Errors for *func* and *F* is not an element of BoundNames of *argumentsList*, then
            1.  <span style="font-family: sans-serif">NOTE A var binding for</span> *F* <span style="font-family:
                                        sans-serif">is only instantiated here if it is neither a VarDeclaredName, the name of a formal parameter, or another</span> *FunctionDeclarations*.
            2.  If *instantiatedVarNames* does not contain *F*, then
                1.  Let *status* be *varEnvRec.*CreateMutableBinding(*F*).
                2.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *status* is never an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type).
                3.  Perform *varEnvRec.*InitializeBinding(*F*, **undefined**).
                4.  Append *F* to *instantiatedVarNames*.

            3.  When the *FunctionDeclaration* *f* is evaluated, perform the following steps in place of the *FunctionDeclaration* Evaluation algorithm provided in [14.1.20](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-function-definitions-runtime-semantics-evaluation):
                1.  Let *fenv* be [the running execution context](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-execution-contexts)’s [VariableEnvironment](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-execution-contexts).
                2.  Let *benv* be [the running execution context](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-execution-contexts)’s [LexicalEnvironment](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-execution-contexts).
                3.  Let *fobj* be *benv*.GetBindingValue(*F*, **false**).
                4.  [ReturnIfAbrupt](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-returnifabrupt)(*fobj*).
                5.  Let *status* be *fenv*.SetMutableBinding(*F*, *fobj*, **false**).
                6.  [Assert](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-algorithm-conventions): *status* is never an [abrupt completion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-completion-record-specification-type).
                7.  Return [NormalCompletion](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-normalcompletion)(<span style="font-family:
                                                sans-serif">empty</span>).

If an ECMAScript implementation has a mechanism for reporting diagnostic warning messages, a warning should be produced for each function whose function code contains a *FunctionDeclaration* for which steps 1.a.ii.1-3 will be performed.

<span id="sec-B.3.4" class="secnum">[B.3.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-functiondeclarations-in-ifstatement-statement-clauses "link to this section")</span> FunctionDeclarations in IfStatement Statement Clauses
================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

The following rules for *IfStatement* augment those in [13.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-if-statement):

*IfStatement*<sub>\[Yield,\\ Return\]</sub> <span class="geq">:</span>

`if` `(` *Expression*<sub>\[In,\\ ?Yield\]</sub> `)` *FunctionDeclaration*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub> `else` *Statement*<sub>\[?Yield,\\ ?Return\]</sub>

`if` `(` *Expression*<sub>\[In,\\ ?Yield\]</sub> `)` *Statement*<sub>\[?Yield,\\ ?Return\]</sub> `else` *FunctionDeclaration*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub>

`if` `(` *Expression*<sub>\[In,\\ ?Yield\]</sub> `)` *FunctionDeclaration*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub> `else` *FunctionDeclaration*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub>

`if` `(` *Expression*<sub>\[In,\\ ?Yield\]</sub> `)` *FunctionDeclaration*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub>

The above rules are only applied when parsing code that is not [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code). If any such code is match by one of these rules subsequent processing of that code takes places as if each matching occurrence of *FunctionDeclaration*<sub>\[?Yield\]</sub> was the sole *StatementListItem* of a *BlockStatement* occupying that position in the source code. The semantics of such a synthetic *BlockStatement* includes the web legacy compatibility semantics specified in [B.3.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-block-level-function-declarations-web-legacy-compatibility-semantics).

<span id="sec-B.3.5" class="secnum">[B.3.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-variablestatements-in-catch-blocks "link to this section")</span> VariableStatements in Catch blocks
==========================================================================================================================================================================================================

The content of [subclause 13.14.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-try-statement-static-semantics-early-errors) is replaced with the following:

*Catch* <span class="geq">:</span> `catch` `(` *CatchParameter* `)` *Block*

-   It is a Syntax Error if BoundNames <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">of *CatchParameter*</span> contains any duplicate elements.

-   It is a Syntax Error if any element of the BoundNames of *CatchParameter* also occurs in the LexicallyDeclaredNames of *Block*.

-   It is a Syntax Error if any element of the BoundNames of *CatchParameter* also occurs in the VarDeclaredNames of Block, unless that element is only bound by a VariableStatement or the VariableDeclarationList of a for statement, or the ForBinding of a for-in statement.

<span class="nh">NOTE</span> The *Block* of a *Catch* clause may contain `var` declarations that bind a name that is also bound by the *CatchParameter*. At runtime, such bindings are instantiated in the VariableDeclarationEnvironment. They do not shadow the same-named bindings introduced by the *CatchParameter* and hence the *Initializer* for such `var` declarations will assign to the corresponding catch parameter rather than the `var` binding. The relaxation of the normal static semantic rule does not apply to names only bound by for-of statements.

This modified behaviour also applies to `var` declarations introduced by direct evals contained within the *Block* of a *Catch* clause. This change is accomplished by modify the algorithm of [18.2.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-evaldeclarationinstantiation) as follows:

Step 6.d.ii.2.a.i is replaced by:

1.  If *thisEnvRec* is not the [Environment Record](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-environment-records) for a *Catch* clause, throw a **SyntaxError** exception.
2.  Else if *name* is *only bound by a VariableStatement* *or the VariableDeclarationList* *of a for statement, or the* *ForBinding* *of a for-in statement*, throw a **SyntaxError** exception.

<span id="sec-C" class="secnum">[Annex C](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-of-ecmascript "link to this section")</span> <span class="section-status">(informative)</span> The Strict Mode of ECMAScript
============================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

**The strict mode restriction and exceptions**

-   `implements`, `interface`, `let`, `package`, `private`, `protected`, `public`, `static`, and `yield` are reserved words within [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code). ([11.6.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-reserved-words)).

-   A conforming implementation, when processing [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code), may not extend the syntax of *NumericLiteral* ([11.8.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-literals-numeric-literals)) to include *LegacyOctalIntegerLiteral* as described in [B.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-syntax-numeric-literals).

-   A conforming implementation, when processing [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code), may not extend the syntax of *EscapeSequence* to include *LegacyOctalEscapeSequence* as described in [B.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additional-syntax-string-literals).

-   Assignment to an undeclared identifier or otherwise unresolvable reference does not create a property in the global object. When a simple assignment occurs within [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code), its *LeftHandSide* must not evaluate to an [unresolvable Reference](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-reference-specification-type). If it does a **ReferenceError** exception is thrown ([6.2.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-putvalue)). The *LeftHandSide* also may not be a reference to a data property with the attribute value {\[\[Writable\]\]:**false**}, to an accessor property with the attribute value {\[\[Set\]\]:**undefined**}, nor to a non-existent property of an object whose \[\[Extensible\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) has the value **false**. In these cases a `TypeError` exception is thrown ([12.14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-assignment-operators)).

-   The identifier `eval` or `arguments` may not appear as the *LeftHandSideExpression* of an Assignment operator ([12.14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-assignment-operators)) or of a *PostfixExpression* ([12.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-postfix-expressions)) or as the *UnaryExpression* operated upon by a Prefix Increment ([12.5.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-prefix-increment-operator)) or a Prefix Decrement ([12.5.8](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-prefix-decrement-operator)) operator.

-   Arguments objects for strict mode functions define non-configurable accessor properties named `"caller"` and `"callee"` which throw a **TypeError** exception on access ([9.2.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-addrestrictedfunctionproperties)).

-   Arguments objects for strict mode functions do not dynamically share their array indexed property values with the corresponding formal parameter bindings of their functions. ([9.4.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-arguments-exotic-objects)).

-   For strict mode functions, if an arguments object is created the binding of the local identifier `arguments` to the arguments object is immutable and hence may not be the target of an assignment expression. ([9.2.12](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-functiondeclarationinstantiation)).

-   It is a **SyntaxError** if the *IdentifierName* `eval` or the *IdentifierName* `arguments` occurs as a *BindingIdentifier* within [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code) ([12.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-identifiers-static-semantics-early-errors)).

-   Strict mode eval code cannot instantiate variables or functions in the variable environment of the caller to eval. Instead, a new variable environment is created and that environment is used for declaration binding instantiation for the eval code ([18.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-eval-x)).

-   If **this** is evaluated within [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code), then the **this** value is not coerced to an object. A **this** value of **null** or **undefined** is not converted to the global object and primitive values are not converted to wrapper objects. The **this** value passed via a function call (including calls made using `Function.prototype.apply` and `Function.prototype.call`) do not coerce the passed this value to an object ([9.2.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-ordinarycallbindthis), [19.2.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-function.prototype.apply), [19.2.3.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-function.prototype.call)).

-   When a `delete` operator occurs within [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code), a **SyntaxError** is thrown if its *UnaryExpression* is a direct reference to a variable, function argument, or function name ([12.5.4.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-delete-operator-static-semantics-early-errors)).

-   When a `delete` operator occurs within [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code), a **TypeError** is thrown if the property to be deleted has the attribute { \[\[Configurable\]\]:**false** } ([12.5.4.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-delete-operator-runtime-semantics-evaluation)).

-   Strict mode code may not include a *WithStatement*. The occurrence of a *WithStatement* in such a context is a **SyntaxError** ([13.10.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-with-statement-static-semantics-early-errors)).

-   It is a **SyntaxError** if a *TryStatement* with a *Catch* occurs within [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code) and the *Identifier* of the *Catch* production is `eval` or `arguments` ([13.14.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-try-statement-static-semantics-early-errors)).

-   It is a **SyntaxError** if the same *BindingIdentifier* appears more than once in the *FormalParameters* of a strict mode function. An attempt to create such a function using a `Function` or `Generator` constructor is a **SyntaxError** ([14.1.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-function-definitions-static-semantics-early-errors), [19.2.1.1.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createdynamicfunction)).

-   An implementation may not extend, beyond that defined in this specification, the meanings within strict mode functions of properties named `caller` or `arguments` of function instances. ECMAScript code may not create or modify properties with these names on function objects that correspond to strict mode functions ([16.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-forbidden-extensions)).

<span id="sec-D" class="secnum">[Annex D](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-corrections-and-clarifications-in-ecmascript-2015-with-possible-compatibility-impact "link to this section")</span> <span class="section-status">(informative)</span> Corrections and Clarifications in ECMAScript 2015 with Possible Compatibility Impact


[8.1.1.4.15](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-candeclareglobalvar)-[8.1.1.4.18](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-createglobalfunctionbinding) Edition 5 and [5.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-syntactic-and-lexical-grammars) used a property existence test to determine whether a global object property corresponding to a new global declaration already existed. ECMAScript 2015 uses an own property existence test. This corresponds to what has been most commonly implemented by web browsers.

[9.4.2.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-array-exotic-objects-defineownproperty-p-desc): The 5<sup>th</sup> Edition moved the capture of the current array length prior to the integer conversion of the array index or new length value. However, the captured length value could become invalid if the conversion process has the side-effect of changing the array length. ECMAScript 2015 specifies that the current array length must be captured after the possible occurrence of such side-effects.

[20.3.1.15](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-timeclip): Previous editions permitted the [TimeClip](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-timeclip) abstract operation to return either +0 or **−**0 as the representation of a 0 [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range). ECMAScript 2015 specifies that +0 always returned. This means that for ECMAScript 2015 the [time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-time-values-and-time-range) of a Date object is never observably **−**0 and methods that return time values never return **−**0.

[20.3.1.16](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-time-string-format): If a time zone offset is not present, the local time zone is used. Edition 5.1 incorrectly stated that a missing time zone should be interpreted as `"z"`.

[20.3.4.36](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.prototype.toisostring): If the year cannot be represented using the Date Time String Format specified in [20.3.1.16](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date-time-string-format) a RangeError exception is thrown. Previous editions did not specify the behaviour for that case.

[20.3.4.41](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.prototype.tostring): Previous editions did not specify the value returned by [Date.prototype.toString](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-date.prototype.tostring) when [this time value](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-date-prototype-object) is NaN. ECMAScript 2015 specifies the result to be the String value is `"Invalid Date".`

[21.2.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexp-pattern-flags), [21.2.3.2.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-escaperegexppattern): Any LineTerminator code points in the value of the `source` property of an RegExp instance must be expressed using an escape sequence. Edition 5.1 only required the escaping of `"/"`.

[21.2.5.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexp.prototype-@@match), [21.2.5.8](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexp.prototype-@@replace): In previous editions, the specifications for `String.prototype.match` and `String.prototype.replace` was incorrect for cases where the pattern argument was a RegExp value whose `global` is flag set. The previous specifications stated that for each attempt to match the pattern, if `lastIndex` did not change it should be incremented by 1. The correct behaviour is that `lastIndex` should be incremented by one only if the pattern matched the empty string.

[22.1.3.24](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-array.prototype.sort), [22.1.3.24.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-sortcompare): Previous editions did not specify how a **NaN** value returned by a comparefn was interpreted by `Array.prototype.sort`. ECMAScript 2015 specifies that such as value is treated as if +0 was returned from the comparefn. ECMAScript 2015 also specifies that [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber) is applied to the result returned by a <span style="font-family: Times New Roman">*comparefn*.</span> In previous editions, the effect of a comparefn result that is not a Number value was implementation dependent. In practice, implementations call [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber).

<span id="sec-E" class="secnum">[Annex E](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-additions-and-changes-that-introduce-incompatibilities-with-prior-editions "link to this section")</span> <span class="section-status">(informative)</span> Additions and Changes That Introduce Incompatibilities with Prior Editions


[7.1.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber-applied-to-the-string-type): In ECMAScript 2015, [ToNumber](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-tonumber) applied to a String value now recognizes and converts *BinaryIntegerLiteral* and *OctalIntegerLIteral* numeric strings. In previous editions such strings were converted to <span class="value">NaN</span>,

[6.2.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-reference-specification-type): In ECMAScript 2015, Function calls are not allowed to return a [Reference](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-reference-specification-type) value.

[11.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-names-and-keywords): In ECMAScript 2015, the valid code points for an *IdentifierName* are specified in terms of the Unicode properties “ID\_Start” and “ID\_Continue”. In previous editions, the valid *IdentifierName* or *Identifier* code points were specified by enumerating various Unicode code point categories.

[11.9.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-rules-of-automatic-semicolon-insertion): In ECMAScript 2015, Automatic Semicolon Insertion adds a semicolon at the end of a do-while statement if the semicolon is missing. This change aligns the specification with the actual behaviour of most existing implementations.

[12.2.5.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-initializer-static-semantics-early-errors): In ECMAScript 2015, it is no longer an early error to have duplicate property names in Object Initializers.

[12.14.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-assignment-operators-static-semantics-early-errors): In ECMAScript 2015, [strict mode code](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-strict-mode-code) containing an assignment to an immutable binding such as the function name of a *FunctionExpression* does not produce an early error. Instead it produces a runtime error.

[13.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-expression-statement): In ECMAScript 2015, a *StatementListItem* beginning with the token `let` followed by the token `[` is the start of a *LexicalDeclaration*. In previous editions such a sequence would be the start of an *ExpressionStatement*.

[13.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-iteration-statements): In ECMAScript 2015, if the `(` token of a for statement is immediately followed by the token sequence `let` `[` then the `let` is treated as the start of a *LexicalDeclaration*. In previous editions such a token sequence would be the start of an *Expression*.

[13.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-iteration-statements): In ECMAScript 2015, if the ( token of a for-in statement is immediately followed by the token sequence `let` `[` then the `let` is treated as the start of a *ForDeclaration*. In previous editions such a token sequence would be the start of an *LeftHandSideExpression*.

[13.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-iteration-statements): Prior to ECMAScript 2015, an initialization expression could appear as part of the *VariableDeclaration* that precedes the `in` keyword. The value of that expression was always discarded. In ECMAScript 2015, the *ForBind* in that same position does not allow the occurrence of such an initializer.

[13.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-iteration-statements): In ECMAScript 2015, the normal completion value of an *IterationStatement* is never the value **empty**. If the *Statement* part of an *IterationStatement* is not evaluated or if the final evaluation of the *Statement* part produces a normal completion whose value is **empty**, the completion value of the *IterationStatement* is <span class="value">undefined</span>.

[13.10.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-with-statement-runtime-semantics-evaluation): In ECMAScript 2015, the normal completion value of a *WithStatement* is never the value **empty**. If evaluation of the *Statement* part of a *WithStatement* produces a normal completion whose value is **empty**, the completion value of the *WithStatement* is <span class="value">undefined</span>.

[13.11.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-runtime-semantics-caseblockevaluation): In ECMAScript 2015, the normal completion value of a *SwitchStatement* is never the value **empty**. If the *CaseBlock* part of a *SwitchStatement* does not contain *CaseClauses* or if the last evaluated *CaseClause* or *DefaultClause* produces a normal completion whose value is **empty**, the completion value of the *SwitchStatement* is <span class="value">undefined</span>.

[13.14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-try-statement): In ECMAScript 2015, it is an early error for a *Catch* clause to contained a `var` declaration for the same *Identifier* that appears as the *Catch* clause parameter. In previous editions, such a variable declaration would be instantiated in the enclosing variable environment but the declaration’s *Initializer* value would be assigned to the *Catch* parameter.

[13.14.8](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-try-statement-runtime-semantics-evaluation): In ECMAScript 2015, the normal completion value of a *TryStatement* is never the value **empty**. If the *Block* part of a *TryStatement* evaluates to a normal completion whose value is **empty**, the completion value of the *TryStatement* is <span class="value">undefined</span>. If the *Block* part of a *TryStatement* evaluates to a throw completion and it has a Catch part that evaluates to a normal completion whose value is **empty**, the completion value of the *TryStatement* is <span class="value">undefined</span>.

[14.3.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-method-definitions-runtime-semantics-propertydefinitionevaluation) In ECMAScript 2015, the function objects that are created as the values of the \[\[Get\]\] or \[\[Set\]\] attribute of accessor properties in an *ObjectLiteral* are not constructor functions and they do not have a `prototype` own property. In the previous edition, they were constructors and had a `prototype` property.

[19.1.2.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.freeze): In ECMAScript 2015, if the argument to `Object.freeze` is not an object it is treated as if it was a non-extensible ordinary object with no own properties. In the previous edition, a non-object argument always causes a <span class="value">TypeError</span> to be thrown.

[19.1.2.6](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.getownpropertydescriptor): In ECMAScript 2015, if the argument to `Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor` is not an object an attempt is made to coerce the argument using [ToObject](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-toobject). If the coercion is successful the result is used in place of the original argument value. In the previous edition, a non-object argument always causes a <span class="value">TypeError</span> to be thrown.

[19.1.2.7](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.getownpropertynames): In ECMAScript 2015, if the argument to `Object.getOwnPropertyNames` is not an object an attempt is made to coerce the argument using [ToObject](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-toobject). If the coercion is successful the result is used in place of the original argument value. In the previous edition, a non-object argument always causes a <span class="value">TypeError</span> to be thrown.

[19.1.2.9](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.getprototypeof): In ECMAScript 2015, if the argument to `Object.getPrototypeOf` is not an object an attempt is made to coerce the argument using [ToObject](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-toobject). If the coercion is successful the result is used in place of the original argument value. In the previous edition, a non-object argument always causes a **TypeError** to be thrown.

[19.1.2.11](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.isextensible): In ECMAScript 2015, if the argument to `Object.isExtensible` is not an object it is treated as if it was a non-extensible ordinary object with no own properties. In the previous edition, a non-object argument always causes a <span class="value">TypeError</span> to be thrown.

[19.1.2.12](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.isfrozen): In ECMAScript 2015, if the argument to `Object.isFrozen` is not an object it is treated as if it was a non-extensible ordinary object with no own properties. In the previous edition, a non-object argument always causes a <span class="value">TypeError</span> to be thrown.

[19.1.2.13](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.issealed): In ECMAScript 2015, if the argument to `Object.isSealed` is not an object it is treated as if it was a non-extensible ordinary object with no own properties. In the previous edition, a non-object argument always causes a <span class="value">TypeError</span> to be thrown.

[19.1.2.14](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.keys): In ECMAScript 2015, if the argument to `Object.keys` is not an object an attempt is made to coerce the argument using [ToObject](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-toobject). If the coercion is successful the result is used in place of the original argument value. In the previous edition, a non-object argument always causes a <span class="value">TypeError</span> to be thrown.

[19.1.2.15](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.preventextensions): In ECMAScript 2015, if the argument to `Object.preventExtensions` is not an object it is treated as if it was a non-extensible ordinary object with no own properties. In the previous edition, a non-object argument always causes a <span class="value">TypeError</span> to be thrown.

[19.1.2.17](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object.seal): In ECMAScript 2015, if the argument to `Object.seal` is not an object it is treated as if it was a non-extensible ordinary object with no own properties. In the previous edition, a non-object argument always causes a <span class="value">TypeError</span> to be thrown.

[19.2.3.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-function.prototype.bind): In ECMAScript 2015, the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of a [bound function](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-bound-function-exotic-objects) is set to the \[\[GetPrototypeOf\]\] value of its target function. In the previous edition, \[\[Prototype\]\] was always set to %FunctionPrototype%.

[19.2.4.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-function-instances-length): In ECMAScript 2015, the `length` property of function instances is configurable. In previous editions it was non-configurable.

[19.3.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-boolean-prototype-object): In ECMAScript 2015, the Boolean prototype object is not a Boolean instance. In previous editions it was a Boolean instance whose Boolean value was **false**.

[19.5.6.2](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-nativeerror-constructors): In ECMAScript 2015, the \[\[Prototype\]\] [internal slot](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-object-internal-methods-and-internal-slots) of a *NativeError* constructor is the Error constructor. In previous editions it was the Function prototype object.

[20.1.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-number-prototype-object) In ECMAScript 2015, the Number prototype object is not a Number instance. In previous editions it was a Number instance whose number value was +0.

[20.3.4](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-date-prototype-object) In ECMAScript 2015, the Date prototype object is not a Date instance. In previous editions it was a Date instance whose TimeValue was NaN.

[21.1.3.10](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.localecompare) In ECMAScript 2015, the `String.prototype.localeCompare` function must treat Strings that are canonically equivalent according to the Unicode standard as being identical. In previous editions implementations were permitted to ignore canonical equivalence and could instead use a bit-wise comparison.

[21.1.3](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-string-prototype-object) In ECMAScript 2015, the String prototype object is not a String instance. In previous editions it was a String instance whose String value was the empty string.

[21.1.3.22](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.tolowercase) and [21.1.3.24](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.touppercase) In ECMAScript 2015, lowercase/upper conversion processing operates on code points. In previous editions such the conversion processing was only applied to individual code units. The only affected code points are those in the Deseret block of Unicode

[21.1.3.25](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-string.prototype.trim) In ECMAScript 2015, the `String.prototype.trim` method is defined to recognize white space code points that may exists outside of the Unicode BMP. However, as of Unicode 6.1 no such code points are defined. In previous editions such code points would not have been recognized as white space.

[21.2.3.1](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-regexp-pattern-flags) In ECMAScript 2015, If the pattern argument is a RegExp instance and the flags argument is not <span class="value">undefined</span>, a new RegExp instance is created just like pattern except that pattern’s flags are replaced by the argument flags. In previous editions a **TypeError** exception was thrown when pattern was a RegExp instance and flags was not <span class="value">undefined</span>.

[21.2.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-regexp-prototype-object) In ECMAScript 2015, the RegExp prototype object is not a RegExp instance. In previous editions it was a RegExp instance whose pattern is the empty string.

[21.2.5](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-properties-of-the-regexp-prototype-object) In ECMAScript 2015, `source`, `global`, `ignoreCase`, and `multiline` are accessor properties defined on the RegExp prototype object. In previous editions they were data properties defined on RegExp instances.
